Title: Paush Purnima Vrat 2020: Puja Vidhi, Vrat Katha, Shubh Muhurat and all you need to know
Content: Paush Purnima is one of the most significant day in Hinduism, which falls on the Purnima or Full Moon day in the month of Paush as per the Hindu calendar. As per the Georgian calendar, this day is celebrated in January. Purnima symbolizes the end of a chapter in one’s life and has been always considered important for devout Hindu devotees. While Purnima takes place every month of the year, but Paush Purnima is considered as the most auspicious of all.This year, the country will celebrate the festival of Paush Purnima on Friday, January 10. Thousand of devotees on this day take a holy dip in different scared rivers, distribute goods, money to the needy and worship the deity. It is believed that by doing these things they are relieved from the cycle of life and death. Thousands of devotees gather at different holy places including Haridwar, Kashi and Prayagraj to take a holy dip and wash away their sins.This days also marks the beginning of Magh Mela 2020, which will continue till Mahashivratri (February 21). In some parts of India, Paush Purnima is known as Shakambhari Purnima. This year, the day coincides with the first Lunar Eclipse of 2020. Here are some important things you need to know about the day:The puja rituals vary from place to place. But in Northern India here is what people do on this day.-Devotees get up early in the day before sunrise to take a holy bath in the sacred rivers.-After they pray to the Sun God and Lord Vishnu. They chant their name 108 times, offer flowers, fruits, sweets and Naivedya to God. They donate money in the temple and to the priest.-There is also an ancient tradition of distributing sesame seeds, jaggery and blanket among the neddy people.-Many people also observe fast on the occasion of Paush Purnima.Someone who cannot visit a holy place to take a bath in a sacred river adds a few drops of Gangajal (the water of Holy river Ganga) in their bath water and bathe with it.You can recite the snippets from Bhagavad Gita and Ramayana on this day. People also chant the name of Lord Sun and Lord Vishnu.Paush Purnima is a one-day festival, which will be celebrated on Friday, January 10, 2020.Paush Purnima starts on January 10 at 2:30 amPaush Purnima ends on January 11 at 12:10 amThis year, Paush Purnima coincides with the first Lunar eclipse of the year. The first Lunar Eclipse of the decade will be visible from Asia, Africa, Europe and Australia. It can be seen from all over India. The Lunar Eclipse of January 10 is also called as 'Wolf Moon Eclipse and it will be across the country. The eclipse will start at 10:39 minutes on January 10 and will end at 2: 40 am on January 11.

Title: ‘Boarding schools key to personality development’
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

PATNA: Academics as well as trade body experts hailed the role of residential or boarding schools in personality development of students in a talk show held on the same topic on the premises of Bihar Industries Association here on Thursday.

Delivering the keynote address, Alokesh Sen, principal of Birla Public School (BPS)-Pilani said boarding school education inculcates deep values of life in students.

“Students become highly disciplined, self-reliant and independent at boarding schools. They become experts in managing time and quickly learn to perform domestic chores themselves, which is extremely important in day-to-day life of youth. As there are fewer distractions at boarding schools, students become more focused in their work and studies and gain maximum knowledge. Boarding school provides a wholesome environment with sports, extra-circular activities and studies which are required to maintain a well-balanced lifestyle,” Sen said.

BPS alumnus (1996 batch) and eminent radiologist Pragati Sinha said brotherhood, team spirit, mutual respect, courage, discipline, self-discipline and self-dependence were few virtues he learned in boarding school.

“Any ship sails as good as its captain sails it,” he said, adding that school culture has gone down, especially in day schools.

P K Agarwal, president, Bihar Chamber of Commerce and Industries, said personality development depends on the type of school students are going to. He shared his experience how BPS offered food and accommodation to their guests and parents as there were hardly any hotels and restaurants in Pilani. His son Sumit Agarwal graduated from BPS in 1995.

Sanjay Goenka, former vice-president of BIA , shared his experience of student days at BPS and emphasized how residential schools shape the personality of students by providing a platform for all-round development.

Arun Khandelia, president Vidya Niketan Old Boys Association (VINOBA), spoke on how the old boys’ association has created a benevolent fund, which is used for providing help to children of deceased alumnus of BPS.

Title: Patna College honours 5 retired teachers, 4 toppers
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

PATNA: Altogether five teachers and three non-teaching staff, who had retired last year, were feted at a function organized to mark the 158th foundation day of Patna College on Thursday. Four university toppers of the institute were also felicitated on the occasion.

The retired teachers were Ila Sinha, Maya Shankar, Ravi Kiran Sharma, Sufia Nasreen, and P K Poddar, while the staff included Arun Kumar, Ram Shakal Paswan, and Ram Lakhan Mahto. The four students were Tushar (English), Roshan Kumar (ancient Indian history), Somesh Kashyap (Sanskrit), and Rishav (statistics).

Patna College alumnus and Veer Kunwar Singh University’s former vice-chancellor (VC), I C Kumar, who was the chief guest of the event, recalled the glorious tradition of the institute and called upon the present generation to maintain it.

“Although the college was awarded a poor grade by the National Assessment and Accreditation Council, it still commands the respect of a lot of people of Bihar,” Kumar said.

He also unfurled the college flag and released altogether 158 balloons of different colours in the sky.

Addressing the students, PU VC Rash Bihari Prasad claimed, “There was a time when getting admitted here was a matter of pride for the students as well as their parents. Things have changed now, but we are making efforts to restore the lost glory of Patna College.”

Others, who spoke on the occasion, included college principal, Rama Shankar Arya, and his former counterparts, Nawal Kishore Chaudhary, P K Poddar, Ezaj Ali Arshad and R P Singh Rahi.

“Intellectuals should not remain in ivory towers, but come forward to resolve the present crisis, which has gripped the campuses of most premier institutions in the country. They should analyse the real cause of the growing social unrest and show the younger generation the right path,” they said.

Patna College’s sociology department head and Patna University Teachers’ Association president, Randhir Kumar Singh, proposed the vote of thanks.

Established in 1863, Patna College owes its distinct identity to the nature and mode of its response to social issues. Its teachers and students actively participated in the national freedom movement and it was here that Lok Nayak Jayaprakash Narayan first presented his ideas of a ‘total revolution’.

Academics are of the view that the history of Patna College is synonymous with the history of the growth and development of higher education in the region. It has exercised a profoundly significant influence on the lives of its people in many ways.

The college, which provided the backdrop to English novelist E M Forster’s ‘A Passage to India’ and film director Satyajit Ray’s ‘Seemabaddha’, has been the mother of a number of institutions of higher education in Bihar, including the erstwhile Bihar College of Engineering (now NIT-Patna), Patna Law College, Patna Medical College, Patna Science College and Vanijya Mahavidyalaya.

Title: Kathiawadi horses, horsemen saddle up for Jan 18 show
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Participants practising at Popatpara police ground

Rajkot: Nearly 60 Kathiawadi horses will take part in the equestrian show to be organized in Rajkot on January 18 as a part of state-level Republic Day celebrations.

The cynosure of the event, apart from the elegant horses jumping and barrel racing, is the 13-year-old boy from the city, Jay Vyas, the youngest rider in the event.

Participants are currently practising in the Popatpara police mountaineer ground where the event is scheduled to be held.

President of Kathiawadi horse breeders association, Ghanshyamji Maharaj said, “Kathiawadi horses are known for their strength. We have invited those breeders who have taken the part in the earlier shows. This time we will have some Indian games and an American game in the show.”

Jay has been into horse riding for the past two years and is a Class 7 student in a Gujarati-medium school in Rajkot. He has completed the 4km obstacle ride organized in Maharashtra last year and was also qualified for the 20km endurance race organized in Palanpur last year.

Talking to TOI, Jay’s father Chetan Vyas said: “I was also a rider and Jay has been interested in horse riding since his childhood. I try to help him participate in all the games played in Rajkot.”

“I loved playing with horses since I was five years old. I love horses and aim to be become a professional horse jockey one day,” gushed the teenage equestrian enthusiast.

Rajkot rural police is providing all possible help to the horse breeders. A participant in the event and a businessman, Chandresh Dangar, told TOI, “I have been attracted to horses since my childhood. I love them as they are very loyal animals. I take part in all possible horse shows. It keeps one physically fit.”

Title: More benches, food kiosks at Patna zoo by July
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

PATNA: Animals, birds, reptiles, trees, medicinal plants and flowers at Sanjay Gandhi Biological Park, commonly known as Patna zoo , will get quick response (QR) codes soon. The facility will help people get all information just by scanning the QR codes tagged near the enclosures and nurseries at the zoo on their smartphones.

The QR facility and several other amenities will be introduced at the zoo with the help of Rs 2.75 crore contributed by the Airport Authority of India (AAI) under its corporate social responsibility (CSR) initiative.

Patna zoo director Amit Kumar said a software and mobile application would be prepared to scan the barcodes. “The initiative is aimed at making visitors aware about the species, age, common name, zoological and botanical name and lifespan of animals, birds, reptiles, aquatic animals, trees and flowers,” he said.

A per the CSR proposal, the interpretation centre and educational centre at the zoo will be equipped with interactive kiosks, touch screens and digital games related to forest and environment.

Amit said around Rs 2 crore would be spent on installation of electronic gadgets at a gallery in interpretation-cum-3D centre which will be operational by June. “Some electronic devices, including augmented reality technology, will be installed at educational centres as well. The bidding for the same will start soon,” he said.

Amit added, “Around 10 electronic kiosks will be installed at the gallery of interpretation centre and some touchscreens will be installed at the garden near the centre. Children can learn names of animal and birds and hear sounds they make on touchscreens.”

“All the analogue signage inside zoo premises will be replaced with electronic signage. Electronic signage will also be installed outside the Patna zoo enclosures to display details of animals,” the zoo director said.

As far as the basic amenities is concerned, more sitting kiosks, benches, lamp posts, water kiosks and food kiosks will come up at the zoo by July this year.

Giraffe calf welcomed: A giraffe at Patna zoo gave birth to a calf at 4pm on Wednesday under the care of veterinary doctors from Bihar Veterinary College. With this the giraffe count at the zoo has increased to six. The male calf of six feet was born to ‘Shanti’ and ‘Bhima’.

Patna zoo director Amit Kumar said the mother and the baby were doing fine. “They have been kept in a separate enclosure away from public glare. This will help the new member adapt to the surroundings. The mother is taking care of the calf and nurturing it by herself,” he said. Earlier, a female giraffe ‘Hema’ was born in May to ‘Shristi’.

Title: Dawood aide Lakdawala arrested in Patna
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

PATNA: Ejaz Yusuf Lakdawala , a close associate of Dawood Ibrahim, was arrested by a joint team of Mumbai police’s crime branch and Bihar STF near Patna railway station on Wednesday morning.

The four-member Mumbai crime branch team led by DCP Shahji Umap took Lakdawala into custody around 10.30 am while he was on his way to Patna airport. Sources said he had hired a cab after arriving at Mithapur bus terminus from Nepal.

ADG (operations) Sushil Mansingh Khopde said senior officials of Mumbai crime branch were in touch with the Bihar STF since Tuesday evening. “They had definite information about the arrival of Lakdawala in Patna as they were tracking him for a while. Our team cooperated with the Mumbai police in the operation,” he told TOI.

Khopde, who was recently promoted to ADG rank, said the visiting team left for Mumbai with the fugitive gangster after completing legal formalities at the Jakkanpur police station in Patna. “We provided security to the members of the visiting team before it left for its destination,” he added.

The SHO of Jakkanpur police station, Mukesh Kumar Verma, said they handed over the wanted criminal around 12.10 pm after completing the legal formalities. “The accused was brought to the police station at 10.35 am. Inspector Sachin Kadam, who was part of the four-member Mumbai team, gave in writing that the accused would be produced in court within 24 hours,” Verma said.

He said the Mumbai police team had sought the cooperation of the local police in the operation, which lasted about 15 minutes. “The Mumbai police team along with officials of the state STF earlier visited the police station around 10 am and sought our cooperation to arrest a fugitive. We sent our team accordingly,” the SHO said.

ADG Khopde said as there was no case pending against Lakdawala in Bihar, the state STF neither detained him nor interrogated him. “The Mumbai crime branch team showed documents of cases in which he (Lakdawala) was evading arrest,” Khopde added.

Sources in the police headquarters said Lakdawala was residing in Nepal’s Pokhara. He used to make extortion calls to several builders and other affluent businessmen of Mumbai from Nepal. Pokhara, a tourist destination, has, of late, become a safe haven for gangsters and terrorists operating in India.

Earlier, Indian Mujahideen (India) co-founder Yasin Bhatkal, was arrested by NIA at Raxual on the India-Nepal border in East Champaran district in August 2013. “Bihar is being used as a safe route by gangsters and terrorists to reach their destinations in different parts of the country from Nepal,” a senior intelligence officer said.

Title: Ashok Leyland, ABB Power tie up for flash charge tech
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Chennai: Truck and bus maker Ashok Leyland and ABB Power Products and Systems India have signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) in the electric bus transportation space to improve load sharing and reduce charging efficiency.

The MoU outlines a partnership to develop a pilot electric bus based on ABB’s flash-charge technology, TOSA, which tops up the battery in just seconds while passengers get on and off the bus. This avoids the need to take the vehicle out of service for recharging every few hours or having a replacement bus ready, thus minimizing the size of the fleet while increasing passenger carrying capacity. “We are pushing the boundaries of e-mobility with our flash-charging technology TOSA for buses. The aim is to provide a zero local emission mass public transportation bus system with high passenger capacity. We are pleased to be working with Ashok Leyland in advancing responsible urban mobility,” said N Venu, MD, ABB Power Products and Systems India (ABB Power Grids’ business in India).

Ashok Leyland has already kicked off its electric mobility play with e-buses and for this pilot will develop and manufacture electric buses with ABB’s TOSA flash-charging technology along with operational support and service. “To stay competitive in our domestic and global markets, we are joining hands with ABB to use their world-renowned TOSA technology on our e-buses to take forward our vision of expanding in the EV space,” said N Saravanan, chief technology officer, Ashok Leyland.

Title: SoftBank ropes in Google India exec
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

TNN

Bengaluru: SoftBank Vision Fund has roped in Vikas Agnihotri , who was till recently Google India ’s interim country head, as its first operating partner in the country. He will work to foster closer connections with the region’s technology ecosystem and the SoftBank Vision Fund’s global network, according to a statement. Agnihotri’s addition comes as SoftBank Vision Fund has been building a team in India, which started with the hiring of Sumer Juneja last year to lead investments.

Agnihotri spent over a decade at Google in different leadership roles and also has experience in wealth management, finance and banking operations in his 25-year career. His exit comes after Google announced former Star and Disney India head, Sanjay Gupta , as its country manager in November.

SoftBank Vision Fund, which has come under scrutiny after the failed IPO of WeWork last year, has invested over $10 billion in India in companies like Paytm , Oyo , Ola and Policybazaar .

Title: WB team holds second round of talks with SMC on funding projects
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Surat: A seven-member team of World Bank from its India unit is on a two-day visit to the city for second time in two months to hold discussions with officials of Surat Municipal Corporation on funding a few of major development projects of the civic body.

The team held talks with municipal commissioner Bancchanidhi Pani and other civic officials here on Thursday. A three-member team of World Bank had visited Surat on November 24, 2019.

Surat is looking for funds worth Rs5,000 crore for construction of Tapi riverfront and Outer Ring Road project. The city administration is exploring the possibility of financial assistance in the form of either grant or loan. Pani told TOI, “World Bank has shown keen interest in some of our projects. We are eager for assistance for Tapi riverfront and Outer Ring Road projects. The World Bank officials during discussions with us today went into micro details of these projects. The discussions are in advanced stage and will continue.” Tapi riverfront is Rs3,900 crore worth project and Outer Ring Road will entail an expense of Rs5,000 crore. These projects are expected to generate revenue up to Rs5,000 crore in five years for the civic body.

The World Bank team comprised Harsh Goyal and Ankush Sharma besides five consultants. They were given detailed information about projects, finances, land monetization, public utility space etc, civic officials said.

SMC has never taken any financial assistance from any foreign financial institution till now. In 2018-19 it did raise Rs200 crore through bonds from Indian market for its sewage treatment plant (STP) and tertiary treatment plants (TTP).

Title: Patna records highest murder rate among 19 cities
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: The state capital recorded the highest rate of murder among 19 metropolitan cities across the country in 2018, as per data released by the National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB) on Thursday.

The rate of murder in Patna stood at 4.4 murders per one lakh population, which was the highest after Jaipur (3.1), followed by Lucknow which has a murder rate of 2.9.

Patna also figured on top in dowry deaths category with the corresponding rate standing at 2.5 deaths per one lakh population. Kanpur also shared the same rate of dowry deaths, jointly sharing the top slot in the category.

However, Patna has seen a reduction in the number of incidents in the category of Indian Penal Code (IPC) and special and local laws (SPL) crimes, according to the NRCB report for 2018. The total number of such crimes in the two categories came down from 20,980 in 2017 to 17,572 in 2018.

The number of cognizable crime incidents in Bihar increased by 26,760 cases in 2018 as compared to the previous year. Altogether 2,62,815 cases of cognizable crimes were registered in the state in 2018, comprising 1,96,911 IPC and 65,904 SPL crime cases. In 2017, the total number of cognizable crime cases was 2,36,055, including 1,80,573 IPC and 55482 SPL crime incidents.

The rate of murder in the entire state in 2018 stood at 2.2, which is significantly lesser than other states, including Jharkhand, Arunachal Pradesh and Assam, where it was recorded at 4.6, 4.2 and 3.6 respectively.

Bihar also witnessed 179 incidents of human trafficking in 2018, involving 231 victims, which was the highest rate in the country in category. Bihar also witnessed highest number of cases of property dispute in the country, accounting for 6,608 incidents. Every 5.6 person per one lakh of the population in the state was affected by property dispute.

Altogether 18,665 cases of auto/motor vehicle theft were registered in the state, while the incident of simple theft stood at 12,902. Over 4,600 burglary incidents were also reported. As per the data, no incident of obscene act and songs at public places were recorded in Bihar.

Patna SSP Upendra Kumar Sharma said a special drive was being conducted to crackdown on crimes such as murder, dacoity and dowry death . “I joined a week back and since then we have arrested 62 such culprits. The drive is on,” Sharma added. He further said dowry deaths in most cases occur when victims continue to face suffering and atrocities, instead of complaining to the police.

Title: Bihar: Cold day forecast for two days from today
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Girls wearing woolen clothes during cold weather in Patna. (File photo)

PATNA: Following light to moderate showers at many places in central and south Bihar on Wednesday night, most places in the state witnessed cloudy skies on Thursday. According to weathermen, clouds will start getting clearer by Friday, paving way for plunge in temperature along with dense fog in morning hours for a few days.

India Meteorological Department (IMD) issued a warning for cold day conditions at isolated places in the state on Friday and Saturday. Cold day condition is declared when the minimum temperature touches 10 degrees C or low and there is a departure of 4.5-6.4 degrees C in maximum temperature on two consecutive days.

Patna Meteorological Centre, on the other hand, also stated in its daily weather bulletin that night temperatures would gradually fall by three to five notches for three days from Saturday.

The IMD has also issued forecast for dense fog at few places in the state over the next three days.

The daily bulletin issued by Patna Meteorological Centre on Thursday evening stated that Patna, Jehanabad, Bhabhua, Ekangarsarai, Lalbegiya Ghat, Kodawanpur, Garhi, Ramnagar, Bihpur, Rosera and Jamui received showers over the last 24 hours.

Bhagalpur witnessed 3.8mm rainfall between 8.30am and 5.30pm on Thursday. Meteorologists have attributed the showers to a western disturbance and claimed that its impact in Bihar would reduce from Thursday.

“The western disturbance crossed Bihar and moved towards north-eastern districts. Accordingly, the clouds are expected to start getting clearer from Friday evening, which will lead to drop in night temperature over the next two to three days,” said an official at Patna Meteorological Centre.

He added that sharp plunge in minimum temperature is expected in the region owing to snowfall in the Himalayan peaks in north India.

Patna Meteorological Centre has predicted that minimum and maximum temperature in the state capital would hover in the range of 18-20 and 8-10 degrees C, respectively, till Sunday.

At 8 degrees C, lowest minimum temperature in the state was recorded at Sabour in Bhagalpur district on Thursday.

Meanwhile, a fresh western disturbance is likely to affect western Himalayan region from January 11 night onwards. Western disturbances are low pressure area or extratropical storms originating from Mediterranean Sea , Red Sea and Caspian Sea, which cause snow and winter rainfalls in northwestern Indian subcontinent .

Officials at the Patna Meteorological Centre said the upcoming western disturbance would be of low intensity with not much impact on the weather system in Bihar.

Title: Over 70% vehicles still without FASTags in Bihar
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Long queue of vehicles at a toll plaza on Patna-Bakhtiyarpur NH on Thursday.

PATNA: Over 70% vehicles arriving at toll plazas on national highways across the state do not carry radio-frequency identification (RFID) tags, popularly known as FASTags . In Patna , more than 65% vehicles pass through different toll plazas on national highways without FASTags.

“Only 30% of total vehicles, including trucks, buses and cars, have FASTag stickers pasted on their windscreens. We have allotted two lanes for vehicles without FASTag stickers. Police force has also been deployed for keeping an eye on vehicles without the tags,” said Sanjeev Kumar, manager of a toll plaza on Patna-Bakhtiyarpur NH-30.

The Union ministry of road transport and highways made FASTags mandatory for vehicles from December 1 last year. However, due to less number of vehicles with FAStags, the deadline was extended till December 15. Thereafter, the Centre, through a letter, announced that 25% of all lanes at toll plazas will be earmarked as hybrid lanes, where vehicles without FASTags can cross by paying cash for another 30 days. The remaining 75% of the lanes were dedicated to vehicles with FASTags.

With the deadline of January 15 for electronic clearing of vehicles at toll plazas approaching, sales of FASTags at various toll plazas have picked up. “More than 150 vehicles get FASTag stickers on a daily basis – 60% private vehicles and the remaining public vehicles,” said Kumar, adding that motorists without FASTags will be penalized after January 15.

“Even though we have the provision of taking fines from motorists entering FASTag lanes without the RFID tags pasted on their vehicles, we aren’t fining them. Instead, we make them aware about the procedure of getting the tags,” said an official.

A senior National Highway Authority of India (NHAI) official said, “FASTags are easily available at all the toll plazas on national highways. It hardly takes 30 minutes to get the sticker pasted on windscreen of a vehicle. One can get the FASTags online too,” he said.

The official added, “All NH toll plazas in the state have been converted into FASTag lanes. Only one lane has been allotted to vehicles without FASTags due to which long queues are witnessed at toll plazas. It’s time now for people to get FASTags as it will not just save their time, but also reduce chaos at toll plazas.”

Motorists, on the other hand, are having a tough time crossing through toll plazas on NHs. “I got stuck on Patna-Bakhtiyarpur NH-30 toll plaza for more than an hour. The queue for motorists entering the cash lane was too long,” said Farhan Ahmed.

Another motorist, Sanjay Sinha, said FASTag lanes mostly remain empty.

Title: Why was DMK mum when UPA didn’t back SL refugees’ case: Smriti
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Madurai/Trichy/Chennai: Under fire from the opposition parties and allies over the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Register of Citizens (NRC), the Narendra Modi government has gone into firefighting mode deploying ministers Ravi Shankar Prasad and Smriti Irani as well as BJP general secretary Ram Madhav to clear the air over the issues in the state.

“When you had so many opportunities to show your sympathy towards Sri Lankan Tamil refugees and other minorities when the UPA government came up with policies which against their welfare why did you not react,” asked Union Minister of Women and Child Development and Textiles, Smriti Irani, while addressing a pro-CAA rally at Sellur on Thursday. Speaking at the ‘Janjagran Abhiyan’, she said they had gathered there because all those who were participating in the rally had put the nation first. “Seventy-two years ago, our motherland was ripped apart in the name of religion to side with those who were against the nation’s welfare, and worked with the British,” she said. She said she remembers poet Subramania Bharathi’s vision for India. ``We recall the sacrifices of the Indians beyond caste and religion, so that they can live in dignity, but the DMK has joined hands with those who shamed those sacrifices,’’ she said. ‘When the November 2007 special commission for rehabilitation did not entertain citizenship for Sri Lankan refugees under the UPA government why did you remain silent?’’ she asked. At Chennai, Union law minister Ravi Shankar Prasad said the government will hold talks with allies and take them into confidence. He was responding to a question on Chief Minister Edappadi K Palaniswami’s statement in the assembly that he had told Home Minister Amit Shah that NRC was not acceptable to the AIADMK government. On NRC, he said, “There are provisions that the date for NRC shall be announced, there will be verification, hearing of objections and disposal of objections and appeal against that. Nothing has been decided at all including the date.”

Addressing a meet organized by BJP at Trichy, party national general secretary Ram Madhav said, “Some leaders in Tamil Nadu are opposing the Act. If we ask them reason for their opposition, they do not have answers. Those who opposing the Act really do not know anything about it”, he said. "I appeal to Muslim brothers not to fall prey to the false propaganda of opposition parties. This bill is not against Muslims or Christians”, he added. Party national executive committee member L Ganesan, actor Gautami and general secretary M Muruganantham too participated.
