Title: Maximum road accidents reported in MP between 6 -9 pm, says NCRB data
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Bhopal: The latest traffic accidents report released by National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB) has revealed some startling statistics. Most of the road accidents reported in Madhya Pradesh in 2018 took place in three hours of the evening, between 6pm and 9 pm, states data released by NCRB.

In all, 8988 accidents were reported in the state during this three-hour period in the evening, this is the second highest figure after Tamil Nadu where 14238 accidents were reported during the same period. In 2018, 47469 accidents were reported in MP in which 51149 people were injured and 11427 people lost their lives.

In Bhopal, highest number of road accidents were reported during peak office hours between 9 am and 12 pm. According to NCRB report, 2675 road accidents were reported in Bhopal in which 2188 people were injured, and 149 people died. Contrary to NCRB report, the figures maintained by Bhopal traffic police state that 3508 accidents were reported in the city in 2018 in which 3001 people were injured and 327 people died.

In 2018, the highest number of road accidents were reported in the month of January, both in the state and the city. 4841 accidents were reported in MP in January while 265 were reported in Bhopal. Stray cattle menace caused many casualties during the year across the state. 318 accidents were caused by stray cattle in the state in which 499 people died and 114 injuries were reported. However, none of the accident was listed under this category in Bhopal in the report.

13024 accidents reportedly took place in the state due to dangerous/ careless driving and overtaking in which 13960 people were injured and 3604 people died. Overspeeding caused 25020 accidents in the state which claimed 5815 lives and left 27791 injured. 727 drunk driving accidents took place in the state in which 889 people were injured and 195 deaths were reported.

In Bhopal, dangerous driving and overtaking caused 1986 accidents in which 1494 people were injured and 112 died. In 135 cases of accidents caused by overspeeding ,155 people were injured and seven died. Merely five cases of drunk driving accidents were reported in the city in 2018 in which six people were injured.

The report states that lack of road infrastructure caused 263 accidents in MP in which 251 people were injured and 40 people lost their lives. 1844 accidents were due to unknown causes in which 1812 people were injured and 377 people died across the state. Only five accidents were caused by lack of road infrastructure in Bhopal in which five people were injured and no death was reported. 162 accidents were listed due to unknown causes in the city in which 194 were injured and 12 people died.

Title: Tamil Nadu most unsafe state for the elderly
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Tamil Nadu remains one of the most unsafe states for the elderly in the country. According to NCRB data, 152 senior citizens were murdered in Tamil Nadu in 2018, the highest in the country, followed by Maharashtra (135) and Uttar Pardesh (127).

While the numbers are alarming, Tamil Nadu also has a higher percentage of senior citizens, 11.2%, compared to other states. In the overall crime rate against senior citizens, Tamil Nadu is third with 3,162 cases.

Maharashtra, where the elderly population is less than 10%, recorded the maximum number of crimes against senior citizens at 5,961, followed by Madhya Pradesh, which has less than 8% senior citizens, with 3,967 cases.

Tamil Nadu also recorded the highest number of attempt-to-murder cases against senior citizens, 76. There were 182 cases of robbery and 16 extortion cases in which the elderly were targeted.

Activists said the high incidence of robberies, in which 184 senior citizens were targeted, highlighted how criminals found the elderly population an easy target.

Police said they have strengthened patrolling and all city police stations have been directed to collect details of senior citizens living alone.

A senior police officer said personnel on beat patrol have been assigned to enumerate the elderly in their neighbourhoods.

“Those living alone become soft targets of miscreants as they cannot fight back,” said Chandrasekar, a member of Senior Citizens Group Of Besant Nagar and Mylapore.

Title: DMK, allies want quota for Anglo-Indians to continue
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Nancy Ann Cynthia Francis

CHENNAI: The Tamil Nadu assembly on Thursday passed a resolution ratifying the amendment to the Constitution, as passed by both Houses of Parliament, extending quota to SC/ST in Lok Sabha and state assembly by another 10 years. While the bill does not extend the reservation for Anglo-Indians by way of nomination, which is set to expire on January 25, the DMK and its allies, Congress and IUML demanded that the nomination should continue.

Lone Anglo-Indian nominee in the House, Nancy Ann Cynthia Francis said the community was a ‘minor minority’ in terms of linguistic, religion and numbers and deprived of privilege in the assembly. “It is really heartbreaking,” she said, pointing to the contributions made by the community in educational institutions, railway and postal services. DMK leader S Durai Murugan, Congress whip S Vijayadharani and IUML MLA Md Abu Backer demanded that the nomination be allowed to continue.

Deputy chief minister O Panneerselvam said during the debate in Parliament, the AIADMK MPs, along with Samajwadi Party, BSP, BJD, JD(U), the DMK, AAP, JD (S), YSR Congress, RJD and the Left parties had demanded that the Centre consider extending reservation to Anglo Indians under the bill, besides meeting the minister in person. “The minister also assured that the request would be considered,” the deputy CM said.

Title: Special cell to gather intelligence
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Coimbatore: The rural police have set up a special intelligence cell (SIC) to gather intelligence from Mettupalayam and Pollachi, which are considered communally sensitive.

The unit is headed by inspector N Suseela. The department has appointed one cop each for Karumathampatti, Perur, Pollachi and Valparai sub-divisions and two for the Periyanaickenpalayam sub-division.

The unit will keep an eye on the Hindu and Muslim outfits active in the areas, police sources said. During the Ganesh Chaturthi festival, large number of police personnel are deployed in both the places to prevent any untoward incidents.

The decision to set up the SIC was taken at a review meeting conducted by director general of police (DGP) JK Tripahty at the police guest house here a few months ago. Superintendent of police Sujit Kumar had suggested the need for such a unit.

The Coimbatore city police and the Madurai city police had earlier set up SICs to gather information about terrorism, IS sympathisers and the outfits trying to create communal divide.

The commissioner of police monitors the operation of SICs.

Title: Bad roads killed 266 in Chennai
Content:
Roads dug up by different government agencies are mostly left unattended after work and become unmotorable.

CHENNAI: Bad roads in Chennai have killed more motorists than reckless driving, according to National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB) Accident Report 2018.While 266 died due to lack of proper road infrastructure, 62 lost their lives to careless driving or overtaking.Chennai topped the city-wise comparison chart by accounting for 80% of such deaths across the country followed by Prayagraj (33). Every other city in the list reported single-digit figures.Roads dug up by different government agencies are mostly left unattended after work and become unmotorable. “Roads are being laid overnight which is even more dangerous for motorists as patchworks remain uncovered,” said V S Jayaraman, founder member of T Nagar Residents Welfare Association. “When we talk about good road, it should all be well lit,” he said.Officials from Greater Chennai Corporation claimed they have made ‘adequate efforts’ before every monsoon to ensure roads were safe. The corporation claims to have spent more than Rs 120 crore every year to maintain existing bus route roads and fill around 1,400 potholes. But a ride across most roads tell a different story.“We are happy to see that police are finally recording the correct reason for deaths in FIRs. Earlier, they never mentioned road infra as a reason in order to prevent other government agencies from paying compensation,” said Srinivasan, a high court advocate.But a state transport department official said action has been taken against erring officials in such cases. “Last year, two Tamil Nadu Road Development Corporation officials were suspended for negligence in this aspect,” he said.Sivasubramaniam Jayaraman from Institute for Transportation and Development Policy said along with good roads, proper driving behaviour and strict enforcement of the law can bring down road fatalities. Given the 10% increase in vehicular population, more accidents could happen. So driving behaviour needs to change and should be a subject at school, he saidA senior officer from the Chennai traffic police said that there was very little awareness about rules among motorists. “Just look at the number of vehicles parked in no-parking zones on every street. Do we need anything else to show utter disregard for rules,” he said.The NCRB report shows that 73 people died in 392 accidents caused by vehicles parked illegally on road shoulders — highest in the country.The report suggested that motorists in Chennai cared little about their vehicles. Around 400 accidents were reported in 2018 due to mechanical defects in vehicles.

Title: DMK, allies want quota for Anglo-Indians to continue
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Nancy Ann Cynthia Francis

CHENNAI: The Tamil Nadu assembly on Thursday passed a resolution ratifying the amendment to the Constitution, as passed by both Houses of Parliament, extending quota to SC/ST in Lok Sabha and state assembly by another 10 years. While the bill does not extend the reservation for Anglo-Indians by way of nomination, which is set to expire on January 25, the DMK and its allies, Congress and IUML demanded that the nomination should continue.

Lone Anglo-Indian nominee in the House, Nancy Ann Cynthia Francis said the community was a ‘minor minority’ in terms of linguistic, religion and numbers and deprived of privilege in the assembly. “It is really heartbreaking,” she said, pointing to the contributions made by the community in educational institutions, railway and postal services. DMK leader S Durai Murugan, Congress whip S Vijayadharani and IUML MLA Md Abu Backer demanded that the nomination be allowed to continue.

Deputy chief minister O Panneerselvam said during the debate in Parliament, the AIADMK MPs, along with Samajwadi Party, BSP, BJD, JD(U), the DMK, AAP, JD (S), YSR Congress, RJD and the Left parties had demanded that the Centre consider extending reservation to Anglo Indians under the bill, besides meeting the minister in person. “The minister also assured that the request would be considered,” the deputy CM said.

Title: Union ministers will visit Kashmir from Feb: Kishan
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Hyderabad: Union minister of state for home affairs G Kishan Reddy said that all Union ministers would begin visiting Kashmir from February to quell fears of the Kashmiri people.

Interacting with the media during ‘Meet the Press’ programme on Thursday, he said that there was a general misconception among Kashmiris that outsiders will usurp their land. “The investors’ meet in Kashmir has been deferred for the same reason. The Centre is in the process of identifying government land in the state to set up educational institutions and hospitals, but industrialists from other states are also showing keen interest in investing in the state for the state’s development,” he said.

He said that gram panchayats in the region have started receiving funds from the Centre for the first time. “We are not against any religion, every decision is taken in the interest of the country,” he said.

Ridiculing the statement of Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan, who said that there would be a war-like situation in Kashmir after Section 144 is lifted, he said nothing of that sort had happened. “The state is peaceful, and the Centre will take all steps to see that Kashmir becomes an integral part of the country,” he said.

Title: Bhopal airport will have its third aerobridge by February-end
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

The underconstruction aerobridge

BHOPAL: The Raja Bhoj airport will get its third aerobridge by February-end. Installation of aerobridge, which is being imported from China, will start by the end of this month.

At present Bhopal airport has two aerobridges. The need for another aerobridge was felt after a huge surge in footfall and flight movement in 2019.

With the arrival of SpiceJet and IndiGo airlines, traffic has considerably increased at Bhopal. This could be gauged from the fact that last year around 5 lakh more passengers travelled from Bhopal airport. There are now more than 34 regular flights a day operated by Air India, IndiGo and SpiceJet and the number is likely to go up to 40 by this summer.

Airport director Anil Vikram said, “This calls for at least another aerobridge to handle the volume of passengers embarking and alighting.”

About the installation process, director Vikram said, “We are hoping to get the aerobridge by January 25. After that a team of experts will come to install. We will prepare a report to send it to headquarters of Airport Authority of India.” He added that after installation site inspection will be conducted. “We will do the safety assessment of the installed aerobridge. A report will be prepared about it. We will send the report to AAI’s headquarters.”

AAI will send the report to DGCA for its approval. “Once DGCA approves, the aerobridge will start functioning,” Vikram further said.

This one is being imported from China, Vikram said, adding, “It will cost us around Rs 2.5 crore while the complete cost of installing the aerobridge is Rs 8.5 cr.” Existing two aerobridges in operation were installed by an Indonesian firm in 2014. Incidentally, Bhopal airport has also got the nod for installation of fourth aerobridge and installation work will start soon.

Vikram said with the start of new airlines, Bhopal airport is getting more traction on the national map. “Things are moving in the right direction. Infrastructure at Bhopal airport is bigger than Indore’s Devi Ahilya Bai Holkar airport,” he pointed out, adding that with the installation of third aerobridge facilities will definitely be increased.

Title: State improves ranking in hydrology project review
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Kerala, which witnessed floods of catastrophic dimensions consecutively in the past two years, seems to have learned some vital lessons. In the latest review of the national hydrology project, the state has improved its ranking from 13 to 8.

In the ranking of around 44 agencies, including states, union territories and river basins, Kerala ranks above states like Andhra Pradesh, which gives a lot of focus on irrigation and farming. The project, fully funded by World Bank, began in 2016 and is expected to be implemented by 2024. The state has secured the satisfactory rating in the mid-term review.

Around Rs 42 crore will be granted to the state for the project. The project involves studying hydro-meteorological data in real time by introducing various instruments such as rain gauge stations, river gauge stations, and monitoring of river data, among other things.

It involves collection of data on the quality of water that flows through the 44 rivers in the state, as well as on annual rainfall, besides improving the quality and the number of data-collection instruments. The World Bank will also provide training for officials.

Water resources department of Gujarat and Damodar Valley Corporation secured the first and second rankings while Rajasthan was ranked in the third position. The Irrigation Design and Research Board (IDRB) under the Water Resources department is co-ordinating the project in the state. K A Johny, chief engineer of IDRB, said the state has taken a slew of measures such as setting up of early flood warning system, which helped in improving its ranking.

The state is planning to introduce a decision-support system at Bharathappuzha river basin system to collect real time data and improve flood management, he said. For example, analysis data of inflow, carrying capacity of river, etc can be used to decide on the need to evacuate people from river banks,” he said. Johny said water resources department’s proactive measures such as room for river programme and the decision to introduce flood-control dams will improve the situation in the state.

Title: Plans afoot to set up more all women police stations
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Coimbatore: While the rural police have sent a proposal to set up two all women police stations (AWPS) at Valparai and Karumathampatti sub-divisions, the city police have also expressed interest to set up one at the Coimbatore south sub-division.

The rural police, which have Periyanaickenpalayam, Perur, Pollachi, Valparai and Karumathampatti sub-divisions and 35 police stations under its jurisdiction, have only three AWPS at Perur, Periyanaickenpalayam and Pollachi.

“We have sent proposals to the headquarters in Chennai to set up two more AWPS at Karumathampatti and Valparai sub-divisions. Once they become operational, women from these places won’t have to travel far to other stations to lodge complaints,” police superintendent Sujit Kumar said.

Currently, residents of Karumathampatti, Annur, Kovilpalayam and Sulur travel 30 kilometres to lodge complaints at the Perur AWPS.

Of the four sub-divisions in the Coimbatore city, only central, west and east have AWPS. Those staying in the south sub-division travel to RS Puram (AWPS -west) to lodge complaints.

Title: PIL for 5% quota for Tamil medium students in MBBS
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: The Madras high court on Thursday ordered notice to the state government on a PIL seeking 5% reservation in admission to MBBS courses in all government medical colleges for students who did school education in Tamil medium.

Admitting the plea moved by N Murugesan of Dharmapuri, a division bench of Justice M Sathyanarayanan and Justice R Hemalatha directed the state to file its reply by February 20.

The petitioner, quoting an RTI response, said that of the 5,400 MBBS seats available in Tamil Nadu medical colleges, only less than 5% seats were secured by students who had studied in Tamil medium. The petitioner said in the academic year 2016-17 only 537 Tamil medium students got seats in MBBS course. In 2017-18 this reduced to 52 students.

Similarly, in the academic year 2018-19 only 106 Tamil medium students got admission to MMBS course in state colleges, which constitutes only 2% of the total seats, he said.

Such circumstance has created a false image among students who are pursuing school education in Tamil that they would not be able to secure a MBBS seat in government run medical college, he said.

The petitioner further added that our neighbouring state – Karnataka is already implementing 5% reservation in medical seats for candidates who have completed school education in Kannada medium.

The Tamil Nadu government which takes several steps for the growth and to safeguard Tamil language should also provide such reservation which would encourage more students to opt for Tamil medium in school education, he said.

Since the government has not responded to a representation made by him on November 4, 2019 and the schedule for NEET exam are nearing for the academic year 2019-20 the petition has moved the high court.

Title: Bengalis in city all set for a grand Poush Mela
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Chennai: With tribal dancers from Ooty and Baul singers from Bengal, the Poush Mela or winter festival , hosted by the Bengali associations of Chennai, promises to be an “amalgamation of the cultures of the two states”, says Ravi Shankar Roy, a part of the Chennai Banga Sanskriti Sammelan Samiti which is organising the fair.

The winter mela will be held from January 10 to 12 from noon to 10pm, but will kickstart with a procession on Friday evening through the streets of T Nagar, where singers and dancers and members of the community will herald the beginning of the harvest season. “Bengali communities across the country celebrate the Poush Mela but this is the first time we are hosting it in Chennai,” says Roy. “For the past six years we have been hosting a Banga Mela in April, which is a cultural programme, but we decided to start off the year with these celebrations.”

The mela will feature stalls of sari makers, artisans and ‘pitha makers’, says Roy. Pithas are a dish made from a batter of rice flour or wheat flour, which are stuffed with sweet or savory ingredients. “We are bringing pitha-making specialists from West Bengal.”

Another highlight would be the stall on Krishnanagar’s clay dolls, famed for their realistic depiction of everyday rural life. One will also get to sample the famous ‘nolen gur rosgulla’, made in the winter season from boiling the sap of date palm.

“The idea is to get Chennai to celebrate our winter festival with us in true Bengali style,” says Roy.

Title: School edu dept seeks list of retiring teachers
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Coimbatore: The department of school education has asked chief education officers of al districts to send the list of PG teachers in government schools, who would retire in the academic year 2020-2021. This is to prepare a draft list of vacant posts that would come up as a result of the retirements and to fill the posts, said a communication from the director of school education.

The communication said the CEOs should send a list of PG teachers, grade-I physical education directors who retire this academic year.

Teachers, meanwhile said there were around 2,000 PG teachers, who handle Classes XI and XII. The recent PG teacher recruitment board (TRB) selection test conducted recently was still under process and they expected it to be completed by this month-end.

Sources also said by the end of the academic year, in each district, 20 OG teachers would retire and across the state, in total, 500 PG teacher posts would fall vacant. TNN

Title: BJP ministers, leader in firefighting mode, hold pro-CAA rallies in Tamil Nadu
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Union minister Smriti Irani addresses a pro-CAA rally in Madurai on Thursday

CHENNAI/MADURAI: Under fire from the opposition parties and allies over the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) and National Register of Citizens ( NRC ), the Narendra Modi government has gone into firefighting mode deploying ministers Ravi Shankar Prasad and Smriti Irani as well as BJP general secretary Ram Madhav to clear the air over the issues in the state.

“We will hold talks with our allies and take them into confidence,” said Union law minister Ravi Shankar Prasad in Chennai while responding to a question on chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami’s statement in the assembly that he had told home minister Amit Shah that NRC was not acceptable to the AIADMK government.

Prasad said at a new meet on Thursday that the CAA does not have anything new on grant of citizenship to non-Muslims persecuted in Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan government. It was done under Indira Gandhi and Rajiv Gandhi regimes decades ago which granted citizenship to Hindus from Uganda and Sri Lanka. “They did not give citizenship to Muslims from these countries,” he noted.

On NRC, he said, “There are provisions that the date for NRC shall be announced, there will be verification, hearing of objections and disposal of objections and appeal against that. Nothing has been decided at all including the date.” Speaking at the ‘Janjagran Abhiyan’ at Sellur in Madurai, Union minister of women and child development and textiles, Smriti Zubin Irani questioned the “double standards” of the DMK on the issue of citizenship for Sri Lankan refugees.

“This is not about the BJP, but about brotherhood and the nation,” she said. When the Nov 2007 special commission for rehabilitation did not entertain citizenship for Sri Lankan refugees under the UPA government why did you remain silent?’’ she asked. This was because the UPA government gave them a free run to loot the treasury of the nation, said Irani. Addressing a meeting organized by the BJP at Trichy, party national general secretary Ram Madhav said, “Some leaders in Tamil Nadu are opposing the Act. If we ask them the reason for their opposition, they do not have answers. Those who opposing the Act really do not know anything about it”, he said. “I appeal to the Muslim brothers not to fall prey to the false propaganda of opposition parties. This bill is not against Muslims or Christians”, he added. Party national executive committee member L Ganesan, actor Gautami and general secretary M Muruganantham also participated.

Title: Chorus rises for removal of police barricades from NH-16
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Visakhapatnam: At a time when the city police is placing barricades on the national highway to slow down traffic and reduce accidents, members of the AP Chambers of Commerce have sent a proposal to the Union government to remove all barricades from the NH.

On Thursday, during an interactive session with TG Venkatesh, chairman of parliamentary standing committee on transport, the trade body gave a nine-fold proposal to ease traffic on the busy and accident-prone NH-16 stretch that passes through the city. One of the proposals was to ask the local police and state government to remove barricades from that highway stretch.

“Because of the barricades, bottlenecks are created on the stretch that reduces the traffic speed considerably. Such things should not happen on a national highway,” Sudhir Mulagada, chairman of Visakhapatnam zone of the trade body, told TOI.

MY Danam, regional manager of Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation (APSRTC), too had made a similar request to the police during a recent meeting of the Visakhapatnam road safety committee. But the traffic department made it clear that they won’t remove the barricades from the accident-prone stretch.

The traffic cops have claimed that after the placement of 66 barricades on the stretch, there was a considerable fall in the number of accidents. A senior traffic department official said while 118 accidents were reported on that highway stretch in July 2019, the number came down to 91 in September after the barricades were placed. The number of injuries also reduced to 48 in September from 68 in July, he added.

Though Mulagada did not dismiss the cops’ claims, he said they need to sit down with the cops to find a middle path. “We have to sit down with the police to understand their logic behind putting these barricades. Bottlenecks and slow traffic on the highway is not a good option,” he added.

Another important proposal suggested by the members is removal of toll gates from the city limits to facilitate faster traffic movement. The other suggestions include construction of dedicated parking areas near petrol pumps for trucks, food plazas, washrooms, vehicle repair and servicing centres, and construction of 60-feet-wide service roads on both sides of the highway stretch passing through the city limits. “Now that Visakhapatnam is proposed to become the executive capital, traffic too would increase considerably. But these proposals are the need of the hour and are essential even if the city does not become the capital,” Mulagada added.

Title: Odisha approves NTPC’s Talcher plant expansion, two other projects
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Bhubaneswar: The state government on Thursday cleared three investment proposals totalling Rs 17,833 crore, including a Rs 7,698.46-crore expansion of National Thermal Power Corporation (NTPC)’s plant in Talcher.

The NTPC expansion will involve the setting up of two new power units of 800 megawatt each at its existing facility in Talcher.

The two other projects approved by the high-level clearance authority chaired by chief minister Naveen Patnaik are a Rs 8,000-crore, two million tonne per annum (MTPA) alumina refinery by Hindalco in Rayagada district, and a Rs 2,135-crore expansion of Rungta Mines Limited (RML).

Industries minister Dibya Shankar Mishra said, “The three projects will create more than 6,500 jobs.”

The approval of the NTPC project is significant as the state government had in 2018 expressed strong reservations against it, citing the high tariff of the power that will be generated by the new plants. The Centre, however, had tried to push through the project so that Prime Minister Narendra Modi could have laid its foundation on September 22, 2018.

Before last year’s simultaneous Lok Sabha and assembly elections, petroleum minister Dharmendra Pradhan and the Union power minister R K Singh had both written to Naveen for help in clearing the project. As the election campaign intensified, then state energy minister, Susanta Singh, had opposed the project. He had said the power tariff of the proposed plants had been pegged at a high Rs 3.40 per unit.

A senior government officer said the expansion project approved on Thursday was a revised one, which addressed the concerns raised by the state. The power tariff of the revised plan is not known.

As per the earlier plan, NTPC had proposed to invest Rs 9,785 crore in two new units totalling 1,320 megawatts. The existing plant in Talcher — launched by former Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru in 1964 — has a capacity of 460 megawatt and will become outdated in 2021.

The Hindalco project in Kansariguda village, which is expected to start running within five years, would create 4,250 new jobs, sources said. The company already has 1,500 acres with it and will need to acquire 600 acres more for the alumina refinery. Running at full capacity, the refinery will need six million tonne of bauxite per year.

The RML plans to expand its integrated steel plant in Sundargarh district from 0.27MTPA to 0.9MTPA, creating 2,289 new jobs.

Title: Haridwar: Workers to hold hunger strike demanding hike in salary
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Bhojan matas from across the state also held a protest in Doon on Thursday

HARIDWAR: Irked over the state government’s apathy to their demands, scores of anganwadi workers, who have been holding protest for the last 35 days, decided on Thursday to sit on a hunger strike . The workers have been demanding job regularisation and salary hike at par with Delhi and Kerala.

“For the last 35 days, we have been demanding salary hike at par with Delhi and Kerala, where the anganwadi workers are paid more than Rs 10,000 per month. We have also been demanding regularisation of job, but the state government has not paid heed to our demands. Hence, we have decided to launch hunger strike to draw their attention to our plight,” said Rekha Negi, head of anganwadi karyakarti worker employee union. She said two of its workers would be sitting on a hunger strike on Friday.

Notably, on Tuesday after the cabinet meeting, minister of women and child development Rekha Arya had claimed that Uttarakhand is paying its anganwadi workers better than Uttar Pradesh and Himachal Pradesh.

Uttrakhand has four registered unions of anganwadi workers and under these different banners, all of them have similar demands. There are around 37, 000 anganwadi workers.

Earlier on Thursday in Haridwar , the general secretary of Uttrakhand anganwadi karmchari sangh, handed a memorandum, addressed to the PM, to the district administration. “When we are proving useful for the system then why are they not including us in the system as their regular part?” Sushila Khatri, president of the sangh said.

Title: Tamil Nadu assembly passes 15 bills
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Tamil Nadu CM Edappadi K Palaniswami

CHENNAI: The Tamil Nadu assembly on Thursday passed 15 bills, including reverting to indirect elections to heads of urban local bodies, mayors of corporations, chairpersons of municipalities and town panchayats.

While the Congress opposed the indirect polls alleging that the move would lead to horse-trading, the DMK said people were confused over the conduct of the polls itself. DMK MLA and former Greater Chennai Corporation mayor M Subramanian hit out at the government for its frequent flip flops on the polls ever since it took over.

Bills were passed to extend the term of special officers by another six months or until the first meeting of the elected local bodies, use of EVMs in the elections to rural local bodies, suspension of president or vice-president of a registered society under certain circumstances and doing away third grade municipalities in the state.

The House passed a bill to confer the government with the power of inspection and inquiry to monitor the use of government funds in TN Veterinary and Animal Sciences University and TN Dr J Jayalalithaa Fisheries University, and another bill to revise the qualification prescribed for the post of registrar of Dr Ambedkar Law University. A bill sought to repeal 150 laws as they had become obsolete and redundant.

Title: Agra records 33% decline in road accidents in 2018: NCRB
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

According to NCRB, Agra recorded 186 road accidents with equal number of casualty figures in 2018

AGRA: Just 15 weeks after Union ministry of road transport and highways (MoRTH) reported that Agra district witnessed 23.35% rise in road accidents in 2018 after two consecutive years of decline, on Thursday, National Crime Record Bureau (NCRB) stated that Agra city recorded a 33% decline in road accidents in the same year.

According to NCRB, Agra city recorded 186 road accidents with equal number of casualty figures in 2018, as against 278 accidents which killed same number of people in 2017. Further, it also reported, that 36,855 road accidents occurred in Uttar Pradesh killing 22,541 people in 2018. But the MoRTH report, titled ‘Road Accidents in India 2018’, stated that 42,568 road accidents were reported in the state in which 22,256 people lost their lives.

NCRB-2018 said 125 people were injured in road accidents Agra city, while MoRTH claimed that 999 were injured in 1,273 accidents in Agra district. The MoRTH report highlighted that Agra district continued the upward trend with 12.25% increase in road accident casualties and 11.49% rise in total number of injured victims in 2018. In 2018, Agra reported 623 fatalities as compared to 555 in 2017, while in 2016, a total of 522 people lost their lives and 474 in 2015 .

According to MoRTH data, a total of 1,032 road accidents occurred in Agra district in 2017 and 1,062 in 2016 while in 2015, 1,143 accidents took place. A similar trend was witnessed for injured victims as well, as Agra reported 896 in 2017 as compare to 811 in 2016. 2015 saw 650 injred accident victims.

Apart from Agra, cities like Allahabad, Lucknow and Kanpur also showed a huge gaps as compare to MoRTH district wise data of 2018 road accidents in 2018.

MoRTH claimed Allahabad district reported 614 causalities in 1,380 road accidents but NCRB said Allahabad city recorded 374 deaths in 878 accidents. Similarly, Lucknow district accounted for 580 deaths in 1,638 road accidents but Lucknow city recorded 452 in 872 road accidents. Meerut district lost 443 lives in 1,019 accidents but Meerut city witnessed 223 deaths in 543accidents. In Kanpur district, 698 people died in 1,588 accidents but Kanpur city lost 653 in 1,126 accidents. Varanasi district registered 261 deaths in 568 accidents but Varanasi city accounted for 98 deaths in 208 accidents.

Title: Economy stuck in low gear, pump makers stop storing
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Coimbatore: The practice of having additional stock in Coimbatore’s micro and small pump units is declining. Industrialists say around five years ago, small pump manufacturers would maintain extra stock of a few hundred pieces with a hope that they would be sold soon. But now, many of them have reduced the stock to 20% and some have stopped the practice, said industrialists.

The main reason micro and small industrialists cite for this is the economic slowdown which resulted in tightening of cash inflow.

President of Kovai Power Driven Pumps and Spares Manufacturers Association (KOPMA) K Maniraj said around five years ago micro pump units would stock around 100 pieces and medium ones would have around 500 pieces. “This was done in the hope that the orders for these would be there. But it has been decreasing gradually and now many units have decreased their stock to 20%,” he said.

The slowdown and the decrease in orders have created an apprehension among small industrialists to produce extra and maintain stock. “We have to purchase more than 70 spare parts to assemble a pump. This would cost us GST as well. But we are not sure if we could sell them. So, the trend now is to manufacture only when there is a guaranteed order,” Maniraj added. He also cited the decrease in demand for pumps from agriculture and construction sectors as reasons for this.

This trend, as expected, has also hit micro and small spare part manufacturers and job work units in the value chain. With orders for manufacturers shrinking and their practice of hoarding stock declining, the constant orders for spares and job work is also coming down.

Stock was a routine industrial process even in micro and small spare parts units, said J James, president of Tamil Nadu Association of Cottage and Micro Enterprises (TACT). “But now as the orders have come down, small job work units also cannot have stock,” he said.

With big companies manufacturing only if they get guaranteed orders, they give job work or spare parts orders only then, he said. “If micro units can’t deliver these sudden orders, big firms split it among several micro units and get the job done. So, micro and small firms having stock is unthinkable today,” he said.

Title: BJP ministers, leader in firefighting mode, hold pro-CAA rallies in Tamil Nadu
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Union minister Smriti Irani addresses a pro-CAA rally in Madurai on Thursday

CHENNAI/MADURAI: Under fire from the opposition parties and allies over the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) and National Register of Citizens ( NRC ), the Narendra Modi government has gone into firefighting mode deploying ministers Ravi Shankar Prasad and Smriti Irani as well as BJP general secretary Ram Madhav to clear the air over the issues in the state.

“We will hold talks with our allies and take them into confidence,” said Union law minister Ravi Shankar Prasad in Chennai while responding to a question on chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami’s statement in the assembly that he had told home minister Amit Shah that NRC was not acceptable to the AIADMK government.

Prasad said at a new meet on Thursday that the CAA does not have anything new on grant of citizenship to non-Muslims persecuted in Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan government. It was done under Indira Gandhi and Rajiv Gandhi regimes decades ago which granted citizenship to Hindus from Uganda and Sri Lanka. “They did not give citizenship to Muslims from these countries,” he noted.

On NRC, he said, “There are provisions that the date for NRC shall be announced, there will be verification, hearing of objections and disposal of objections and appeal against that. Nothing has been decided at all including the date.” Speaking at the ‘Janjagran Abhiyan’ at Sellur in Madurai, Union minister of women and child development and textiles, Smriti Zubin Irani questioned the “double standards” of the DMK on the issue of citizenship for Sri Lankan refugees.

“This is not about the BJP, but about brotherhood and the nation,” she said. When the Nov 2007 special commission for rehabilitation did not entertain citizenship for Sri Lankan refugees under the UPA government why did you remain silent?’’ she asked. This was because the UPA government gave them a free run to loot the treasury of the nation, said Irani. Addressing a meeting organized by the BJP at Trichy, party national general secretary Ram Madhav said, “Some leaders in Tamil Nadu are opposing the Act. If we ask them the reason for their opposition, they do not have answers. Those who opposing the Act really do not know anything about it”, he said. “I appeal to the Muslim brothers not to fall prey to the false propaganda of opposition parties. This bill is not against Muslims or Christians”, he added. Party national executive committee member L Ganesan, actor Gautami and general secretary M Muruganantham also participated.

Title: Can tweak CAA if citizens hit: G Kishan Reddy
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

G Kishan Reddy

HYDERABAD: Union minister of state for home affairs G Kishan Reddy on Thursday said the Centre is ready to make changes in the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) if it impacts even a single citizen of this country. Allaying the fears of Muslims on CAA , Kishan Reddy said not even a single Muslim individual would be sent away from the country. “PM (Narendra) Modi is with every citizen of this country,” he said at a ‘meet the press’ programme here.

Stating they did not anticipate widespread protests across the country, he blamed the opposition parties for running a vicious campaign on NPR . “I do not know why students, intellectuals and others are coming on to the streets and protesting against it. There is nothing to fear. There is no need to submit any document in NPR. It is a usual process which is taken up along with Census,” he said. Responding to a query, Kishan Reddy said no decision had been taken on NRC. “The issue has not been discussed by the Union cabinet yet. What home minister Amit Shah has spoken about is our party line. When a discussion happens in the government, we will let people know. No citizen will be impacted because of this,” he said.

Title: Cyient lays off around 100 techies
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Hyderabad: City-based engineering and technology solutions provider Cyient Limited has handed over pink slips to around 100 employees in multiple locations over the past few days, according to sources.

Most of the layoffs are learnt to have happened in Cyient’s geographic information systems (GIS) department offices at Hyderabad and Noida over last week. The retrenched employees were mid-career techies with work experience of up to 11-12 years in the industry, said sources.

According to sources, the company has been in the process of cutting flab over the past couple of months in the GIS vertical, where the attrition rate has traditionally been very high.

While Cyient refused to state the exact number of people it has laid off, it indicated that the employees were asked to leave because of poor performance.

“Changes are made to every business unit to ensure there is efficiency towards supporting a customer operation. The policy is strictly followed in performance cases as well as those where individuals may have to adapt to newer technologies. In addition, there is training for associates who choose to take on newer certifications. In the event of operational restructuring, the company has a well-established policy to offer redeployment to each individual, which may also include the opportunity to learn new technologies,” said a Cyient spokesperson without elaborating further.

In its investor presentation during the announcement of its Q2FY20 financial results, the homegrown IT major said its total headcount had decreased to 14,869 in the quarter ended September 30, 2019, from 15,043 during the quarter ended June 30, 2019. According to the company, during the October-December 2019 period it hired over 400 new associates.

This week, Cyient also opened its development centre at Warangal where it has plans to hire around 800 people, primarily local youth. This centre will support telecom customers globally with plan and design and engineering services for their mobile and fixed-line networks.

Title: ‘Banks may lose up to Rs 1,800cr on zero MDR’
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Mayur.Shetty@timesgroup.com

Mumbai: The annual revenue loss caused by zero merchant fees on RuPay cards and UPI is expected to be Rs 1,800 crore going by the present level of transactions. Given that banks can choose between either suffering this loss or pushing Visa and Mastercard transactions, there are suggestions that the RBI should bear this cost.

The government last month did away with merchant discount rate ( MDR ) — the fees that businesses pay banks for transferring money from the cardholders’ accounts to their own. While mandating small businesses to accept digital payments, the finance minister had said “the RBI and banks will absorb these costs from the savings that will accrue to them on account of handling less cash as people move to these digital modes of payment”.

According to a report (discriminatory approach for RuPay debit cards — a corrective approach) by IIT-Bombay professor Ashish Das, this results in induced discrimination between RuPay, on the one hand, and Mastercard & Visa on the other.

The revenue differential for banks between RuPay and Mastercard/Visa, would prompt them to promote that card scheme which generates more revenue for them, the report said. “Therefore, the RBI would need to set a revised cap on debit card MDR, on lines currently set for RuPay debit card by NPCI. Alternatively, if the RBI feels appropriate, it can increase the revenue support for RuPay debit card, in order to maintain parity with extant MDR caps set by the RBI,” Das said. According to the report, the revenue for RuPay debit card is expected to be no more than Rs 1,000 crore for calendar year 2020, while for BHIM-UPI, it is expected to be another Rs 800 crore.

As of December 2019, for BHIM-UPI, NPCI had an MDR cap of 0.3%, subject to a maximum of Rs 100. Additionally, to promote on-boarding of small and medium merchants with less than Rs 1 lakh worth of BHIM-UPI transactions in a month, there are no fees imposed. Also, for merchants other than online ones, there are no transaction fees when the ticket size is within Rs 100. “The MDR pricing structure for BHIM-UPI introduced by NPCI in October 2019 appears quite reasonable as it attempts to encourage small and medium merchants to get on-boarded and be active in acceptance of digital payments. In an attempt to encourage payment service providers, the RBI should provide for the necessary support for the banks’ revenue loss towards BHIM-UPI also,” said Das.

Title: ‘Odisha has producers but not visionaries’
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Jitendra Mishra with Vikas Khanna

The Neena Gupta-starrer ‘ The Last Colour ’, produced by Titilagarh native Jitendra Mishra , is among films that are in the running for a nomination in the ‘ best picture ’ category at the 92nd Academy Awards . The Delhi-based Mishra, who has emerged as a pioneering ‘alternative producer’ with films like ‘I am Kalam’ on his CV, talks to Amava Bhattacharya over phone about the Oscar nomination list to be announced on Monday, the future of Odia films and working the festival circuit

Did you expect ‘The Last Colour’ to be on the Oscar contention list?

When we made the film, Vikas (Khanna, New York-based Michelin-starred chef and director of ‘The Last Colour’) told me that we should try to ensure that it makes it to the Oscars eligibility list. Otherwise, he said, we would not have done justice to the product. As far as the announcement of the Oscar nomination list on Monday is concerned, we are not in any rat race. The journey matters more than the destination and we are happy to have made it to the contention list.

‘The Last Colour’ deals with the subject of widows of Varanasi and Vrindavan. What was shooting in Varanasi like?

We had a wonderful time there. People were warm and friendly. If you are a good human being, you can really connect to some wonderful people there. It is such a holy place and the people were very hospitable towards us.

The film was screened at the UN headquarters in New York last year. Its first look was revealed at Cannes. Will it get a theatre release in India?

Of course it will. We have travelled with the film across festivals but the ultimate aim is to release it in India. We are waiting to see what happens on Monday before deciding when and how we will take ‘The Last Colour’ forward here. While I can’t ensure that it will get a theatre release in Titilagarh, I do want to release it in Bhubaneswar where I know it will be appreciated.

Regional cinema, especially Malayalam films, are doing so well. What do you think ails the Odia film industry?

I would disagree with the fact that the Odia film industry is ailing. I know of some great filmmakers in Odisha who are doing some really good films. But the problem here is that these films are not being marketed well. I have only one piece of advice for producers in Odisha. If your budget is Rs 1 crore, stretch it to Rs 1.5 crore to include marketing costs. How will people know about a film, especially if the budget is limited and it does not have big stars, if it is not marketed well? In Odisha, we have producers but not visionaries.

Your production model is often described as ‘alternate production’. What does that mean?

I would call myself a technical producer. I am not a money man. Usually we think of producers as pouring money into a film and then taking a step back. I am invested in the technical aspects of production, from sales to marketing to distribution. I believe in supporting a film and taking it to its logical end. I believe every film should be given the best chance it can have of shining. I am very passionate about films.

Have you ever wanted to direct films?

I made some shorts and documentaries but there is the matter of earning a livelihood. I have chosen to focus on the production aspect as of now.

Does your method of production lead to conflicts with the director?

Not at all. I think of a producer as the father of a film and of the director as its mother. Our family didn’t have a lot of money but I saw my mother managing the best she could with the resources my father would provide her with. I think of films like that. The director’s vision is final.

What do you think of films being released on OTT platforms like Netflix?

I do feel that youngsters today are missing out on the magic of watching a film in the hall, but films are doing well on such OTT platforms and I have no problems with them as such. In my personal capacity, I organise a film festival in New Delhi (Siffcy) for youngsters to get an experience of watching films on the big screen.

Do you think film festivals can help small budget films get exposure?

Yes, definitely. I have been going to Cannes for the past eight years and have visited other international and national festivals as well. In them, you meet like-minded people, get honest feedback on your film, and can even strike deals with other producers and broadcasters there. Quantity does not matter to me, quality does; the same holds true for film festivals. One should try to take the films to the credible festivals. Look at ‘Village Rockstars’, for instance. It’s a small Assamese film, but it created a sense of anticipation among the urban audience after doing the rounds of festivals.

EoM

Title: Ashkelon, Vadodara sign twin city pact
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

The declaration was signed in the Israel city on Wednesday

Vadodara: A twin city declaration was eventually signed between Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) and the municipality of Ashkelon , a city in Israel on Wednesday. The civic bodies had been working towards the declaration for six years now.

The declaration signed by Vadodara mayor Dr Jigeesha Sheth and Ashkelon mayor Tomer Glam aims at developing and deepening the cultural, social, economic and tourism ties between the two cities. The idea of reaching an agreement has been under discussion since 2014.

The idea of the twin city agreement was first floated by city-based organisation, Friends of Israel, and its convenor Nikitin Contractor. In 2014, the then Vadodara mayor Bharat Shah had even visited Ashkelon. The biblically historic town has a population of around 1.5 lakh and an industrial base including one of the largest desalination plants in the world.

In 2015, a delegation from Ashkelon municipality and other representatives from Israel had visited the city. But little was heard of the twin city pact after this visit.

It was only in October last year that things started moving again. Former deputy mayor of Ashkelon Dr Ricky Shay and other representatives met VMC top brass to carry things forward. Sheth and VMC commissioner Nalin Upadhyay are on a tour to Israel since last week. The pact was signed during their visit to Ashkelon.

The areas that are being explored for cooperation have been termed as ‘The Five E’s’. These include education, environment, emergency management, empowering women and exchange of cultural programmes. The delegation from VMC also got an insight into the smart initiatives taken by various cities in Israel including Ashkelon.

Title: Check for encroachments, save 33 lakes in Ameenpur: NGT to Telangana
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Ameenpur Lake (File photo)

HYDERABAD: The National Green Tribunal (Southern Region) on Thursday asked the Telangana government to probe encroachments in 33 lakes in Ameenpur , a rich biodiversity site in the state.

Coming to the rescue of city lakes, the NGT bench at Chennai asked chief secretary Somesh Kumar to constitute a body of experts to find out encroachments and also fix the Full Tank Levels.

The order comes in the wake of complaints lodged by Human Rights and Consumer Protection Cell Trust and others, alleging that builders and realtors have encroached around 13 water bodies in Ameenpur and 20 water bodies in the catchment area. They have alleged that large-scale encroachments have reduced the lakes’ width and, in some cases, its been filled up illegally.

Hyderabad Metropolitan Development Authority (HMDA), Hyderabad, in its counter-affidavit mentioned that a joint committee was formed to inspect the lakes which has identified encroachments and now action was being taken.

“In some of the water bodies there are encroachments and request has been made for fixing the FTL. Further action will be taken,” the HMDA said in its petition.

Private parties who were accused of trespass by the Trust contended that it was was a private dispute and members of the Trust also had properties adjacent to the respondents. They also alleged that there was no water body in the properties and construction was done in accordance with the law.

NGT Southern Zone Chennai bench comprising Justice K Ramakrishnan and expert member Saibal Dasgupta in its order asked Somesh Kumar to look into the matter and ascertain whether the water bodies in the state, especially those in Ameenpur, were notified, FTL fixed and encroachments identified and action taken. NGT also asked the committee to check any buffer zone of the water body, which can be declared as non-development zone.

“Whether all the water bodies were inventoried and notified under the Wetlands (Conservation and Management) Rules, 2017, shall be looked into by the committee. What are the encroachments and action taken to remove them and steps taken to prevent further encroachments? The committee should also look into any dumping of garbage and discharge of non-treated sewage or effluents into water bodies and action taken,” said the order.

The committee should consist of officials of the Lake Protection Committee, district collectors, Telangana State Pollution Control Board, the State Wetlands (Conservation and Management) Authority, officials of the Telangana Bio-Diversity Board and heads of local bodies, the NGT said.

Title: Shift bus shelters closer to metro station entry points, CMRL tells corporation
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

At least eight metro stations including Ekkatuthangal (in picture) have been identified for shifting existing ... Read More

CHENNAI: Boarding an MTC bus to your destination after travelling the entire metro rail network stretch could soon become easy. Chennai Metro Rail Limited ( CMRL ) has asked city corporation to shift existing bus shelters closer to the entrances of at least eight metro stations including at the airport and proposed new bus stops in at least five stations including Guindy metro. This is to make first mile or last mile connectivity easier for metro rail commuters.

“We have written and discussed about shifting existing bus stops closer to our stations with city corporation officials. We hope to get it done soon,” a CMRL official said.

Metro rail officials said at least eight metro station locations have been proposed for shifting existing bus shelters closer to the entry points of the stations. It includes Thousand Lights, Airport, Pachaiyappa’s College, Government Estate, LIC, Teynampet and Ekattuthangal. At Government Estate metro, CMRL has asked for stopping of MTC buses plying on certain routes closer to the station, and said the existing bus shelter at the airport could be shifted closer to the pedestrian subway linking the suburban services with metro.

Officials said there is also a proposal to set up new bus shelters closer to metro stations at Guindy, Meenambakkam, Nanganallur, Vadapalani and Ekkattuthangal. At Guindy metro, which is already closer to the suburban station from where share auto services ply to Porur, a new shelter has been proposed for mofussil buses.

Both the corridors and the 32 stations along the 45km phase-1 were planned closer to bus shelters and link major transport hubs like CMBT, Central railway station, Egmore railway station and the airport.

At present, bus shelters are a stone’s throw for metro rail commuters at Saidapet, AG-DMS, Central metro and Alandur stations. The buses that stop at these stations ply to far-flung areas in the north and the south.

A senior corporation confirmed the CMRL request. “For shifting a bus shelter, a deposit of Rs 60,000-Rs 80,000 has to be given. We have already sent a letter to CMRL on this. Once the money is deposited, the work will start,” he said.

Title: All families along Cooum, Adyar will be shifted: CM O Pannerselvam
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

O Pannerselvam

CHENNAI: The government will shift all households along the Cooum and the Adyar rivers in the city to Perumbakkam and Okkiyam Thoraipakkam, said deputy chief minister and state housing minister O Pannerselvam on Thursday. Replying to a question raised by Harbour MLA P K Sekar Babu in the assembly, Panneerselvam said several households in Satyavanimuthu Nagar and other areas along the rivers have shifted to Perumbakkam.

“There were more than 11,500 families settled along the Cooum in the city. Of this, 10,740 families are to be shifted to Perumbakkam, Okkiyam Thoraipakkam and other areas. During the 2015 floods, 9,000 families on the banks of the Adyar were affected and of this, 4,000 families have been shifted to Perumbakkam,” said Panneerselvam.

In December last year, eviction of families began at Satyavanimuthu Nagar as part of the Cooum River Restoration project taken up by the Chennai Rivers’ Restoration Trust. There were protests from various parties and VCK chief Thol Thirumavalavan visited the area and spoke to Panneerselvam about the eviction.

“More than 2,000 families from Satyavanimuthu Nagar agreed to shift to Perumbakkam and many of them have settled in their new apartments. There are a few more who have asked time due to their children’s exams. Therefore, we have given them time till April,” said Panneerselvam.

Though Sekar Babu said many people who have shifted to Perumbakkam don’t have proper facilities, the deputy CM differed from what the MLA said.

“The people who have settled in Perumbakkam and Okkiyam Thoraipakkam have all facilities. There are schools, colleges, hospitals, parks, playgrounds, primary health centres and Aavin parlours,” said Panneerselvam.

He said the families are to get Rs 2,000 per month for 12 months and also Rs 5,000 when they shift to the new place. “For school children, free buses are provided from the area to the place where schools are situated,” said Panneerselvam.

Title: Coming to Agra? Enjoy brewing some fresh beer
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

AGRA: The city of Taj has more to cheer now, literally. With the decks cleared and infrastructure ready, the first microbrewery in the state is all set to open at MG Road here on Saturday.

Entrepreneurs Sushil Bhati and his nephew Kunal Bhati, the brains behind UP’s first microbrewery pub ‘Folks’, said that the initiative is aimed at overhauling the experience of drinking beer for local residents and lakhs of tourists who visit the city.

Sushil said, “A craft brewery or microbrewery produces beer in much smaller quantities as compared to a commercial unit. Fresh from the tap, craft beer focuses on the quality of the brew and preferences of the individual customer.”

Kunal said, “Craft brewing makes the experience of drinking beer a rich one. It is fresh, tastier and healthier. Bottled beer is no match to the freshly brewed one as the former has added preservatives. Craft beer also gives more individual freedom to the customer as he/she can choose the preferred variety. Initially, we are planning to offer three varieties — Belgian Wit, India Pale Ale and Munich Helles — at economical prices.” “We will import the malt and hops from Europe and USA to ensure quality. Also, a variety of minerals will be added to the water to give the beer an authentic taste,” he added.

Sushil said, “When the UP government amended its excise rules last year, we decided to tap the growth potential of Agra , which is also a popular tourist destination. That’s why we decided to open our first microbrewery in the state in the Taj city.” He added that he has obtained the licence to produce 66 litres of craft beer daily.

The UP Brewery Rules 2019, announced in June last year, mandates an annual licence fee of Rs 2.5 lakh for microbreweries, up from Rs 25,000 fixed in 1974. A guarantee fee of Rs 1 lakh has also been fixed. According to the rules, a microbrewery can produce only 600 litres of craft beer a day. Similarly, an annual production limit of 2.1 lakh litres has also been fixed for microbreweries.

Kunal quotes a US-based home brewing consultant Jake Baker, “Anyone can make craft beer with just a basic understanding.” “It is just a heady mixture of science and arts,” he adds.

Title: Cybercrime against women: Odisha moves up 6 places
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

BHUBANESWAR: Women in the state have increasingly become vulnerable to crimes in the cyberspace, if the latest report of the National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB) is any indication. The NCRB’s crime in India 2018 report, released on Wednesday, placed Odisha only after Assam for the maximum number of cyber offences against women.

Assam topped the list with a registration of 295 cases, involving women as victims of cybercrimes, in 2018. It was followed by Odisha with 208 cases in the same year, the NCRB data showed.

Odisha has moved up six places from its rank in 2017 when it had recorded 23 cases of cybercrimes against women .

The NCRB said most of the cybercrime cases in the state in 2018 were related to sexual harassment of women on social media. “Of the 208 cases of cybercrimes against women in Odisha, at least 172 were publication or transmission of sexually explicit materials on websites. The remaining 36 cases fell under other forms of cybercrime (extortion/blackmailing, morphing, defamation and creation of fake profile),” the NCRB report said.

Cybercrime experts blame lack of awareness and lack of necessary precautions by the victims for the alarming rise of such crimes against women in the state. “Though it is difficult to pinpoint the exact reason for the spurt in cybercrimes against women, lack of adoption of safety precautions on cyberspace could be a strong factor behind falling prey to cyber crooks. Social media users, especially women, should be extremely careful and extra cautious while befriending strangers on chatting sites,” IT expert Pramod Satpathy said.

The NCRB data said Odisha did not report any case of circulation of fake news on social media in 2018. The matter assumes significance amid Odisha occupying the fourth spot with the registration of 13 such cases in 2017, the NCRB report said.

Significantly, the state government on Monday launched cyber safety and security awareness week where chief secretary Asit Tripathy urged internet and social media users to remain aware and take adequate safety precautions to keep cyber offenders at bay.

Title: Goa: Two villagers admit to burying two tigers, but not killing them
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

KERI: After four tigers, including two cubs, were found dead within a span of four days, forest officials have failed to crack the case. While officials said that two villagers confessed to burying two of the cubs inside the Mhadei wildlife sanctuary in Sattari , they said the suspects didn’t disclose how the four tigers were killed.

Meanwhile, the two-member committee formed by the Centre to probe the deaths is set to arrive in Goa on Friday.

The tigers had reportedly killed a cow and buffalo belonging to Vitho Pavane and Malo Pavane respectively, which led forest officials to claim that the tiger deaths were “revenge killings”. Accordingly, the two were taken into custody. A third suspect, who was also rounded up, didn’t yield during investigations.

“After confessing to burying the tigers, both accused were taken to the spot where two of the cubs had been buried by them. However, they did not tell us how the four tigers died. Today, the postmortem of the fourth carcass that was found on Wednesday was done. Investigation is in progress,” said deputy conservator of forests Vikas Desai.

Forest officials maintain that the tigers were killed after consuming poisoned buffalo meat. But they have no concrete evidence to support this theory so far.

Wildlife conservationists said delayed action by forest officials in providing compensation are usually known to lead to such actions by forest dwellers affected by tigers preying on their cattle. For the two Pavane families, the killed cattle were a crucial source of livelihood.

On Thursday, veterinary doctors Harsh Bathini and Loveleen Vaz conducted a postmortem of the fourth sub-adult female tigress in the presence of inquiry officer Nandkumar Parab. The postmortem found in the abdominal cavity of the tigress the partially digested parts of a porcupine with quills. Remnants of two dead porcupines had earlier been found in the cashew plantation in the neighbouring village of Rive, a few meters away from the killed buffalo.

Out of the four tiger carcasses, only the fourth tigress’ abdominal cavity showed remains of the porcupines.

Title: Aligarh police booked AMU students inappropriate sloganeering
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Aligarh Muslim University

AGRA: Aligarh police has booked 25-30 unidentified students of Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) on Thursday after they allegedly shouted inappropriate slogans against the PM and CM while forming a human chain to express their solidarity with JNU students and teachers who were attacked by masked men on their campus on Sunday.

Confirming it, station house officer of Civil Lines police station, Amit Kumar, said an FIR has been registered against 25-30 unidentified students of AMU under IPC section 153 A (promoting enmity between different groups on ground of religion). He said the case was registered after the video of students shouting slogans was widely circulated on social media. He said the matter is being investigated in detail.

Title: Focus on ease of doing biz neglects environmental issues, say experts
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Hyderabad: Several environmentalists from the city on Thursday conducted a meet to discuss environmental issues due to the pollution created by pharma companies in the city and other parts of the state. “Due to ease of doing business, businessmen have hardly considered environmental issues and the government has given an easy pass to companies.

“Issues of granting of license and environment have not been taken into consideration,” said Damodar Reddy, an environmentalist from the city and added that Telangana State Industrial Project and Self-Certification System (TS-iPASS) facilitates speedy processing of applications to issue clearances required for setting up of industries.

“There are institutional mechanisms that come from three main laws that deal with pollution -The Water (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act of 1974, Air (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act of 1981 and the Environment Protection Act of 1986, but these laws have been diluted by the government under the guise of TS-iPASS and ease of doing business. If one big pharma firm can causes so much pollution, one can only imagine what a 100 industries in pharma city can do,” said environmentalist Prof. K. Purushotham Reddy.

According to Central Pollution Control Board, Telangana has 59 such highly polluting industries of which 45 are in the surrounding areas of Hyderabad. Experts said that Hyderabad, being a major hub of bulk drug production and pharma firms, provides thousands of jobs in Telangana. However, they alleged that these industries are not recruiting more than 0.5% of the total local employees. “As per the Comprehensive Environmental Pollution Index (CEPI), due to the pharma industries, the problem of water pollution has worsened in last eight years,” said Dr Narasimha Reddy, an independent policy expert and environmentalist.

Title: City lab to facilitate export of paddy, cotton, veg seeds to EU
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Coimbatore: The seed testing laboratory in the city is all set to act as a facilitator to export seeds to the European Union (EU).

Representatives from the EU had visited the facility under the directorate of seed certification recently to review the standard operating procedures and lab equipment. An official, who didn’t want to be named said the EU was looking to sign a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with the Centre to import seeds from India. As part of it, experts from the EU had visited Haryana, Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu, the official said.

The MoU, she said, would be signed under the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), an intergovernmental economic organization that works to build better policies for better lives.

In Tamil Nadu, they had visited the seed testing laboratory in the city last month. “The lab is the only public institution that has world-class equipment for seed testing in the region,” the official said. Three experts from Ireland and Slovenia visited the lab and they were accompanied by as many counterparts from the central Indian institutions, she said.

“They are looking to import paddy, cotton and vegetable seeds from here. If the MoU is finalized, our farmers would produce the seeds. The department of seed certification would oversee the field standards, while the seed testing lab would take care of seed standards. Both wings would work together,” she said.

The experts mainly looked for compliance to standard operating procedure and quality of the systems at the lab. “The lab has imported equipment of high caliber. Right from weighing to seed imaging to testing the moisture and germination of seeds, the lab has all equipment,” the official said.

The lab has equipment such as analytical balances, seed blower, seed imager to study seeds of size less than 1mm, digital moisture meter and cabinet germinator, the official said.

She said the EU experts were taken to fields to show them the farming practices of the region. “They seemed impressed by our facility. We expect a positive feedback from them.”

Title: Elusive subway: People crawl under trains, jump tracks
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

A passenger walks under a parked goods train at Rajanukunte railway station

Title: Suicides by farmers lowest in 3 years
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

NEW DELHI: Suicide by farmers and agricultural labourers registered a modest decline in 2018 and was lowest in the past three years. According to the National Crime Records Bureau , 10,349 people in the farming sector - 5,763 farmers/ cultivators and 4,586 agricultural labourers -committed suicide during 2018 as compared to 10,655 people during the previous year.

In 2016, the number was significantly higher at 11,379. Like in 2017, the home ministry did not specify the reason of farmers and agriculture labourers committing suicide.

The report said many states and Union Territories have reported "nil" data on suicides by farmers , cultivators and farm labourers. These include West Bengal, Bihar, Uttarakhand, Meghalaya, Goa, Chandigarh, Daman and Diu, Delhi, Lakshadweep and Puducherry.

According to the report, out of 5,763 farmer/cultivator suicides, 5,457 were male and 306 were female during 2018. Similarly, out of 4,586 suicides committed by agricultural labourers during 2018, 4,071 were male and 515 were females.

Title: Chorus rises for removal of police barricades from NH-16
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Visakhapatnam: At a time when the city police is placing barricades on the national highway to slow down traffic and reduce accidents, members of the AP Chambers of Commerce have sent a proposal to the Union government to remove all barricades from the NH .

On Thursday, during an interactive session with TG Venkatesh, chairman of parliamentary standing committee on transport, the trade body gave a nine-fold proposal to ease traffic on the busy and accident-prone NH-16 stretch that passes through the city. One of the proposals was to ask the local police and state government to remove barricades from that highway stretch.

“Because of the barricades, bottlenecks are created on the stretch that reduces the traffic speed considerably. Such things should not happen on a national highway,” Sudhir Mulagada, chairman of Visakhapatnam zone of the trade body, told TOI.

MY Danam, regional manager of Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation (APSRTC), too had made a similar request to the police during a recent meeting of the Visakhapatnam road safety committee. But the traffic department made it clear that they won’t remove the barricades from the accident-prone stretch.

The traffic cops have claimed that after the placement of 66 barricades on the stretch, there was a considerable fall in the number of accidents. A senior traffic department official said while 118 accidents were reported on that highway stretch in July 2019, the number came down to 91 in September after the barricades were placed. The number of injuries also reduced to 48 in September from 68 in July, he added.

Though Mulagada did not dismiss the cops’ claims, he said they need to sit down with the cops to find a middle path. “We have to sit down with the police to understand their logic behind putting these barricades. Bottlenecks and slow traffic on the highway is not a good option,” he added.

Another important proposal suggested by the members is removal of toll gates from the city limits to facilitate faster traffic movement. The other suggestions include construction of dedicated parking areas near petrol pumps for trucks, food plazas, washrooms, vehicle repair and servicing centres, and construction of 60-feet-wide service roads on both sides of the highway stretch passing through the city limits. “Now that Visakhapatnam is proposed to become the executive capital, traffic too would increase considerably. But these proposals are the need of the hour and are essential even if the city does not become the capital,” Mulagada added.

Title: Cops yet to crack temple theft attempt case
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Tirupur: More than a month has lapsed since an unidentified man attempted to steal money from the hundials of Thirumuruganatha Swami Temple here, but police are yet to crack the case .

It was on the night of November 29, 2019, that the masked man entered the temple premises by drilling a hole on the giant compound wall and attempted to break open hundials using a crowbar and other tools. He hadn’t, however, succeeded in the attempt.

Subsequently, the Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments (HR&CE) department, which looks after the daily affairs of the temple that’s controlled by the Archaeological Survey of India (Asi), had a lodged a complaint with the Thirumuruganpoondi police. The HR&CE department HAD also handed over CCTV footages to police, who registered a case and launched a probe.

However, police haven’t made any progress in the case so far. “Identifying the accused is not easy as he had masked his face. We are probing the role of any habitual offenders in the theft attempt,” a police officer said.

Meanwhile, the HR&CE department has been beefing up security in the temple, which is already equipped with 16 CCTV cameras and an anti-burglary alarm. The temple authorities have ensured proper lighting on its premises and appointed one more night watchman based on the directions of police.

“We would soon install another 16 CCTV cameras. We have also written to ASI to replace the compound wall, which is weak in some points,” said an HR&CE official.

Title: A year after prasadam tragedy, Kollegal temple set to reopen?
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Mysuru: A year after the prasadam tragedy , moves are afoot to reopen the Kichguth Maaramma temple in Sulwadi village in Kollegal . State officials have visited the temple and reviewed the conditions and will submit a report for reopening soon, the tahsildar said.

On December 14, 2018, poisoned prasadam killed 17 devotees while more than 117 were taken ill. A seer had confessed to engineering the tragedy to wrest control of the temple trust. Following the deaths, the state endowment department took over the temple and it has been shut since. Locals are demanding that the temple be reopened at the earliest as it has caused anguish among devotees.

Kollegal tahsildar K Kunal said the agamikas of the state endowment department had visited the temple and reviewed the situation recently. “They will submit a report to the endowment department. Based on this, the temple-opening modalities will be taken up on the directions of the department and the Chamarajanagar DC,” he said.

Locals said the delegation from the state endowment department held discussions with them and assured that they would submit a report to the department soon.
