However, some locals felt those who suffered in the tragedy should be part of the process. Balan, a grama panchayat member, said, “Those who suffered want relief before the temple doors are reopened. Authorities come and go but our opinion is not taken. Some people want the temple to reopen but others want status quo to prevail.”

Pattada Guruswamy of Saluru mutt, which controlled the temple before the tragedy, said he was not aware of moves for reopening.

Title: Sait summoned to identify assailant
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Mysuru: Under treatment for serious injuries sustained in an attack , MLA Tanveer Sait on Thursday appeared before the executive magistrate for identification of the suspect at Mysuru Central Prison .

The additional tahsildar had summoned Sait and 10 others for inquiry in connection with the attack on him during a wedding reception at Bannimantap Grounds on November 17. Passers-by had immediately caught the accused Farhan and handed over to police.

Speaking to reporters outside the prison, Tanveer said doctors have given him a new life. The Narasimharaja MLA is now undergoing therapies. “I had gone out of the country for some time for rest. Due to injuries my voice has become soft and it would take another three months to return to normal,” he said.

Hundreds of his supporters had gathered at the prison. Sait got emotional after being hugged by a few supporters.

Title: Mathura court sentences man to life imprisonment in decade-old case
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

MATHURA: A Mathura court has sentenced a man to life imprisonment for kidnapping and killing a minor boy in the district a decade ago.

The convict Omveer and his accomplice, also a minor, kidnapped the 14-year-old boy when he was playing outside his home in Barauth village in February 2010 to settle an old rivalry. They subsequently killed the boy and hid his corpse in a mustard field, 3 kms from the village, according to the prosecution.

After the two were arrested for kidnapping, murder and causing disappearance of evidence, they disclosed the crime and the body was recovered.

Omveer's minor accomplice was sentenced for three years imprisonment by a juvenile court.

Since the statements of a majority of witnesses corroborated the police investigation, Additional District Judge VI Sanjai Kumar Yadav on Wednesday awarded life imprisonment to Omveer and also imposed a fine of Rs 20,000, said Assistant District Government Council Udham Singh Chaudhary.

If Omveer fails to pay the fine, he would have to spend another year in prison, the judge ruled, adding that both the sentences would run concurrently.

Title: Odisha: State, NCRB differ on number of rape cases registered in 2018
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Image used for representational purpose only

BHUBANESWAR: Contrary to the state government’s whitepaper that 2,502 rape cases were registered in Odisha in 2018, the latest report of the National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB), released on Wednesday, states that only 918 rape cases were reported during the period.

Amid the data mismatch, opposition Congress alleged that the state government had suppressed data and did not share the correct figure with the national bureau.

“It is extremely shameful and condemnable that the government, instead of addressing the issue of rising criminal cases against women in Odisha, indulged in suppression of crime data,” Congress state president Niranjan Patnaik said.

The state home department’s whitepaper, featuring data on different crimes in 2018, was placed in the assembly in July last year. The data mentioned that at least 2,502 rape cases were registered in the state in 2018.

“We also found under-reporting of crimes towards some other heads, including suicide by farmers in the state in 2018. While we come across farmer suicides regularly, NCRB report said no farmer suicide took place in 2018. The NCRB authorities should seek an explanation from the state government for suppression of data,” Niranjan added.

According to the procedure, the state crime records bureau (SCRB) supplies all requisite crime statistics to the NCRB. However, the SCRB could not explain the reason of the data mismatch between the state’s figure and the NCRB report.

“We receive data from the district police offices and send it to the NCRB. All forms of crime classifications, sought by NCRB, were sent to them,” SCRB director Rajesh Kumar said.

Police denied allegation of suppression of data. Another police officer said the data mismatch occurred because of NCRB’s crime classification rules. “They (NCRB) have written in the beginning of their report that they have some limitations. If a single FIR has mention of crimes of different nature, the NCRB will consider only the most heinous crime with maximum punishment. For example, a murder with rape is accounted as murder only for the NCRB’s compilation of data,” the officer explained.

Title: AIIB to fund Rs 2,306 crore to build part of Chennai metro rail’s phase-2 corridor
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) will fund the construction of nearly 18km elevated stretch between Meenakshi College in Kodambakkam and Poonamallee Bypass, which is part of Chennai Metro Rail Limited’s (CMRL) ambitious 118.9km 3-corridor phase-2 project.

The Beijing-headquartered bank will fund around Rs 2,306 crore ($320 million) to build the stretch linked by 18 elevated stations.

“We will call for tenders in another two to three months. A detailed design consultant, who will design the stations and the line, is already on the job. Soil test on this stretch is also completed,” an official said.

The stretch between Meenakshi College and Poonamallee bypass is part of 26.1km corridor 4 from Light House to Poonamallee Bypass. The stretch will link localities like Porur, Iyyappanthangal, Kattupakkam, Kumananchavadi, Karayanchavadi and Poonamallee which are otherwise not linked with good public transportation.

Officials said Asian Development Bank will fund the rest of the corridor between Light House and Meenakshi College covering around 8km.

Earlier, CMRL planned corridor 4 between Light House and CMBT linking core areas of the city including Mylapore, Adyar, Nandanam, T Nagar a Kodambakkam and Vadapalani. But they later extended the line to cover localities like Porur, Iyappanthangal, Kumanan Cahvadfi, Karayan Chavadi and Poonamallee, which were earlier planned to be part of monorail project, as studies found that the passenger traffic was high which could be handled only by metrorail services.

Construction for a 52km corridor in the phase is expected to begin in June. Tunnelling will be carried out on two stretches - from Venugopal Nagar in Madhavaram to Kellys covering 9km and from Kellys to Taramani Road Junction covering 12km. CMRL has invited tenders for the work.

The 52km stretch between Madhavaram and Sholinganallur and Madhavaram to CMBT will be funded by Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA).

Title: Train-18: Official refuses to respond to vigilance inquiry
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Chennai: Some of the senior railway officials facing vigilance enquiry into the Train-18 case have replied to the chief vigilance officer of Chennai-based Integral Coach Factory (ICF) stating that the questionnaire served to them is a procedural violation as per the Indian Railways Act. At least one officer has refused to respond to the questionnaire citing this and has returned the envelope unopened, multiple official sources told TOI.

The issue pertains to a vigilance case opened by railways vigilance wing to probe the alleged procedural irregularities in the procurement of electrical propulsion system for the first two rakes of Train-18, which is operated as the Vande Bharat Express between Delhi-Varanasi and Delhi-Katra. After stopping production, ICF last month floated fresh tenders for procurement of propulsion system.

Top officials including former general manager Sudhanshu Mani, former chief mechanical engineer Shubhranshu, chief design engineers Srinivas and Vavre, chief electrical engineer NK Gupta, deputy chief engineer Amitabh Singhal, finance head Kanwaljeet Asla, another CME LC Trivedi and another chief design engineer DP Dash were served questionnaire. Some officials have responded stating that the vigilance questionnaire should have been served only after consulting respective controlling officers, which was not done.

For instance, one officer has replied that his controlling officer, Railway Board Member Rolling Stock was not consulted. “This is a violation of the Indian Railways Vigilance Manual,” the official wrote in the letter. Another official in a similar letter has stated that the procedure prescribed by the manual has been violated.

Another retired official in his response has stated that for natural justice to prevail, he should have been given ‘copies of the documents, file notings and correspondence pertaining to Train-18 to be able to make a complete and competent reply.’

The officer also stated that he had been asked to support his response with documents. “How can I do that once I’m retired and not in office,” he said in his reply. However, he has responded to the questions on alleged irregularities, stating that it was from memory alone. TOI has seen copies of some of these replies and spoken to other officials regarding their response.

When contacted, ICF chief vigilance officer G Loganathan declined to comment, stating that he was not authorised. Request for an official response through the spokesperson also went unanswered.

Title: CPM to organize collectives in 104 places in Kannur
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Kannur: CPM will organize Constitution protection collectives in 104 places in the district as part of the campaign against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA). The party said that it is against the Constitution to decide citizenship on the basis of religion.

This apart, a massive rally would be organized in Thalassery on January 13, in which chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan, CPI state secretary Kanam Rajendran and prominent LDF leaders would participate, said CPM district secretary M V Jayarajan addressing a news conference here on Thursday. The collectives have already been held in some places. Jayarajan alleged that the BJP government at the Centre introduced this amendment to “divide the nation and people”. “Hence, the protest against this should not be limited to minority communities alone who are anxious about their future here,” said Jayarajan.

“That is why we decided to set up constitution protection committees,” he said, adding that the protest held in Thiruvananthapuram, in which both the ruling and opposition parties took part, within five days of the passing of the Bill was a model for the entire nation. When the assembly unanimously passed a resolution against CAA, the lone BJP member did not even vote against it because of the unity among the people of Kerala against this law, he pointed out.

The committees formed at the local level have the participation of the people who believe in secularism and democracy, but the communal and extremist organisations are not part of it, he said, adding that already 25 such committees have been formulated.

Congress and IUML activists had extended all cooperation to the campaign rallies held in the recent days, he claimed.

Title: Hockey India withdraws affiliation of Hockey Bhopal and Hockey Madhya Bharat
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Bhopal: The days of multiple hockey associations are over as Hockey India has decided to follow the Indian Olympic Association’s mantra of ‘one state-one unit’. As per the new directives issued through a letter by Hockey India - Hockey Bhopal, Hockey Madhya Bharat (Jabalpur) and Hockey Madhya Bharat (Gwalior) - will lose their membership and Hockey Madhya Pradesh will come into existence from July 20 this year.

The letter states, “From July 1, 2020, the membership of your unit with the Hockey India will deemed to be withdrawn and you will be required to coordinate your sports activities related to hockey through Hockey Madhya Pradesh.” With the IOA emphasizing on the need for national federations to work in sync with its constitution, HI has decided to comply with clause 31.1.3 of IOA's statutes that states, “The right to vote in any of the national sports federation is granted to those associations that have only one sports association in one state for those sports. It implies, therefore, that in the field of sports, it will be ‘one state, one unit’ and at the national level it will also be one unit (national sports federation) for one sport.”

From July 1, only one team — representing Hockey Madhya Pradesh— will be allowed to participate in the Nationals. It has been made clear to Hockey Bhopal and Hockey Madhya Pradesh that from July 1, 2020, the operation area of the new state member unit (Hockey Madhya Pradesh) will be all the districts of the state, including the players registered with the Hockey Bhopal and Hockey Madhya Bharat.

When contacted, secretary Hockey Bhopal, Syed Jalaluddin Rizvi, admitted that he has received a letter in this regard. “We have been running hockey for more than a decade. I will write to Hockey India that we must be given the responsibility of the upcoming Hockey Madhya Pradesh,” said Rizvi. When asked if it will be easy for three hockey units of MP to merge into one, Rizvi said, “We will ask Hockey India to advise us on this process.”

Title: Pharma cos pollute ground water in Aregudem, agri takes beating
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Villagers alleged that pharma firm Divis is letting out chemical waste into soil

HYDERABAD: All is not well in Choutuppal mandal’s Aregudem village. Locals say they are forced to spend Rs 200 every day to buy packaged water for household purposes. The borewell water is heavily polluted, thanks to large-scale presence of pharma firms.

The villagers’ concerns were corroborated by experts who said the water in the village was not fit for agricultural purposes.

While the recommended maximum level of total dissolved solids (TDS) in water is 500mg/l which is fit for use, experts found TDS to be as high as 2,000 mg/l to 20,000 mg/l. “We also found almost 10,000 tonnes of illegal solid waste dumped in and around the area. This, even as the people have been facing various health issues like skin diseases and respiratory problems,” said Damodar Reddy, an environmentalist.

Infuriated residents of this village in Yadadri-Bhuvanagiri district staged a dharna recently, demanding that expansion plans of Divis Pharma company be stalled. “The company is polluting groundwater. Even animals and cattle are not spared. Crops are dying and so are the cattle because of pollution ,” said Rajsekher Reddy, social activist from the village.“The company illegally dumps chemical waste without treatment. The borewell water is brown and some times black, but the authorities have turned a blind eye,” he charged.

The situation is much the same at Polepally village in Mahbubnagar. “Over the past couple of years, we have been complaining about the pharma companies causing pollution in the surrounding areas. In 2017, a letter was sent to the National Green Tribunal by locals about the issue,” said J Venkataiah, a farmer and resident of Polepally.

Nine companies were penalised, but they were small units, Venkataiah said. “Big players like Aurobindo Pharma Ltd, Hetero Labs, Shilpa Medicare, etc., have not been penalised. It is time criminal cases were filed against these companies,” the farmer said.

Title: Illegal electric fence claims elephant’s life, 1 arrested
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Erode: A 25-year-old female elephant was electrocuted near Thalavadi here in the early hours of Thursday when it tried to break through an illegal electric fence that was set up around a coconut farm.

According to a forest official, they have registered a case against the farm owner, 49, of Thiginarai village near Thalavadi, and arrested him for installing the electric fence without obtaining permission from concerned officials.

Pointing out that Thiginarai was situated adjacent to Sathyamangalam Tiger Reserve, the officer said wild elephants used to stray into the village and raid farmlands.

“Rangasamy erected the electric fence to protect his crop from wild elephant raid. He used to power it at nights and disconnect power supply during daytime,” the officer said.

On Thursday around 4am, the elephant tried to damage the fence using its trunk to enter the coconut farm. “The elephant was electrocuted as soon as it touched the live wires,” the official said.

When alerted, forest officials conducted autopsy and buried the carcass in the forest area. “We have registered a case against Rangasamy and arrested him,” the forest official said.

Title: Senior citizen killed at Zuarinagar after bike rams into him
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

VASCO: A 60-year-old pedestrian died on the spot after a motorcycle rammed into him at Zuarinagar, on Thursday morning. The rider of the motorcycle is critically injured and is undergoing treatment at GMC, Bambolim.

Chandrappa Khatapur was walking on NH 66-B near Zuari Indian Oil Tanking Ltd (ZIOTL), when 19-year-old Bogda resident Rahul Pal, who was proceeding from the MES College junction to ZIOTL on his motorcycle, rammed into him, killing him on the spot. Pal also sustained serious injuries and his condition is believed to be critical.

A case has been registered under provisions of the IPC. Verna PSI Shridhar Kamat is investigating. tnn

Title: Madhya Pradesh CM Kamal Nath questions BJP on nationalism
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Kamal Nath

BHOPAL: Chief minister Kamal Nath on Thursday attacked BJP and Prime Minister Narendra Modi for “teaching lessons on nationalism” to Congress, asking if PM Modi has even a distant relative who joined the freedom movement and whether BJP has a single freedom fighter.

“You have to realise the politics of BJP. It is just politics of diversion that we have perceived in the past six to seven years. Now that the assembly elections are near, look how they have diverted from real issues,” CM Nath said at a training camp of Congress’ grassroots organization, Seva Dal, on Thursday evening.

“There are questions and challenges before the nation that get no answer. Have you heard Modiji talk of the youth, farmers and women’s issues in the past few months? And they will teach Congress and Seva Dal lessons on nationalism. I always say that Modiji should name one person from his party who was a freedom fighter,” the CM said.

“If he was not there himself, then at least mention a relative who has fought for the country’s independence. Forget your name, leave out even the names of your ancestors, father and grandfather. They don’t have a single freedom fighter and want to teach nationalism to Congress,” Nath remarked at the Seva Dal camp.

CM Nath also attacked BJP over NRC and CAA. “Look how our country is under attack today and think of the outcome of this in the future. This is taking a dangerous turn. Many persons dismiss it as just politics and think it will all pass by. But the seeds that are being sown now will not go away,” CM Nath cautioned, reminding that the world looks upon India with respect for its unity in diversity and tradition of tolerance and brotherhood which is the essence of the Constitution.

“There is no other country like ours with so much diversity. The Soviet Union was there, but it disintegrated because their culture was not like ours. And our biggest strength is being attacked,” he said.

“If you go to register under NRC, there will be a question asking about your religion. You say, I am a Hindu. Then, they will ask for proof. Do you have proof you are a Hindu, your father was a Hindu and your grandfather was a Hindu? What is written in the Act is not important. What concerns us more is what is not written. Laws are made but there are sections that protect citizens also. Are those sections there?” he asked.

Reacting to the CM’s attack on PM Modi, LoP Gopal Bhargava said, “WasCM Nath a freedom fighter? Was his father or any person in his family part of the freedom movement? This debate is unnecessary and meant to divert the attention of people.”

Not a single manifesto promise of Congress has been implemented, he claimed. “Tirth darshan Yojana has stopped, 27,000 newly-wed couples are still awaiting the payment of Rs51,000 under Kanyadaan Yojana. It doesn’t matter if anyone has participated in the freedom struggle. Nationalism is defined as love for the nation. Seventy-two years have passed since the country became Independent. The chief minister should concentrate on good governance.”

Title: Wait continues for new court complex
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The wait for the new four-story court complex in the district court premises is on since years.

The cost for the Rs 31-crore project is said to have gone up by several notches in the meantime. However, the civil works of the building is still incomplete. A separate court complex with parking facilities was much needed as the existing cramped courtrooms are posing inconvenience for all.

After a wait of over three years since demolition of the old criminal court building in 2014, the foundation stone laying ceremony for the new court complex took place in early April 2017 on the district court premises. The first phase of the 2.78-acre court complex was supposed to be completed by 2018-end. After years of wait, the construction of the new court complex had begun in 2017 funded by the roads and building department. The work was going on at a slow pace and after sand shortage hit the market last year, works have come to a standstill. The civil works are incomplete and as per sources, the estimated cost likely to have escalated to nearly Rs 50 crore due to this delay.

President of Vizag Bar Association (VBA) G Maheswara Reddy said, “Around 50% works of the new court complex has been completed. The contractors have told us they would finish two floors in the first phase soon for courts to commence functioning though they have not given any deadline.”

Senior advocate and president of Forum of Legal Professionals Kuppili Muralidhar told TOI, “The new court complex was supposed to house different courts in four floors .”

Title: Fake marksheets racket busted
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Vadodara: A resident of Harni area was held for making fake marksheets and attempt certificates of Maharashtra Education Board. The breakthrough was made after the Special Operations Group (SOG) of the city police received information regarding such marksheets being made by one Vishal Patel at a computer institute in the Raopura area of the city. Patel used to run the institute in the name of his wife. SOG sleuths raided the premises and found 10 marksheets as well as 10 attempt certificates at the place. Officials claimed that Patel used to sell these for Rs 85,000 each to needy students. SOG filed an offence regarding the forgery at the Karelibaug police station. tnn

Title: Missing boy’s body found in well with limbs tied
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

M Purushothaman

CHENNAI: Two days after a Class IX boy went missing, his body was found on Wednesday in an abandoned well in Chengalpet district with the hands and feet tied. The boy, who had gone to a nearby temple, reportedly went missing on Monday and was found in the well near the land where the new collector’s office is set to come up.

Police said M Purushothaman, 14, was the second child of Murugan and Usha. Almost seven years ago, Usha separated from her husband and was staying at Kannadasan Street in Vembakkam in Chengalpet district. Purushothaman was a student in a nearby private school.

On Monday evening, Purushothaman had left home saying he would be visiting the Kannabiran temple near his house. He used to frequent the temple to meet his friends. As he did not return home till Monday night, his mother launched a search for him and contacted his friends. As she could not locate him, she lodged a complaint at the Chengalpet Taluk police station.

However, on Wednesday evening, public alerted police about a body on vacant land behind the Government Industrial Training Institute in Chengalpet. The land had been allotted for the construction of the Chengalpet collector’s office and there was an abandoned dry well near the land, police said.

Police, who recovered the body, said Purushothaman had injury marks on his hands and his limbs were tied. His mother confirmed his identity.

The Chengalpet Taluk police registered a case and sent the body to the Chengalpet Government hospital. Police said that other than the temple, the boy doesn’t venture anywhere. Police, who are clueless about the motive behind the murder, are probing whether any fight between the friends resulted in the murder.

Title: Full of residential waste, thick froth engulfs Yamuna in Mathura
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Though, the froth appears like snow, this toxic waste is full of residential and industrial discharges, confir... Read More

AGRA: Yamuna River, near Gokul barrage in Mathura , has been flowing with bubbling thick foam and filth, caused by waste discharge. Though, the froth appears like snow, this toxic waste is full of residential and industrial discharges, confirmed district authorities in Mathura.

Prof Ateeque Ahmad from Geography department in Aligarh Muslim University, who has field specialisation in environmental planning and management, told TOI on Thursday that the condition appears like frozen water due to low temperature at surface of water bodies.

“The foam starts forming on the water due to high concentration of fluoride content, caused by industrial waste and it remains standstill due to low temperature at surface of water body during this period,” he said.

Such a situation may occur when concentration of fluoride content increases and also due to unusual low temperature in winter, he said, adding that this will be more visible in morning hours when the temperature is very low.

An activist, Gopeshwar Nath Chaturvedi, who filed a petition in NGT and Allahabad high court for cleaning and maintaining ecological flow of Yamuna, told TOI that there has been no change in river’s condition till date. He said, around 1,000 people, comprising marginal farmers, devotees and activists, had started a march from Kosi Kalan in Mathura to Delhi in 2015 in a bid to save the Yamuna that has presently turned into a sewer canal. The group reached the national capital with the intent of staging an indefinite protest, which was led by Ramesh Babaji Maharaj of Maan Mandir at Barsana.

But the protest was called off after the union government gave assurance to resolve the issue. He claimed that there has been no change in quality of water till date, in fact, aquatic animals have been found dead almost every year whenever pollution levels increases in the water.

It is worth mentioning here, cleaning of Yamuna is also part of the Namami Gange Mission and Government of India has been supplementing the efforts of the states for checking the rising level of pollution of Yamuna, a tributary of Ganga, by providing financial assistance to states of Haryana, Delhi and Uttar Pradesh in a phased manner since 1993 under the Yamuna Action Plan (YAP).

The Namami Gange Mission has been approved as the flagship programme by the Central government in June 2014 with a budget outlay of Rs 20,000 crore to accomplish the twin objectives of effective abatement of pollution, conservation and rejuvenation of national river Ganga.

Title: Health workers to help locate illegal sewage outfalls
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Chennai: Greater Chennai Corporation (GCC)’s health workers who are currently busy spraying mosquito larvicidal oil (MLO) to cut breeding of malaria mosquitoes will contribute to assimilation of a data spread that will help the storm water drain (SWD) department identify illegal sewage outfalls.

Senior officials in the civic body said in most of the locations, health workers have found that mosquito breeding is concentrated in some pockets of the storm water drain (SWD) channel. This means that there is water stagnation in some pockets of the drains, facilitating breeding.

“Since this is happening at a time when there is negligible rain, this means the water stagnation is due to illegal sewage being let out in drains,” said a senior official. This comes at a time when many residents across the city have complained about mosquito breeding.

Civic body’s engineers have repeatedly pointed out how many residential as well as commercial establishments have not obtained sewer connections and let out waste matters into the nearest SWD outlet.

Since the field-work by health workers will be documented in the vector control monitoring system, corporation’s engineers will get accurate data on the areas where this illegal practices are happening, the official said. Already, inter-departmental meetings have taken place discussing this aspect.

The corporation’s anti-mosquito drive has been mostly focussed only on the water-bodies like Cooum, Adyar and water canals. To put things into perspective, the waterways are 234km long in the city, while the storm water drain network has a total length of around 1,800km. “Even if 30%-40% of the network has stagnant water, it would be a cause for concern from the mosquito point of view,” another official said.

An official earlier said at the zonal level, there were dedicated staff for drain desilting work, who would monitor the mosquito breeding spots in the channels. “But now the desilting work is done by contractors,” the official said.

Title: City witnessed 32% fall in property offences in 2019
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Though property offences saw a steep fall of 32 per cent in 2019 compared to the previous year, giving the city a reason to cheer, crime mapping has revealed that 35 per cent of the offences took place in a handful of locations — MVP Colony, HB Colony, Seethammadhara, Lawson’s Bay Colony, Pandurangapuram, East Point Colony and few other spots under east and Dwaraka sub zones of the Vizag Police.

Close to 850 cases of property offences were reported in 2019, the corresponding figure for 2018 was 1,256.

Speaking to TOI, ADCP (Crime) V Suresh Babu said that the police department has adopted new strategies to nab habitual offenders, some of whom belong to inter-state gangs, bringing down the number of untoward incidents significantly.

“We observed that the over 35 per cent of the property offences were reported from posh colonies in the city. We are chalking out plans to mitigate the number of offences in the areas in the coming days,” he added.

Vizag Police Commissionerate has two divisions (North and South) and six sub-divisions — east, west, south, north, Harbour and Dwaraka sub-divisions. Among the six sub-divisions, Vizag east and Dwarka sub-divisions witnessed more incidents of theft — Rs 6.06 crore in cash, gold and silver ornaments were stolen in 2010 and the city police managed to recover Rs 2.77 crore with 50 per cent detection rate in the cases.

Crime mapping is one of the major tools to understand crime trends, crime-prone zones, the modus of operandi and pattern to the reduction of the crimes and nabbing the offenders. Crime mapping supplemented with preventive measures can play a critical role in keeping the city safe, said ACP of Central Crime Station, DS Sravan Kumar.

“We are working on keeping the number of break-ins in the city to a minimum this Sankranti vacation by deploying special teams at vulnerable locations in the city,” said a police official.

City police chief RK Meena said increasing number of online thefts were a cause for concern in the city. Cyber criminals stole over Rs 7.2 crore in 2019, while house break ins caused a loss of Rs 6 crore.

Title: FICCI moots relaxations of fiscal deficit target to boost demand
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Hyderabad: With advance GDP estimates projecting FY20 GDP growth at 5% it is necessary for the government to look at measures to infuse capital in the economy in a systematic way, FICCI national president Sangita Reddy said on Thursday.

“FICCI is of the view that the fiscal deficit target could be relaxed to support infusion of Rs 1.5-2 lakh crore in the economy in the coming year as such fiscal expansion is much needed at the current juncture to give a boost to demand and trigger investments,” Reddy said in a release.

“The nature of the economy is cyclical and when a potential recessionary cycle is foreseen, move to induct more capital into the economy to re-energise it is more important than worrying about fiscal deficit. A time-bound plan must be put in place to repair fiscal deficit through different measures including disinvestment in PSUs,” she said.

Reddy said India Inc was looking forward to the government continuing taking steps towards bridging the existing gaps and giving out positive signals to boost sentiment, consumption and investments. “Apart from providing cheaper loans, more efforts must be made to increase incomes, especially in rural areas. This can be achieved through an increase in the quantum income support under PM-KISAN and expansion of the direct benefit transfer scheme. Steps are also required to boost construction, infrastructure and exports,” she added.

Pointing out that FICCI is conducting a survey across industry to assess the sentiment of the nation and what it would take corporate India to re-energise itself, Reddy said the government must enable reforms, which will enable ease of doing business, for sustaining growth and demand.

Title: Postmaster booked for siphoning off Rs 1.6L
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Vadodara: A postmaster was booked for siphoning off public money to the tune of Rs 1.6 lakh while serving at Kotna branch post-office between November 2017 and January 2018.

The accused Bhima Gohil had collected the money from the citizens as the electricity bill of Madhya Gujarat Vij Company Ltd. But instead of depositing the money with the sub-post office, Gohil used the money for his personal expenses. Police said that Gohil used to take the money from the citizens and even gave them receipt for it.

It was only in January 2018 that postmaster of Koyali sub-post office learnt about Gohil’s scandal and he informed his superiors. When the accused was questioned, he deposited Rs 65,964.

An inquiry was ordered against him and at the end of it he was suspended. The remaining Rs 98,099 was recovered from him after the inquiry was ordered.

After the internal probe, the senior superintendent of post-offices, Vadodara west division, ordered that a criminal offence be registered against Gohil.

Accordingly, the department complained against Gohil and an offence was registered against him at Nandesari police station on Wednesday.

Title: Keeladi auditorium an instant hit with visitors
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Chennai: Soon after the inauguration of the 43rd Chennai Book Fair on Thursday, a special auditorium showcasing artefacts excavated from Keeladi in Sivaganga district and the virtual reality show taking the visitors to excavation trenches became an instant hit with visitors to the fair.

The 3000sqft auditorium titled as Keeladi-Eeradi at the fair at YMCA grounds in Nandanam displayed 2,600 years-old artefacts like bones of humped bull, terracotta vessels, model of excavation trenches, replica of water management structures, black and redware bowls and pot sherds inscribed with Tamil Brahmi. Some of the ancient copper objects and Carnelian beads displayed at the auditorium also attracted many visitors and some of them took pictures with the ancient artefacts.

But, youngsters and old people queued up to get the feel of the Keeladi excavated site through virtual reality.

Tamil Nadu’s archaeology department has employed a virtual technology start-up to record 3D images of the Keeladi excavation site. With the help of virtual gears, viewers get a feel of entering the excavation site.

“It is excellent experience. I felt like being physically there in the trenches where the excavation is going on. We can also get the feel of ambience with trees in the surroundings are visible,” said R Mehandran, a civil service aspirant.

K S Madhuvanthie, a Class IX student said the experience was very exciting and she can see inside one of the tents at the excavation site. If visitors focus more on the objects, they can also view the Brahmi writings on the pot sherds at the site.

Adjacent to VR show, there were another display of excavated objects with explanation of their usages in Tamil. Viewers can also take a picture at Keeladi site using Kinect technology at the auditorium. The pictures will be mailed to them within hours.

Along with Tamil Nadu Textbook and Educational Services Corporation, the archaeology department brought out a book about Keeladi excavation and artefacts in 24 different languages.

“We are releasing Keeladi book at the Chennai Book Fair. Readers and visitors can buy a book in any language including French, Spanish and German and Mandarin,” said T Udhayachandran, commissioner of archaeology, Tamil Nadu.

Earlier, chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami inaugurated the book fair and Keeladi-Eeradi auditorium. He also unveiled Tamil saint poet Thiruvalluvar's sand sculpture by Sudarsan Pattnaik at the venue.

He said, “The government would give Rs 75 lakh to Booksellers and Publishers’ Association of South India (BAPASI) to conduct book fair.”

Title: Transporters see red over ‘entry fee’ in Meerut Cantt
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

The fee is being levied to create funds for maintenance purpose as no new funds are being released for the sam... Read More

MEERUT: Transporters are up in arms as they were charged an “entry fee” at three points in Meerut Cantt on the intervening night of Wednesday and Thursday. The Meerut Cantt Board had cancelled the order allowing the private contractor from imposing an “entry fee” on all commercial vehicles. However, the contractor cited a Allahabad High Court order, dated December 20, 2019, which put a stay on the Cantt board’s directive.

The fee is being levied to create funds for maintenance purpose as no new funds are being released for the same by the authorities. Earlier, no fee was charged. The instructions to levy a fee were given by the Cantt board on December 8. However, after protests, the board authorities withdrew their order on December 12 and cancelled the contract with the contractor. Later, the contractor approached the Allahabad High Court for relief and obtained a stay on the Cantt board orders.

On January 8, the contractor in question suddenly started taking an “entry fee” without informing the Cantt authority. He cited the HC order to do so.

According to sources, the authorities of the Meerut Cantonment Board have set up new barriers at three spots — Mawana Road, Roorkee Road and Jali Kothi — to collect an “entry fee” to the restricted area. This is in addition to the nine existing barriers. The fee ranges between Rs 25 and Rs 150 depending on the size of the vehicle.

Mamta Kansey, additional CEO, Meerut Cantt, said, “We did not give any permission to the contractor to collect the fee, and the procedure was started without bringing this to our knowledge. A board meeting is scheduled for January 14. Before this, there is little that we can do because of the court order.”

Title: Bijnor: Leopard attacks if not checked, poachers will exploit fears of villagers, feel experts
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

According to experts and forest department officials, the count of leopards has increased considerably in the ... Read More

MEERUT: Six deaths in just six weeks were enough to instill fear. Panicked villagers in affected parts of western UP’s Bijnor have stopped venturing out alone after the darkness falls. And when they do, they go out in groups huddled together, vigilant and armed. “Leopards, although shy, give you a swift death,” said a villager in Najibabad area, where the felines have mauled three persons to death in the last one month. On Monday, a leopard killed a 14-year-old boy in Najibabad’s Bhogpur village. Soon, enraged villagers shot the animal dead and dragged the carcass for a mile. Administration and forest department officials came later, and booked 80 villagers for killing the animal.

According to experts and forest department officials, the count of leopards has increased considerably in the region, although no one knows their exact numbers in the absence of census. With the numbers, their “trespasses” have also increased, posing a challenge before the forest authorities.

This man-animal conflict will give space to poachers and forest tribes if government agencies are not able to act on time and mitigate the growing crisis, experts believe. “It has already started,” one of them said, while referring to a recent seizure of leopard skin worth Rs 20 lakhs in street market from three poachers in neighbouring Saharanpur district.

“Seizure of leopard skin in Saharanpur is just the beginning of a dangerous trend. There is a growing disenchantment among villagers whose role is critical to the conservation of wildlife. As the forest department is ill-equipped to reduce man-animal conflict, poachers and hunting tribes like Kanjars and Badhiya can easily join hands with panicked villagers to ‘address their problems’ and this obviously will expose leopards and other animals in the region to grave risk,” said Abrar Ahmed, illegal wildlife trade investigator and former programme officer at Trade Records Analysis of Flora and Fauna in Commerce (TRAFFIC-India).

“Perception created by these communities among the farmers and villagers is that they help alleviate human-animal conflict through their traditional vocation of capturing animals,” he adds.

Baljeet Singh, a certified hunter who was on several occasions engaged by the UP and Uttarakhand governments to kill man-eaters, says the problem is going to rise in the future due to depleting green cover and ever-increasing farming lands.

“Though there has been no census done for the leopard in this area, but my experience tells me that there are no less than 200 in Bijnor district. I have seen six of them recently, including four cubs around my village in Jhaalpur,” says the hunter who has so far killed a dozen man-eating leopards in the last four decades.

When contacted, divisional forest officer (DFO) of Bijnor, M Semmaran, a veteranian who rescued more than a dozen leopard cubs from Bijnor, Amroha and Moradabad, told TOI, “There is always a possibility of poachers taking advantage of the vulnerability of villagers. And, the only way out of this situation is creating awareness among farmers in favour of the big cats. Death of villagers in leopard attacks is certainly unfortunate. We have our infrastructure in place, with all cameras fitted in the region. This year we will certainly have census of the leopard.”

Farmers, on the other hand, are stuck between the deep sea and the devil. “Leopards are a kind of evil necessity for us as they keep stray animals and neelgai away from our crops. But, at the same time, these big cats, if turn man-eaters, can play havoc with our lives especially when forest department is unable to mitigate the crisis due to lack of expertise and equipment,” says Rajender Singh, a villager based in Muzaffarnagar.

Title: Prohibit funding of elections by MNCs & NGOs, says Asaduddin Owaisi
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

AIMIM chief Asaduddin Owaisi at the plenary session on ‘Organisational Burden on Political Parties’ on Thursda... Read More

HYDERABAD: Pointing out how parties tend to make attempts to be in the good books of multinationals that fund elections, MIM chief Asaduddin Owaisi said there should be prohibition on sponsorship of elections by multinationals and NGOs. He also said that electoral bonds must be done away with to bring about a level playing field for parties.

Speaking at the plenary session on ‘Organisational burden on political parties’ organised as part of the Indian Democracy at Work Conference- Money Power in Politics, he pointed out that political parties representing marginalised communities lack a level playing field when it comes to elections and are finding it increasingly difficult to fight elections, as each is getting costlier.

“The real cost of sustaining a political party is in competing with disproportionately richer political groups which are now back by corporate donations. This means that parties will not only have to compete for voters but also for being in the good books of large businesses. Therefore, the most urgent reform I believe is to prohibit all forms of corporate donations and NGO donations.”

Owaisi also struck off electoral bonds as a viable option. “Electoral bond is a mystery. It is wrong on principles of equity and transparency. I am of the opinion that it is better to let citizens contribute as I am answerable to citizens,” he added.

He said that among other issues was the privilege that bigger national parties enjoyed. “The biggest injustice is we are carrying a legacy of the British era. For example, any national party having 7 MPs will get subsidised land for construction in Delhi. The expenditure of star campaigners up to 40 is not included in electoral expenditure of the party. These things work in favour of bigger parties and prevent smaller parties from catching up,” he added.

Title: Street vendors are good for public safety: Hawkers’ association
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Presence of hawkers and street vendors can help prevent anti-social activities and even trafficking in such areas, claimed an association of hawkers of NSC Bose Road, which has been declared a no-hawking zone.

Hawking and street vending are recognised and permitted in many countries with appropriate regulation. But in the guise of enumerating hawkers, many new people are added to the list while persons who are hawking in the NSC Bose Road for over three decades are left, advocate Nagasaila, representing the association, said.

The issue pertains to a contempt plea moved by social activist Traffic Ramaswamy and another PIL by a charted accountant to maintain the road as a no-hawking zone as per the directions of the Supreme Court. When the pleas came up for hearing, the association submitted that the Chennai corporation authorities are conducting the enumeration through private agencies who have engaged persons who do not even speak the local language for the process. “The authorities will not complete the process or implement the provisions of the Street Vending Act for their own interest of collecting mamool form such vendors,” she added and said that the only way to find a proper solution for the issue is to include the hawkers in the enumeration process.

However, additional advocate-general PH Arvind Pandian representing the corporation submitted that the enumeration process has been completed in all 15 zones in terms of Street Vendors (Protection of livelihood &Regulation of Street Vending) Act 2014. As for NSC Bose Road, he said the town vending committee rejected the request with regard to 637 street vendors in zone V.

Recording the submissions, a division bench of Justice M Sathyanarayanan and Justice R Hemalatha put a specific question as to the steps taken to check unauthorised parking of two-wheelers on the extended platform along the NSC Bose Road. To this, Pandian submitted that there is a proposal to place bollards at all the intersections from Rajaji Salai to Govindappa Naicken Street for which estimates have been prepared for Rs 28.95 lakhs which is inclusive of fixing duct doors, water tables and floor concrete. Tenders have been floated for the work and it is expected to be completed by February 28, he added.

The bench directed the corporation to publish the enumeration list in its official website and adjourned the hearing to March 10.

Title: Odisha: Extra classes for poor students in summer break
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

BHUBANESWAR: To improve learning abilities of weaker students, the state government has decided to conduct extra classes for them during summer vacation. Teachers will take classes on rotation basis for these students, said school and mass education minister Samir Ranjan Dash.

“State government is taking several learning enhancement programmes (LEPs) for improvement in standard of kids and to ensure that students feel confident to take examinations. So to encourage students, who are weak in studies, they will be asked to attend extra classes during summer vacation,” Dash said.

An official source said after the final examination results are out, students, who are found performed badly in the exam, will have to come to school to attend classes during the holidays for the next session. Teachers, who will come to school on roster duty will implement learning enhancement programmes like Ujjwal and Utthan schemes during the holidays, he added.

Government schools close for around 45-50 days for summer vacation in May-June every year. The one-and-a-half month time can be effectively used for improving the standards of children by taking extra classes for them, he pointed out. The classes will be held for students up to class IX.

The minister further informed that a lot of districts, including Cuttack , Kendrapara , Kandhamal and others, have undertaken special measures to ensure mission zero fail in matriculation examination. This year 82 schools across the state had zero results, said an official.

While parents welcomed the decision of the government, teachers were apprehensive about losing the summer holidays. “It is good that government is thinking about weak students and trying to improve their standard by conducting extra classes. If they get proper guidance and intervention at the right time then many of them may make up when the schools reopen,” said Ajanta Parida, mother of a Class IV student.

“Unlike other jobs, teachers get some extra holidays during summer and winter vacations. But of late due to different administrative works and trainings we are not getting these holidays. Now these extra classes will add to the burden of teachers,” said a teacher, requesting anonymity.

Title: Woman killed in road mishap, hubby injured
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Visakhapatnam: A 43-year-old woman was killed in a road accident and her husband severely injured when a travel bus hit the motorbike they were travelling on at Srinagar in the early hours of Thursday. The deceased women was identified as Keerthi Mandaveeya of Kurmannapalem in the city.

Deepak Vallabh Das Mandaveeya (52), manager of Pooja Industries in VSEZ was going to a private hospital in the city along with wife Keerti for dialysis tests. When they reached Chinagantyada area, a travel bus hit their motorbike.

The impact was such that Keerthi was thrown off the bike and suffered serious head injury. She died on the spot while her husband sustained injures. The driver of the travel bus was taken into custody by cops. Keerthi’s body has been sent for post mortem. Deepak’s friends allege the cops took the deceased woman’s husband to the police station and kept him for long.

Title: Cops hold rally to curb break-ins
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Kancharapalem police on Thursday advised people to use Locked House Monitoring System ( LHMS ) for protection of their houses during Sankranti. Police personnel will monitor residences through the system by fixing cameras in the house and premises if anyone sought the system during their tour to other places.

Cops organised a huge auto rally with more than 100 auto rickshaws with banners of safety precautions to the public who planned to go out station during this Sankranti.

They created awareness among the public through leaflets in which many suggestions to the people to avoid burglaries.

They even pasted posters at various junctions. The crime wing sub-inspector Sudarsana Rao advised the people to be careful while drawing money from the banks or ATMs, because diversion gangs would be there to loot them.

Cops warned the people to keep their bags and others in a safe way while travelling autorickshaws and buses. TNN

Title: Erecting flags on roundabouts, traffic islands also risky
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Trichy: Ever since the death of a 24-year-old woman in Chennai after an illegal banner fell on her, the authorities have prevented hoardings from cropping up at public spots in Trichy city. However, political parties have now an alternative to make their presence felt and appease their visiting party seniors - traffic islands and roundabouts. Though flags erected on the traffic islands and roundabouts are as fatal as flex hoardings, the government agencies are yet to take a step against it.

As the BJP conducted a demonstration in support of the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) in Trichy on Thursday, party flags occupied the traffic islands of Major Saravanan signal and Palakkarai roundabout. Dozens of BJP flags were erected and tied to the traffic infrastructure. Thursday’s incident was not the first of its kind, as various political outfits had done it recently to welcome their senior party leaders to the city.

While city police and Trichy City Corporation have taken a tough stand against illegal flex banners ever since the death of Subashree in Chennai, they lack the steam in tackling the flags in public places. "Flags erected on public spots are also risky. Police and the civic body should take steps against erecting flags on roads as well," S P Thiyagarajan, an RTI activist, said. City traffic police remain a mute spectator to the violations or blame it on the corporation or the state highways department.

Title: Uttar Pradesh’s new scheme: Bring food items to school and learn about its nutrition value by teachers
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

The students will be asked to get any one food item (fruit/vegetable/others) of their choice on the two days t... Read More

MEERUT: In a unique initiative, students of UP government schools will now get lessons on nutritional values of foods they eat. Under the scheme, ‘Anukoot’, 10 minutes on two days a week will be slotted for discussion on nutritional values of food items of the student’s choice.

The students will be asked to get any one food item (fruit/vegetable/others) of their choice on the two days to know its nutritional value. The initiative was first launched in Amethi, and is now being replicated in the entire state.

“The state authorities have decided to come up with ‘Anukoot’ in all the schools of Uttar Pradesh. This initiative was first started as a pilot project in Amethi and will now implemented in the entire state to spread awareness about nutritional value of food items among children,” read the order from Dev Pratap Singh, UP special secretary.

Under the initiative, the nutritional value of green vegetables, fruits, pulses, jaggery, wheat, rice and others will be discussed.

“All the students should be encouraged to bring any food item of their choice on selected two days of the week and teachers should teach them about their nutritional values. The items should be later consumed along with their mid-day meal,” read Singh’s order.

“On other days of the week, teachers should discuss about historical spots, famous personalities, environment conservation and others,” read Singh’s order. While his order is dated December 31, 2019, instructions to follow the order were given by Vijay Kiran Anand, UP Mid-Day Meal director on January 8.

Title: Undaunted student protesters to continue sit-in despite AMU administration warning
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

AGRA: Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) administration on Thursday issued a warning to students to end their sit-in against CAA at Bab-e-Syed gate, as it violates a high court order that bars holding of any protest at the main gate of AMU’s administrative block.

The AMU administration has put notices in campus, stating all concerned are requested to comply with orders of the high court, which direct the Aligarh district magistrate and SSP to ensure that no person is allowed to “convene, hold, attend, address or take part in procession or join any kind of dharna pradarshan and rally, either at the main gate of the administrative block of AMU or within 100m radius of the block and the VC’s lodge inside campus”.

In response, students’ leaders claimed they had measured the distance at which they have set up their protest site, and it is more than the distance suggested by the high court. Former students’ union president Faizul Hassan said their protest will continue, notwithstanding directions of the varsity administration.

Meanwhile, hundreds of students formed a human chain from the Arts Faculty lawn to Bab-e-Syed gate, to express solidarity with JNU students and teachers who were attacked by masked men in their campus.

Demanding immediate action against the goons, the students also sought a probe into the role of Delhi Police and JNU administration in the attacks. They also demanded withdrawal of FIRs lodged against several JNU students including its Union president Aishe Ghosh.

Continuing their protest against CAA, NPR and NRC, the students sang revolutionary songs and poems in chorus, led by Haider Saifullah, such as Faiz Ahmad Faiz’s Hum Dekhenge, Hafeez Meeruthi’s Zanjeeren and El Profesor’s Bella Ciao.

It may be noted that Faiz’s poem, Hum Dekhenge, had created a controversy after IIT Kanpur set up an enquiry to decide whether it is anti-Hindu, a move that was criticized by eminent literary figures including Javed Akhtar.

The protest on Thursday was concluded by recitation of the AMU anthem (Tarana) and India’s National Anthem in succession.

Title: Rs 35 crore bank fraud: CBI raids seven places across Morena
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

BHOPAL: The CBI’s Bhopal branch on Thursday conducted searches at seven places in Morena district in connection with two separate bank fraud cases worth Rs 35 crore. Several incriminating documents were seized during the day-long search.

CBI, ACB, Bhopal had received an information from S S Rattan, deputy general manager and zonal head of UCO Bank , Bhopal, alleging that a bank fraud was committed in UCO Bank, Morena branch, between December 31, 2016 and February 19, 2018 in sanctioning of loan worth Rs10.70 crore in the name of 22 borrowers against warehouse receipts of M/s Maa Bijasen Agro Infrastructure as security.

It is alleged that the warehouse owner availed 22 demand loans from the bank by presenting warehouse receipts through different persons and misappropriated bank’s fund and thus defrauded UCO Bank to the tune of Rs10.70 crore. Owners of the warehouse fraudulently issued warehouse receipts in the name of different persons, who are mostly the employees, relatives etc. of the warehouse owner.

Moreover, they unauthorised released/removed pledged goods without having release orders from UCO Bank. No inspection of stock was carried out at the time of sanction of warehouse receipt loan nor the periodical inspection of warehouse was carried out to ascertain the quality and quantity of the stock pledged with the bank.

A case has been registered against RK Sinha, the then chief manager of UCO Bank, Morena branch, Ravindra Kumar Sharma, partner of M/s Maa Bijasan Agro Infrastructure, Sangita Sharma partner of M/s Maa Bijasan Agro Infrastructure, and others under Section 120-B, 407, 420 of the Indian Penal Code. In a separate complaint, it was been alleged that a fraud was committed in UCO Bank, Morena branch, between August 4, 2016 and September 1, 2018 in sanctioning of loan worth Rs 24.71 crore in the name of different borrowers, against pledge of warehouse receipts of M/s Shanti Bhandargrah.

As in the previous case, owners of the warehouse (M/s Sahanti Bhandarhrah) fraudulently issued warehouse receipts in the name of different persons, who are mostly the employees, relatives etc. of warehouse owner and availed 51 demand loans from the bank by presenting warehouse receipts through different persons thereby misappropriating bank’s fund and thus defrauding UCO Bank to the tune of Rs 24.71 crore.

They released/removed pledged goods without having release orders from UCO Bank. No inspection of stock was carried out at the time of sanction of WHR loan nor the periodical inspection of warehouse was carried out to ascertain the quality and quantity of the stock pledged with the bank, said CBI sources.

Title: Kerala History Congress moves anti-CAA resolution
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Kottayam: The fifth annual session of the Kerala History Congress (KHC) which began here on Thursday moved a resolution demanding the withdrawal of the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA). The resolution was presented by T Mohammed Ali, head of the history department, Farook College, Kozhikode and was seconded by Gopakumaran Nair N, general secretary, KHC. It was passed unanimously by the members.

The resolution said that the Act brings up religion as a determinant for citizenship and as such violates the provisions of Constitution of India. The session demanded the government not to extend NRC all over India. The citizenship is more a right of the people than one thing to be proved.

The session also condemned the vandalism and atrocities against students, teachers, intellectuals, and educational institutions including JNU and Jamia Millia Islamia on account of their articulation of dissent over the policies of the state. The Congress also expressed its solidarity with all those who are protesting against the attempt to destroy the idea of India and the constitutional values of the country.

The three-day Congress began at the MG University campus on Thursday. Kapil Raj, director, School of Advanced Studies in Social Sciences, PSL University, Paris, inaugurated the session. President of KHC Rajan Gurukkal presided. R Mahalakshmi, Centre for Historical Studies, JNU, delivered the keynote address.

Title: ‘Q’ branch seeks custody of arrested terror suspects
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Chennai: The Tamil Nadu ‘Q’ branch sleuths have sought to inquire the three terror suspects arrested in Bengaluru to probe their alleged plans to carry out attacks in Tamil Nadu and Karnataka.

Police had nabbed Mohamed Haneef Khan, 29, Imran Khan, 32, and Mohamed Zaid, 24, all from Bengaluru, for assisting murder suspects S Syed Ali Nawas, 25, A Abdul Shamim, 25, of Kanyakumari, and C Khaja Moideen , 52, of Cuddalore. They had allegedly harboured the trio after they skipped trial in a Poonamallee court in December.

Mohamed Haneef Khan, Imran Khan and Zaid were allegedly indoctrinated by Moideen and were to act as sleeper cells based in Bengaluru to execute terror activities. Inquiries revealed they were asked to take photographs of vital installations in Bengaluru.

The ‘Q’ branch sleuths have sought their custody to question them about three pistols and 80 bullets seized from them and their alleged targets in Bengaluru and in cities of Tamil Nadu and Kerala.

A police officer said they sought the custody of the trio to know about their plans and other sleeper cells active in Karnataka and neighbouring states. Police have seized a pen drive from them.

Moideen and Nawas were involved in the murder of K P S Suresh Kumar, Hindu Munnani leader from Tiruvallur. The incident was reported on July 18, 2014. They had absconded without appearing before the trial court. TNN

Title: Two students hurt in crude bomb explosion
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Two students of a government school were injured when two country-made bombs exploded near the institute at Geddalapadu village under Santhakaviti mandal in Srikakulam district on Thursday morning.

The incident took place when the two had gone for attending nature’s call at an open plot near the school and noticed two objects at the place. Curious, they threw stones at the objects and it exploded.

The injured students have been identified as B Tirupathi Rao (12) and Ch Raju (11), students of Class VII and Class VI respectively.

The injured children were shifted to RIMS Hospital at Srikakulam Town and after first-aid, Tirupathi Rao, who was severely injured, was shifted to KG Hospital in Vizag city. Sub-inspector of Santhakaviti Police Station, N Kameswara Rao, said some farmers may have placed the crude bombs at the location to kill wildboars, which have been destroying standing crops in villages.

The sub-inspector said the condition of the injured persons was stable. However, the parents of the students demanded that the police register criminal cases against those who manufactured the crude bombs.

Title: CBI raids IRSE officer’s quarters
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

SECUNDERABAD: CBI Bengaluru sleuths on Thursday conducted searches on M Ravindranath Reddy, an officer of Indian Railway Service of Engineers (IRSE), in connection with some irregularities committed during his tenure in Bengaluru.

CBI sleuths inspected Reddy’s quarters at Lalaguda. An FIR was already booked against him. Reddy is presently chief project director (bridge works), South Central Railway.

Reddy joined IRSE in 1988. He worked in South Western Railway as chief engineer (construction) in Bengaluru and was a nodal officer with Karnataka government on major railway projects.

CBI, Bengaluru unit, filed the FIR against Reddy following several irregularities in the execution of works in Bengaluru. As per the property returns filed by the IRSE officer, Reddy had purchased a 2,400 square ft of a plot in 2008 at Nagavara area and another 1,575 sft plot in Rachenahalli in Bengaluru in 2013.

CBI sources said Reddy had also inherited a residential plot of 2,920 sft from his father.

Title: Differently-abled man on tricycle peddles awareness on drug abuse
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Meet Kuldip, a 53-year-old differently abled man from Baddowal Chawni, Ludhiana, Punjab, who is on an all-India tour to raise awareness about drug addiction and its effect on society. He arrived in the Port City on Wednesday night on his battery-operated tricycle on which he would travel around 150 km to 200 km every day.

Kuldip started out on his ‘Bharat Bhraman Yatra’ on April 1, 2019, and so far covered 23,200 km. On his tour he has been playing a key role in helping police identify drug users and peddlers. “Usually I chat up with people on the road. Once I identify a drug user, I pretend to be an addict and ask them for drugs . I find out about drug suppliers and inform the cops and help them nab the peddlers. Later, I also help counsel them,” Kuldip told TOI. Adding that he has already tasted success during his tour in Tamil Nadu and Maharashtra.

Kuldip has been given shelter by the Gurudwara committee at the city Gurudwara. His plans to visit Odisha next. But before that he intends to meet polio expert doctor Adinarayana of Subham Prema Hospital of Greater Vizag for calipers. This is not the first Bharat Bhraman Yatra’ for Kuldip. Earlier, he had taken up an pan-India trip on December 1 in 2010 to raise awarenss about disability rights..

Title: HC issues bailable warrant against IAS officers
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Bhopal/Jabalpur: A single-judge bench of MP high court has issued a bailable warrant against IAS officers Vinod Semwal and Gauri Singh, who recently opted for voluntary retirement from service. They have been asked to appear in person in the court on February 11. The warrant was issued in response to a contempt of court petition filed against the two officers by some employees of OILFED, who were sent to panchayat and rural development department on deputation following the company’s closure.

The petitioners RK Malviya, R Tiwari, Mahesh Katare and Pradeep Upase said that after their services were transferred to panchayat department, they were not given benefits of fifth and sixth wage commissions. They filed a petition in the court seeking direction in this regard. A single-judge bench allowed the petition and ordered the state government to provide them benefits of fifth and sixth wage commission, besides the amount of arrears due to them. The state went in appeal against the order before a division bench, which also upheld the order of the single-judge bench. The SLP filed against the double bench order before the Supreme Court was also rejected.

Following this, they had filed a petition in the high court for compliance of the order passed by the single-judge HC bench and retained up to the Supreme Court. Counsel for the petitioner, Ashok Kumar Chaurasia, in the previous hearing said that state government and its officials have been seeking time to comply with the order. The court, then, warned that if the respondents don’t comply with the order by the next date, bailable warrant would be issued against them. Since the compliance had taken place till Wednesday, the court of Justice Subodh Abhyankar issued bailable warrant against Gauri Singh and Vinod Semwal, who were respondents in the case in their capacity as ACS, panchayat and PS, general administration.

Title: Crimes against women in Telangana dipped in 2018, reveals NCRB data
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: The number of murders, kidnaps, crimes against women and crimes against children saw a rise in Hyderabad in 2018 when compared to 2017, but the overall crime rate in the city was down by 3.76%. This was stated in the 2018 crime data released by the National Crime Records Bureau ( NCRB ) on Thursday.For that matter, the overall crime reported in Telangana has also decreased by 4.92% when compared to 2017. Crimes against women across the state dipped by 8.5% in 2018 when compared to the previous year.The NCRB data has also shown that 81 murders were reported in Hyderabad in 2018. In comparison, 64 murders were reported the previous year.NCRB recorded the crime, accident and suicide data under different heads of 29 states and seven Union territories. The bureau also focused on 19 cities by sharing specific information of crimes under different heads.Hyderabad was ranked 15 among 19 cities when it came to overall reported crimes of 16,012 cases. Delhi registered the highest crime cases with 2,37,660 cases.According to the NCRB data, the number of kidnap cases registered both in Telangana and in Hyderabad saw a substantial increase. In Hyderabad, there were 411 kidnap cases in 2018 when compared to 341 cases in 2017. Officials attributed the increase to missing cases of children, which are also treated as kidnap cases.In 2018, the number of road accidents was 22,230 and a total of 6,603 persons had died. In Hyderabad, 2,846 accidents were reported in which 310 persons had lost their lives.

Title: Meerut: Form WhatsApp groups to keep tabs on schools, education officers told
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

MEERUT: Uttar Pradesh government is planning to make WhatsApp groups of block education officers in each district to keep a check on implementation of government policies and school activities. This, government authorities say, will make it easier to keep a check on the policies being implemented in schools in the entire state.

“This is to bring to your notice that in order to keep a check on government policies being executed in the schools and to also see whether school activities are being carried out properly or not, all the block education officers should share their numbers registered on WhatsApp. This is being done so that a WhatsApp group at the state level can be formed to get a daily update from all schools,” Vijay Kiran Anand, state project director, Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan, has said in an order.

The numbers have been asked from each district in a tabular format, which has been shared with all 75 districts of UP. This comes at a time when the initiative of Prerna app has already been launched to keep a check on government facilities being provided at the ground level, including midday meal, school uniforms, furniture and others.

Under the Prerna app initiative, the teachers have been instructed to upload pictures of the schools and the facilities in question so that the state government authorities can be updated of all activities and it also facilitates a transparent framework.

Title: Uttarakhand: Sunshine after snow, but cold wave continues, many roads still blocked
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Snow-covered picturesque Mukhba village near Gangotri

DEHRADUN/MUSSOORIE/UTTARKASHI: The weather cleared on Thursday after almost three days of incessant rain and snowfall in many places across Uttarakhand. People basked in the sunshine which came as a welcome relief from the cold wave conditions. However, over 100 roads, including the Gangotri and Yamunotri national highways in Uttarkashi remained blocked on Thursday following the heavy snowfall that had taken place at many places across the state a day earlier.

In terms of accessibility, Pauri district remained the worst affected with around 40 roads, mostly village link roads, remaining blocked, while over three dozen roads in Uttarkashi district were also obstructed due to heavy snowfall. Badrinath and Kedarnath national highways, which had also been blocked on Wednesday, were opened for traffic movement on Thursday evening, according to state emergency operation centre (SEOC)

Chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat who took stock of the situation, told mediapersons that “all the concerned agencies and departments are at work and efforts are on to open all blocked roads.” “The situation will be normal in the next 24-48 hours,” he added.

Electricity and water supply in several villages across the state were also disrupted. In Uttarkashi, drinking water supply was reported to have been disrupted in as many as 55 villages including Harsil, Mukhba, Raithal, Barsu, Kharsali, Jankichatti, Kupda, Narayanpuri, Kimdar, Pujeli, Liwadi and Fitadi among others.

Meanwhile, cold day conditions prevailed across Uttarakhand with temperatures, both maximum and minimum, settling below normal levels. Mussoorie was recorded as the coldest place in the state on Thursday with mercury plunging to a minimum of -2.5 degrees Celsius. Heavy snowfall in the Queen of Hills on Wednesday had thrown traffic completely out of gear as the roads were blocked and entry of vehicles inside the town had been stopped by police. However, from early Thursday morning, JCBs were deployed and snow was cleared from all connecting roads of the town. Although vehicles from Dehradun were being stopped at Kothal gate and were later allowed to come up till Jaypee bend, this did not deter many tourists who walked nearly 4 km from Jaypee bend to enjoy the snow which was between 9 to 10 inches deep in most places.

Normal traffic on Mussoorie-Dehradun road was resumed by late afternoon. Meanwhile, electricity supply which had been disrupted due to faults as well as trees falling on the supply line in Mussoorie, was resumed by Thursday evening.

In Dehradun, the maximum temperature was recorded at 10.8 degrees Celsius, almost eight notches below normal, while the minimum settled at 4.5 degrees Celsius, two degrees below the normal level.

The regional meteorological centre has predicted continuation of cold conditions across the state on Friday as well.

Title: After J&K, Uttarakhand safest state for senior citizens in North India: NCRB report
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Uttarakhand witnessed total six cases of crime against senior citizens in 2018, as per NCRB data

DEHRADUN: Uttarakhand has once again emerged as one of the safest state for senior citizens in the country in terms of crime against elderly, as per the latest data released by National Crime Record Bureau ( NCRB ).

According to NCRB 2018 report, released on Thursday, Uttarakhand is the second safest state in North India for elderly citizens, only behind Jammu & Kashmir. However, at all-India front, the Himalayan state is the seventh most secure place in the country.

Uttarakhand witnessed total six cases of crime against senior citizens in 2018, as per NCRB data .However, in 2017, Uttarakhand registered only two cases of crime against elderly people and mere one in 2016.

Among other North Indian states, Haryana recorded maximum 571 crime cases against senior citizens, followed by Uttar Pradesh with 454 cases of crime, Himachal Pradesh with 195 cases and 217 cases in Punjab. Jammu & Kashmir is the safest state in northern part of the country with only two crime cases against elderly.

Of the total six crime cases committed against senior citizens in the Himalayan state in 2018, three were of kidnapping and abduction and rest three were of murder.

It is to be noted that Maharashtra has emerged as the most unsafe state for senior citizens in the country with 5,961 cases of crime against elderly population in the state, of which 135 were murder cases.

On the other hand, Meghalaya is the safest state for senior citizens in India as the North-East state did not register even a single crime case against elderly. Other northeastern states such as Assam, Arunachal Pradesh, Manipur and Sikkim performed fairly well, compare to other states, in terms safety of senior citizens.
