Title: TDP: YSRC creating unrest among Amaravati farmers
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Former union minister for civil aviation and senior TDP leader P Ashok Gajapathi Raju on Thursday said the YSRC government was trying to create regional differences with its plan to set up three capitals in AP.

Talking to newsmen here in Vizianagaram on Thursday after launching a signature campaign and rally in support of Amaravati as capital and against the proposed shifting of capital from Amaravati to Vizag, Ashok Gajapathi Raju said that chief minister YS Jagan Mohan Reddy and a few ministers of YSRC had created tension and unrest among farmers who donated their lands for to build Amaravati. TNN

Title: CAA protest: NUJS student group takes back governor invite
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Protest by a section of students at NUJS

KOLKATA: A group of students of the West Bengal National University of Juridical Sciences ( WBNUJS ) “uninvited” Governor Jagdeep Dhankhar from a prestigious event of the university. These students are protesting against the governor’s stand on the CAA . The event, International Mock UN or MUN , starts on Friday.

According to sources, soon after Jagdeep Dhankhar came to Bengal as the governor in last August, an official invite was sent to Raj Bhavan, requesting his presence at the closing ceremony of the event as the chief guest. Raj Bhavan, sources said, had on January 6 gave its consent and subsequently sought more information to work out the logistics. This invite was “withdrawn” early on Thursday. Raj Bhavan chose not to react to the issue. TOI sent a written query to the governor, but it evoked no response. Interestingly, Trinamool Congress MP, Derek O’Brien has been invited to inaugurate the event on Friday.

Public posts on social media by a group of students, who are part of the NUJS International MUN organising committee, say explicitly why they first chose to invite the governor and then why they chose to “uninvite” him. The post mentions that the decision had been taken after a meeting of the Juridical Association — the governing body of the students’ association. This comment has got the students of the university divided because the Juridical Association categorically said there was no GB on the issue and no resolution was taken. This was confirmed to TOI by student vice-president, Akshat Kaushik.

The Association has 600 student members, of whom about 45 felt that the governor should be “uninvited”. “He had been invited at the behest of a particular student. We were excited about the invitation. Surprisingly, this student is now part of the 45-strong group which feel that the governor should not come to the NUJS campus. He has gone ahead and sent a mail to uninvite him. The students’ body is in a fix over this,” said a student.

A detailed mail sent out by this student (the same person who had sent the first mail to Raj Bhavan) indicated that though they had sent an invite to the governor, statements made by the governor in December 2019 “where inconsistent with the views and ideals of the NUJS MUN Society and the NUJS general body at large”. The student reasoned it was then Congress MPs Gaurav Gogoi and Jyotiraditya Scindia were invited to the programme to replace the governor. But this wasn’t informed to the Raj Bhavan then because the students did not get any response to their August invite till then.

Title: Muzaffarnagar: Grocery shop was front for drug business, one held
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

MUZAFFARNAGAR: A joint team of drug inspectors and police raided a grocery store which was allegedly a front for an illegal medical store selling narcotics. The shop owner, Najish Ali, 50, was arrested and a huge quantity of medicines and narcotics were seized.

As part of an ongoing crack down on drug racket in Muzaffarnagar, local police has already busted an inter-state gang that sold prohibited substance in schools and colleges in Delhi, Haryana, and west UP.

According to police sources, a team from Charthawal police station and drugs department personnel raided a shop at Niyamu village and seized drugs and banned medicines worth Rs 2 lakh.

The shop-owner had no licence for selling drugs. The hidden medical store was being run for the past two years, said police.

Sube Singh, SHO of Charthawal police station, said, “A case against the accused under various sections, including NDPC Act, has been registered. The man has been sent to jail. Further investigation is on.”

Satpal Antil, superintendent of police, said, “The raid is part of the an anti-drug drive which is being conducted since November last year.”

From November till now, more than 50 traffickers have been arrested and 114kg of drugs have been seized in 40 raids. Last year, 248 cases were registered under NDPS Act, 490 kg of narcotics were seized and 262 peddlers and traffickers arrested.

Title: Cancer shouldn’t kill your passion for life, says solo biker from Spain
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

VISAKHAPATNAM: When the future seemed blurred after having experienced two major jolts in life, Marta Valdivia, a biker from Spain realised that it was time to chase her dreams. The first jolt was when she was diagnosed with breast cancer and second when her business had to be shut down.

During her first solo biking world tour with a cause to raise awareness on cancer, Marta was on a two-day visit to the Port city to interact with the members of Women’s International Motorcycle Association (WIMA) and the other bikers of the city. Marta reached Visakhapatnam via Anantapur and left to Odisha from the city on Thursday. The 55-year-old has travelled 11 countries and covered 15,000 km already through her solo bike tour. A few of the countries include France, Italy, Bulgaria , Bosnia, Iran, Turkey and others. In India, the female biker has been through Delhi, Uttar Pradesh, Chennai, etc. The next country she plans to reach is Myanmar via West Bengal.

During her visit to the city, Marta, said, “If there is something that has remained unchanged throughout my life, it has been my passion for the motorcycle and road. After closing my companies, I decided to make my passion for the motorcycle my new way of life. But I was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2012 and when I got my mastectomy done along with chemotherapy sessions, it left me on the verge of death.”

“The burning passion of motorbiking and the diagnosis of cancer gave me a reason to chase my passion. Hence, having battled cancer, I decided to take up biking with a cause and to spread the word that cancer is not the end of life,” added Marta.

When asked about the city of destiny, Marta said that she loved the city and it felt like home.

North Spain’s geography is similar to the Port City, she pointed out. She also said that the people are very warm with great hospitality. “I would want to come back to the city and meet my fellow bikers,” she said.

“I wanted to project something for women in an environment as masculine as the motorcycle. I wanted to break the stereotypes which led to a project ‘La Motera’ (Women on wheels) that reflects on the needs of women, especially those who have made the motorcycle their means of transport, their hobby or way of life,” added Marta who rode for around 50 kms in the city covering the coastal stretch.

Title: Two blackmail health officer with video
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

The accused in police custody

Vadodara: Two persons were nabbed for blackmailing an economic inspector of Anand district health centre on Wednesday.

The two accused, Amit Barot and Jigar Barot, were demanding Rs 5 lakh from complainant Yagnesh Pavagadhi, using a video. Pavagadhi told the police that one of the accused sent him formal greetings messages on January 1 but did not identify himself.

On January 4, the accused messaged Pavagadhi that he has a video which may damage the latter’s image. He asked Pavagadhi to come to Vadodara and meet him. Pavagadhi came to Vadodara the same day, but the accused did not meet him.

Police said that they talked over phone and the accused asked him to shell off Rs 5 lakh threatening to share the video on internet otherwise. He identified himself as one ‘Brahmbhatt saheb’ over phone. Meanwhile, Pavagadhi informed Vadodara police about it and a trap was laid to nab the accused.

Pavagadhi called them to inform that he was ready to pay the money. They called him on Gotri-Sevasi road and according to the plan, Gotri police kept a watch there on Wednesday morning. As Pavagadhi reached there and met the two accused, he signalled the cops and the duo was arrested.

While the police did not divulge the details about the video, they said that Pavagadhi knew Amit as he used to frequently meet Pavagadhi when he was posted in Vadodara.

Title: Uttarakhand High court orders fresh elections of MKP College Society
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

The committee which is tasked with managing the affairs of North India's first college for women is elected by... Read More

NAINITAL: The Uttarakhand high court (HC) on Wednesday upheld the decision of the deputy registrar to dissolve the managing committee of MKP College Society and call fresh for elections.

The committee which is tasked with managing the affairs of North India’s first college for women is elected by the MKP College Society. However, the deputy registrar in 2013 said that as the society did not follow the rules and regulations of its constitution therefore the new constitution and all its activities, including election of managing committee were dissolved.

Speaking to TOI, Sashank Pandey the lawyer appearing for one of the respondents said that the MKP Society then approached the court arguing that the registrar’s decision was wrong. “However, the court upheld the decision and has now ordered the registrar to see that a fresh election for the managing committee is conducted within three months,” Pandey said.

The bench of Chief Justice Ramesh Ranganathan and Justice Alok Kumar Verma said in their order that the registrar was within his rights to reject the amendments in the constitution of the society and therefore call for fresh election. “Since the certificate of registration of the society expired on October 9, 2015, and the application for renewal of the certificate of registration of the society is still pending before the deputy registrar, we direct the deputy registrar to convene a meeting of all the members of the Society for election of the managing committee within three months,” the order read.

Title: Midday nightmare at VZM school leaves judge shocked
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Senior civil judge and secretary of District Legal Services Authority (DLSA), Vizianagaram, V Lakshmi Rajhyam expressed shock over the way in which the midday meal scheme was being implemented in the municipal high school at Cantonment area in Vizianagaram. Lakshmi Rajhyam on Thursday made a surprise visit to the school and found food material kept in the most unhygienic of places and food was prepared for only 200 students when 400 were present. She pulled up headmaster P Rama Rao and and warned of action if the school didn’t mend its ways. TNN

Title: Madras high court rejects DMK plea to videograph panchayat chief polls
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: The Madras high court has refused to entertain a PIL by DMK for a direction to the Tamil Nadu State Election Commission to videograph and audio-record the entire process of indirect election to chairperson and vice-chairperson posts in district panchayat councils and panchayat union councils to ensure free and fair elections .

When the plea moved by R Girirajan, legal wing secretary of DMK, came up for hearing, R Nedunchezhian, counsel for election commission, contended that the plea moved as a PIL cannot be entertained. He further submitted that in respect of counting for election to the posts of chairperson and vice-chairperson to district panchayat councils and panchayat union councils, CCTV cameras would be put in place for the purpose of video recording only. Even during the election to the rural local bodies, no audio recording facility was provided, he added.

Recording the submissions, a division bench of Justice M Sathyanarayanan and Justice R Hemalatha said, “This court is of the considered opinion that since the petitioner himself is said to have been aggrieved by the alleged irregularities that took place in the recently concluded phase of the local body election, the relief cannot be sought through a PIL.”

The bench then directed the registry to list the petition before the roster judge for further hearing. According to the petitioner, the indirect election to the post of chairperson and vice-chairperson is scheduled to be held on January 11.

“During the counting of votes held on January 2, many irregularities, malpractices, misuse of power and illegalities were committed by the election officials in collusion with the ruling AIADMK and in various places, even after declaration of results in favour of DMK candidates, the results were illegally changed and subsequently AIADMK candidates were declared elected,” the party said.

A similar situation may arise in the forthcoming indirect election too. Therefore, to ensure transparency, besides CCTV camera recording, the entire election process should be videographed with audio recording which shall be preserved, the petitioner said. This apart, the petitioner wanted the court to direct the commission to ensure that except the returning officer, candidates and police, others were not allowed inside polling and counting rooms.

Title: No internet in valley, volunteers across country step in to check board exam results online for Kashmiri students
Content: Dehradun: Soon after the Jammu and Kashmir State Board of School Education (JKBOSE) declared the results of class 10th on Thursday morning, Sajid Maqbool Raina from Bandipora district was at his wit’s end to find out how he had fared in his exams.“I did not know where to turn to. The board officials had earlier claimed that a printed gazette would be circulated containing the results but that never came out. Then we were told to check the result from the website, but no one had an answer on how to access the internet since we have had no net access in the valley since the past five months,” said Raina while talking to TOI over phone.This is when the Dehradun-based J&K Students’ Association came to the 17-year-old student’s rescue. A member of the association checked Raina’s result and informed him that he has scored 80 % with highest marks in science. Immediately after knowing his own result, Raina shared the helpline number with 45 other friends who also managed to know their marks from the same source.Nasir Khuehami, spokesperson of the J&K Students’ Association said that the association had helped scores of students of Kashmir valley — that is facing an internet clampdown since August 2019 — by finding out their exam results. “We have circulated among students in the valley the numbers of as many as 60 of our volunteers across the country who have checked the results of the students and shared the details with them immediately.”He claimed that “approximately 7000 students from Kashmir have been helped till now.” “We have divided responsibilities among the volunteers. While some are attending calls, others are checking the results simultaneously,” Khuehami said.Junaid Ayub, a volunteer from Dehradun, who told TOI that his team of five volunteers had checked around 1000 results till Thursday, said that calls are continuously pouring in from students anxious to know how they had fared.“It is a mixed feeling as those who have passed with good grades are ecstatic and thanking us profusely for conveying the good news while those who score badly are disconnecting the calls without uttering a word,” he said.Mehraj Hussain, a volunteer from Punjab, said that he was glad that he was engaged in a noble cause.“Class 10th is the first and the biggest result one faces in his or her academic life. I feel glad to be a part of this experience with my young Kashmiri brothers,” he said.

Title: Groom accused of unnatural sex on wedding night
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Vadodara: Her wedding night turned out to be the bride’s worst nightmare too as the groom not only displayed extreme perversion by showing her pornography on his mobile but also allegedly demanded similar acts from her.

Within days of their marriage, the Panchmahal woman lodged a complaint with Halol police against her newly-wed husband accusing him of demanding unnatural sex from her and showing her pornography on the wedding night. Halol rural police station has registered an offence and is conducting further investigations.

According to her plaint, the woman said she got married to the accused on December 13. They had an arranged marriage. After the wedding, they checked into Hotel Sarvottam in Baska near Halol in the early hours on December 14.

Here, the man allegedly forced her to see pornographic videos and photographs on his phone, she said and also accused him of forcing her to do similar acts. According to the police, pornographic acts are categorised under unnatural sex within section 377 of the Indian Penal Code. Provisions of the Information Technology Act were also added as the mobile phone was used to show the woman pornography.

Halol rural police inspector M Z Patel said that the couple checked into the hotel at around 2.30am and left early in the morning after around a couple of hours only. He added that the couple informed their relatives about the incident. According to police, the couple, who are contemplating divorce, had a long engagement period before the wedding.

On Friday evening, cops registered the offence regarding the episode at the hotel.

Title: Madras high court rejects DMK plea to videograph panchayat chief polls
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: The Madras high court has refused to entertain a PIL by DMK for a direction to the Tamil Nadu State Election Commission to videograph and audio-record the entire process of indirect election to chairperson and vice-chairperson posts in district panchayat councils and panchayat union councils to ensure free and fair elections .

When the plea moved by R Girirajan, legal wing secretary of DMK, came up for hearing, R Nedunchezhian, counsel for election commission, contended that the plea moved as a PIL cannot be entertained. He further submitted that in respect of counting for election to the posts of chairperson and vice-chairperson to district panchayat councils and panchayat union councils, CCTV cameras would be put in place for the purpose of video recording only. Even during the election to the rural local bodies, no audio recording facility was provided, he added.

Recording the submissions, a division bench of Justice M Sathyanarayanan and Justice R Hemalatha said, “This court is of the considered opinion that since the petitioner himself is said to have been aggrieved by the alleged irregularities that took place in the recently concluded phase of the local body election, the relief cannot be sought through a PIL.”

The bench then directed the registry to list the petition before the roster judge for further hearing. According to the petitioner, the indirect election to the post of chairperson and vice-chairperson is scheduled to be held on January 11.

“During the counting of votes held on January 2, many irregularities, malpractices, misuse of power and illegalities were committed by the election officials in collusion with the ruling AIADMK and in various places, even after declaration of results in favour of DMK candidates, the results were illegally changed and subsequently AIADMK candidates were declared elected,” the party said.

A similar situation may arise in the forthcoming indirect election too. Therefore, to ensure transparency, besides CCTV camera recording, the entire election process should be videographed with audio recording which shall be preserved, the petitioner said. This apart, the petitioner wanted the court to direct the commission to ensure that except the returning officer, candidates and police, others were not allowed inside polling and counting rooms.

Title: Junked laws are still part of syllabus, say Osmania University students
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

SECUNDERABAD: Final year law students of Osmania University (OU) raised concerns over LLB syllabus on Thursday claiming that it continues to have laws that were either amended or were repealed in the recent past.

Questions over the syllabus were raised during the recent semester exams conducted by the university. In the criminal procedure code law of juvenile justice and probations of offenders’ paper, students were asked to write a brief note on the salient features of Juvenile Justice Act, 2000, which was repealed by the Parliament in 2015. “Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2015 came into force from January 15, 2016. But still, OU is making us study the repealed Act instead of the 2015 Act. Why are we asked to study a 20-year-old law which was repealed five years ago?” asked Alluri Divakar Reddy , a student of Pendakanti Law College, who wrote a letter to the in-charge vice-chancellor seeking revision of the syllabus.

Students claim that despite revising the LLB syllabus in 2017, the university failed to add the new JJ Act, 2015 by removing the repealed Act of 2000, and added that Consumer Protection Act, 2019 was also passed by the Parliament repealing the Consumer Protection Act, 1986. Following the semester exams, students demanded that there are many laws which were amended in the Parliament over the last two years.

“We are close to 10,000 law students who are studying the same old syllabus prescribed by the university. The university must revise the syllabus in the next academic year and make the necessary amendments,” said a student.

When TOI contacted GB Reddy, dean, faculty of law at University College of Law, OU, he said that the syllabus is revised once in every three years. “It is true that several amendments were made to many enactments in 2018 and 2019. These recent changes are so numerous and drastic in certain cases that it is difficult even for practicing lawyers to comprehend,” said Reddy. Reddy said the varsity will try to incorporate the changes during the next immediate revision in 2020. “However, the teachers concerned must be up-to-date with these changes and the examiners also must ensure the same while examining the students,” he added.

Title: Swachh stats ‘whistleblower’ sacked from Gwalior civic body
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Bhopal: A computer operator of Gwalior Municipal Corporation — who had alleged flaws in the performance audit of various cities in Madhya Pradesh during Swachh Survekshan 2019 and sought an inquiry by Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s office — has been terminated from service on charges of ‘conspiring against a government department’.

Various associations in Gwalior have registered protest and have submitted memorandums to revoke the termination of Sandeep Sharma.

Sharma claims he has been targeted for speaking up against wrongdoings. “They initially asked me to ‘work together’, but when I raised objections against bogus inputs (for the Swachh survey), I was removed,” Sharma told TOI, adding he plans to move Supreme Court for an inquiry into the technical evaluation of Swachh Survekshan.

Sharma’s termination order says he has violated civil services rules by misusing his official position and “creating a confused relationship between state and the central government”. It accuses Sharma of moving court without the state government’s permission, that too by submitting documents that he was not authorised to access. “This act falls in the category of grave indiscipline. Since he has submitted unauthorised documents in court with false accusations and complained against senior officers at various platforms,” reads the order, signed by Gwalior municipal commissioner Sandeep Kumar Makin.

This officer could not be contacted for his version despite several attempts.

A few days ago, Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s office had ordered an inquiry into Sharma’s complaint that data was fudged in evaluating performances of cities in Madhya Pradesh during Swachh Survekshan. The ministry of housing and urban affairs was asked to investigate.

Sharma claims to be in possession of documents and data analysis reports to prove that facts and figures were distorted by consulting agencies in connivance with a section of officials of the urban administration. He says Gwalior was placed 32nd despite the outstanding work by its municipality to keep the city clean. “Gwalior is being counted among the dirtiest cities in the country because false data was submitted and this should be exposed,” Sharma says, adding that survey companies are paid in crores from public money, so he has every right to challenge their work.

Madhya Pradesh won the best performing state award for solid waste management in the 2019 survey in terms of door-to-door garbage collection, segregation, recycling, and composting. In 2018, MP was certified the first in the country to achieve 100% door-to-door garbage collection. And in 2017, all urban areas of the state were declared ODF with construction of 4.80 lakh household toilets.

“Gwalior performed better than many other cities under Swachh Bharat Mission (Urban), but false data management by agencies led to its defeat in the 2019 survey. It was downgraded in comparison to Indore, Bhopal, Ujjain, Jabalpur, Chhindwara, Neemuch, Peethampur, Devas, Singrauli and Khargon,” Sharma had alleged in his complaint to PMO.

Gwalior scored only 200 out of 500, whereas Singrauli got 500 despite applying with similar documents, he claims, alleging that data was generated without physical verification. “I have requested the PMO to conduct a fair and impartial inquiry and constitute a committee for proper assessment of ranking,” Sharma added.

Eight cities of MP — Indore Ujjain, Dewas, Bhopal, Khargone, Nagda, Singrauli, and Jabalpur — figured among the top 25 cleanest cities of India in the last survey. Indore was #1, while Bhopal slipped from second place to 19th. Ujjain was adjudged cleanest medium city (population 3-10 lakh). The ministry of urban affairs has been conducting Swachh Survekshan every year since 2016 to evaluate cities on cleanliness standards.

Title: Snowfall a boon for tourists, a bain for locals in Nainital
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

The heavy snowfall on Wednesday night brought joys for tourists who had come to Nainital after predictions of... Read More

NAINITAL/ALMORA/PITHORAGARH: The heavy snowfall on Wednesday night brought joys for tourists who had come to Nainital after predictions of heavy snowfall. While much of the Mall Road was covered in snow after it started snowing on Wednesday evening and continued till midnight, places such as Naina Devi temple, Kilbury Road, Snow View Point and many other locations were also draped in snow.

Kautibh Roy, a tourist from Kolkata said that he and his family were finally happy to see the snow draped hill station. “We have been to Nainital many times but it’s the first time that we saw snowfall. My family was out on the Mall Road till midnight enjoying the snowfall,” he said. Tourists said they were finally happy to see snow for which they had travelled from Kolkata.

However, as the tourists were happy with the season’s heaviest snowfall in Nainital, local residents were badly affected since most of the roads were blocked and cars couldn’t even move. Those who had to travel remained stuck in their homes and power supply which was cut off on Wednesday night around 9 remained so till late afternoon on Thursday. “I had to go to Ghaziabad for official work but I can’t since my car is stuck in snow and the road downhill is too slippery,” Ranjan Sah, a resident of the Zila Panchayat Road. The snowfall and the rush of tourists also led to traffic snarls at many locations. Though the Mall Road was free of jams, Haldwani-Nainital Road saw much traffic and cars were stopped at Rusi Bypass. “As a preventive measure, we had to stop the movement of private vehicles beyond Rusi bypass due to tourist rush and the threat of accident due to snow,” said Nainital circle officer Vijay Thapa.

Meanwhile, due to the heavy snowfall and extreme cold on Wednesday, a person died in Artola area of Almora district . Revenue police officers said that they had received information of a person being buried under snow in the morning. “The deceased has been identified as Kishan Singh, 45, a resident of Bajgaon village,” said Gopal Singh Bisht, revenue sub inspector.Incidentally, a dozen roads in Almora and Bageshwar districts were blocked following heavy snowfall on Wednesday. Power supply is also reported to be disrupted at several places.

The Almora disaster management department said that Almora-Ghat Motor Road was closed near Panuwanula area and among other roads blocked were Suvakhan-Daram-Chalinchina, Artola-Jageshwar and Panuvanula-old Jageshwar motorway.

Rakesh Joshi, Almora district disaster management officer, said, “PWD and disaster management teams are working together to open the roads at the earliest. All roads have been opened, except Kafadkhan-Binsar Motor Road.”

Heavy snowfall also disrupted normal life in Pithoragarh district . Heavy snowfall on Thrusday night cut off Munsyari from the district headquarters in Pithoragarh. Apart from that, five other roads are also blocked in the district.

Title: BJP slams Digvijaya Singh for anti-RSS remarks
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

BHOPAL: BJP on Thursday attacked senior Congress leader Digvijaya Singh for his remarks against RSS, saying he has been exposed as a “pseudo Hindu”.

“Digvijaya could see terrorism in ‘bhagwa’ (saffron), but not in madrasas. Saraswati Shishu Mandirs do not need a certificate from Digvijaya Singh. The Congress leader is blind to terrorism that emanates from madrasas. He shares the same platform with those who oppose Vande Mataram, use ‘ji’ as honorific for terrorists such as Osama bin Laden and Hafiz Saeed,” said BJP MLA from Huzur, Rameshwar Sharma.

On Wednesday, the Congress stalwart had called RSS a “fascist organization imbibed in the ideologies of Hitler and Mussolini”, and said it “cannot be accepted as an organisation of Hindus”. “Saraswati Shishu Mandirs are schools where hatred is taught, which gives birth to violence. And violence gives birth to terrorism,” he had said.

Outraged, Sharma said: “In Saraswati Shishu Mandirs, children are taught to respect the national song, Vande Mataram, and the Tricolour. Digvijaya has no problem with madrasas, where Vande Mataram is opposed. He is the person who had coined the term ‘bhagwa’ terrorism.”

Title: GMR-ESR JV to set up logistics park at Hyderabad airport city
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Hyderabad: GMR Infrastructure Ltd on Thursday informed the bourses that its step-down subsidiary, GMR Hyderabad Aerotropolis Limited (GHAL), has entered into a joint venture with ESR Hyderabad 1 Pte Limited (ESR), a subsidiary of Hong Kong-headquartered ESR Cayman Limited, to develop a logistics and industrial park at the Hyderabad airport city.

The park, which is proposed to be developed over 66 acres at a project outlay of Rs 550 crore, will be developed by a special purpose vehicle, GMR Logistics Park Private Limited, in which ESR and GHAL will hold 70% and 30% stake, respectively. GHAL is a subsidiary of GHIAL, which operates the Rajiv Gandhi International Airport at Shamshabad, Hyderabad.

GMR group said in a regulatory filing that the JV will develop a flagship airport centric logistics and industrial park with state-of-the-art facilities for warehousing, distribution centers and non-polluting industrial units such as light assembly facilities.

ESR India country heads Abhijit Malkani and Jai Mirpuri said the collaboration reiterates ESR’s strategic mission to strengthen its facilities and key positions across the country.

“This new facility at Hyderabad Airport is our latest investment to support national and global trade to and from Telangana. Being strategically located, this facility, showcasing smart, sustainable and human-centric design, will pave way for Indian and global companies to capitalize on the immense growth opportunities available in the Indian market,” Malkani said.

Aman Kapoor, CEO-Airport Land Development, GMR Group, said “This collaboration will set new standards for the warehousing and industrial real estate sector and will also benefit the burgeoning cargo industry in the region.”

GMR Group, which also runs the Indira Gandhi International Airport in New Delhi and has bagged the Mopa project in Goa, is developing unique airport cities on the commercial land available around these three airports.

ESR, which has been co-founded by Warburg Pincus, claims to be the largest Asia-Pacific focused logistics real estate platform by gross floor area (GFA), value of assets owned directly and by funds and investment vehicles it manages. It has a presence in China, Japan, South Korea, Singapore, Australia and India.

Title: Chennai: Watch out for this death trap along busy Koyambedu road
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Pedestrians are the worst hit due to the dug up road opposite Koyambedu bus terminus

CHENNAI: If you plan to use the road opposite Koyambedu bus terminus , perhaps you should think twice. For, chances of an accidental fall into a trench dug by the electricity board along the choked road are rather high. A recent visit to the spot by TOI revealed that pedestrians, in particular, are put to a lot of hardship on the dug-up stretch. S Sundaresan, a resident of Arihant Towers, said the trench was dug by the electricity board about 10 days ago. The excavated soil was dumped along the pavement and was made to resemble an embankment perhaps to prevent accidental falls into the pit. Senior citizens, women and children among others find it extremely difficult to walk on the road as the trench has been dug for more than half a kilometre, he said. Adding to the trouble, protruding iron rods from a flyover that is coming up on the stretch pose another threat to pedestrians. This makes almost the entire stretch unsafe for pedestrians and motorists. Vehicles from Tirumangalam heading towards Vadapalani zip along the road, exposing pedestrians to accidents as well. A senior traffic police officer said the electricity board claimed the trench will be covered and the road laid properly by Monday. However, it has been stuck due to a delay in the arrival of cables that need to be laid on the stretch. Due to the trench, traffic from Tirumangalam moves at a snail’s pace. The road from near Koyambedu-CMBT signal up to Jayapushpam hotel has become narrow due to this. “We have been urging the electricity board officials to cover the trench at the earliest,” the officer said. When contacted, TamilNadu Transmission Corporation Limited (Tantransco) officials said the work is part of a 110-KV transmission line being laid between Koyambedu and Kodambakkam. “The work will be completed mostly before Pongal or a week after that. The line will carry high tension power to Kodambakkam sub-station in order to provide quality power to the residents,” an official said.
