Working under senior officers like Ashish Bhatia and Abhay Chudasama, Shukla was instrumental in ferreting out and arresting terrorists of Indian Mujaheedin involved in the bomb blasts executed in Ahmedabad on July 26, 2008.After serving for five years in the crime branch, Shukla was posted as SP, operations, Gujarat ATS. After joining ATS he has continued to draw praise by detecting one case after another. In February 2019, Shukla was promoted to the position of DIG, ATS.

Title: Very few movies speak about societal issues: Lenin Bharathi
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Trichy: Hinting that cinema is responsible for most of the sexual harassment incidents against women in the society, Tamil film director and script writer Lenin Bharathi has said that very few movies speak about societal issues.

He was addressing a students’ gathering at Holy Cross College (HCC) in Trichy on Thursday on ‘social media and women related issues’ as part of a two-day international conference on ‘Social media: Issues and challenges’.

Speaking on the negative portrayal of women in movies, he asked young women to stop enjoying their negative projection onscreen and watch movies with self-respect. They should not hesitate to boycott a movie if it doesn’t do justice in terms of gender equality.

Saying that women are the most under-privileged section in the society even in the present era, he asked them to be conscious and leave movies in the cinemas. Most of the movies are keeping people in imaginary dream world away from societal reality, he said.

We may think that cinema may not impact our imagination, but it affects our thought process and even develop complex among many who are obese, bald or even dark skin, he said.

Social media platforms lack basic ethics and operate with the basic objective of keeping people engaged by making trivial incidents. Make effective use of your time instead of falling victim to online media, which is feeding information every minute.

Title: Nilgiris misses winter to erratic, extended rainfall
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Udhagamandalam: The erratic rainfall pattern in 2019 has delayed the onset of winter season in the Nilgiris. While monsoon showers were scarce until July in the last year, the hill retreat received heavy rain in August, September and October. And the rainfall recorded was more than the double the district received in the corresponding months in 2018.

The rainfall was, however, not proportional across the district. Some locations recorded heavy rain, while the intensity was low in other places. According to horticulture department officials, the unusual heavy downpour during the three months has delayed the onset of winter season.

However, the delayed winter season has benefitted the tea plantations as they won’t be affected by frost. Normally, temperature would dip to 2Celsius to 3Celsius in December and the first week of January. But the minimum temperature registered in the past three weeks in Ooty was 7Celsius. The temperature had on Wednesday night dipped to 2Celsius, the lowest till date.

Shiva Subramaniam Samraj, joint director, horticulture department, told TOI, “The rainfall pattern was very erratic last year. The southwest monsoon was a failure, but the months of August, September and October recorded around 100% more rain than the corresponding months in 2018.”

Pointing out that the rainfall was location-specific in the district in 2019, the official said, “While Avalanche received more than 800mm rainfall on August 8, Ooty and surroundings recorded only 70mm-90mm. Most of the agriculture fields in low-lying areas were severely affected due to floods, which also claimed human lives.”

According to him, the district last year missed the autumn season, when tourist inflow is usually high. “The extended rain till October has ultimately affected the winter season. There has been no report of frost in the district till date this year,” Samraj said.

He said the frost-free December had benefitted the small tea farmers who realized a good yield.

Viswanathan, president, Nilgiris Farmers’ Association, said, “Vegetable growers faced a huge loss owing to the heavy rains in August and September last year. Most of the fields with standing crops were damaged. However, the delayed winter has now helped the tea gardens.”

He, however, said the district could expect severe winter anytime till February 15.

Title: Private tutor held under POCSO Act
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Pune: A 29-year-old private tutor was arrested on Wednesday for outraging the modesty of his 13-year-old student.

An officer from the Chatushrungi police said the action was taken after the minor girl’s mother lodged an FIR with them.

“The incident occurred on Tuesday afternoon. The girl’s mother told us that the tutor used lewd language while addressing the minor in one of his classes. She also alleged that the man inappropriately touched her daughter,” the officer said. The tutor was arrested under the relevant sections of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act.

In a separate incident, the Koregaon Park police on Wednesday launched a search for a man who allegedly outraged the modesty of an 11-year-old girl on December 29, last year. The girl’s mother lodged an FIR on Wednesday.

Title: Godinho, Dhavalikar trade barbs
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Porvorim: At the Legislators’ Day event, panchayats minister Mauvin Godinho exchanged a sharp repartee with former PWD minister Ramakrishna Dhavalikar, on the move by the 10 Congress MLAs to join BJP. “They did not join for selfish reasons, but for development in their constituencies,” he said. To this, the MGP MLA questioned whether Godinho was in favour of horse-trading and defection. Godinho shot back that it was not the fault of the MLAs. “You also know about how much work people wanted to be done when you were in power. I extend my sympathies to you today because once upon a time I was sitting in your place,” he said.

Title: Salem: Widow sells her hair for Rs 150 to feed 3 kids
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Prema and her husband Selvam were working in a brick kiln, before he decided to set up a business with Rs 2.5 ... Read More

SALEM: A 31-year-old woman, neck deep in debt left behind by her husband who committed suicide seven months ago, sold her hair to feed her children.

On Friday last, Prema, widow of Selvam had run out of the last penny she had. With three children, aged five, three and two years, by her side in hunger, Prema approached every person she knew seeking money. But none of her neighbours or relatives would part with cash on a Friday, an auspicious day.

That’s when a man passed through her street in Ponnamapet offering to buy hair to make wigs. Without a moment’s thought, Prema rushed inside her hut, chopped off her hair and sold it for Rs 150 with which she bought food for Rs 100. Then she went to a shop and asked for a bottle of insecticide. The shopkeeper sensed something amiss and refused to sell her.

“She then attempted to consume poisonous arali seeds (nerium oleander). Fortunately, her sister stopped her from consuming it,’’ said G Bala, a graphic designer who posted Prema’s plight on social media and eventually helped her crowd fund financial support.

Prema and her late husband Selvam were working as daily wagers in a brick kiln. Selvam wanted to set up a small business of his own and borrowed money to the tune of Rs 2.5 lakh. But he was cheated by people and eventually the family slipped into deep penury forcing him to commit suicide. Shattered by husband’s death, hounded by those who lent money and saddened by suffering of children, she decided to end life.

A week later, now Prema is a new woman. Thanks to Bala’s post, several good Samaritans offered help and she managed to collect Rs 1.45 lakh. On Thursday, the Salem district administration also sanctioned her monthly widow pension. Bala’s friend Prabhu who runs a brick kiln has also given her a job.

So regained confidence so much so that she asked Bala to remove his Facebook post seeking help for her. “I am so overwhelmed by the support of people. I will never even think of committing suicide again. I want to give a good education to my children and take them out of this penury,’’ says Prema.

What changed her was not just the help that poured in but Bala’s advise too, as they were not just textbook motivational speech but his own life experience strikingly similar to that of Prema. When he was a child Bala’s family too was in penury and his mother once attempted suicide. “One day we never had any money left for food. My mother sold all the old newspapers and with Rs 4 she got, bought rice and cooked it for us. Soon after she tried to commit suicide, but relatives saved her,’’ recalled Bala.

“I told Prema that if my mother had died that day she wouldn’t be here now to go around in her son’s car,’’ Bala said.

Title: MLC, 15 co-op bank office-bearers booked for Rs 71 crore fraud
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The city police have booked sitting MLC Anil Bhosale and 15 other office-bearers of Shivajirao Bhosale Cooperative Bank Limited here for an alleged economic fraud of Rs71.78 crore involving the bank’s funds.

Bhosale is the chairman of the bank. His wife Reshma, a sitting corporator, and the bank’s chief executive officer Tanaji Dattu Padwal are among those booked for the offence.

The fraud is suspected to have been committed during the financial year 2018-19 and came to the fore during an audit by a statutory auditor assigned in May last year by the Reserve Bank of India.

“All 16 office-bearers face charges of misappropriating Rs71.78 crore by way of fudging entries in the bank’s cash balance records and siphoning off the amount to some other account for their personal benefit,” deputy commissioner of police (economic offences wing) Sambhaji Kadam told TOI.

“The RBI has been monitoring the bank’s functioning and has appointed an administrator to look into its daily affairs. We have kept open the option of arresting those booked at an appropriate time during our probe,” Kadam said.

The case has been transferred to the economic offences wing for investigation after chartered accountant and statutory auditor Yogesh Rajgopal Lakade lodged a formal FIR with the Shivajinagar police on Wednesday night.

When contacted, Anil Bhosale told TOI, “We will give all replies to the investigating agencies and whoever calls us for any inquiry in relation to the complaint that formed the basis for the FIR against us.”

On whether he would contest his or any of the other office-bearers’ involvement in the matter, Bhosale insisted that all answers will be given to the relevant investigating authorities.

TOI on Thursday visited the bank’s head office in Shivajinagar but found it closed. Some officials sitting nearby refused to comment.

Lakade has stated in the FIR that an RBI-appointed scrutiny panel had told the bank’s head office to provide the cash records for verification, but the latter failed to act on it. The scrutiny panel had come across certain discrepancies in the bank’s cash register and the computer system and the bank was unable to explain it properly, the FIR stated.

Consequently, on May 16, 2019, the RBI assigned Lakade’s statutory auditor firm, Torvi Pethe and Company, to conduct an audit of the cash records of the bank’s head office and all other branches, the FIR added.

The audit revealed a shortfall of Rs71.78 crore funds in the cash register of the bank’s head office, the FIR said, adding that the auditor intimated it to the office of the district special auditor in the state department of cooperatives.

A special supplementary audit was conducted in November last year, following which the district special auditor authorised Lakade’s firm on November 14, 2019, to register a case, the FIR stated.

Mihir Thatte of Punekar Nagarik Kruti Samiti and a few other account holders of the bank told TOI, “We have reasons to believe that the amount of misappropriation is more than what has been mentioned in the complaint. We will fight against the alleged corrupt activity and will knock on the doors of the state government, seeking justice for all depositors of the bank.”

For now, the police have invoked offences under sections 406 (criminal breach of trust), 408 (criminal breach of trust by clerk or servant), 409 (criminal breach of trust by public servant, or by banker, merchant or agent), 420 (cheating), 467 (forgery), 471 (using as genuine a forged) and 34 (common intention) of Indian Penal Code against the 16 office bearers.

A senior police officer told TOI, “As the amount of the fraud may increase during the course of investigation, we have decided to employ the services of a forensic auditor to establish the money trail.”

Title: Temperature level dips to season’s lowest at 10.3C
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Nashik: The city recorded a sudden drop of 5.8 degrees celsius in the minimum temperature of the city on Thursday. At 10.2 degrees celsius, the city recorded the season’s lowest minimum temperature as against 16 degrees celsius on Wednesday. The previous lowest temperature was recorded on January 1 at 10.3 degree Celsius.

The minimum temperature rose to 14 degrees celsius on Tuesday and 16 degrees celsius on Wednesday. On Wednesday and Thursday, Nashik recorded maximum temperature of 26.5 and 25.4 degrees celsius respectively. “It was warm throughout Wednesday but it suddenly became cold on Thursday. I had put away my woollens for the past two three days but took them out again as it got cold,” said Bhusan Gavande, a resident of Nashik.

The district’sNiphad taluka, which is known as the grape-growing belt, recorded the season’s lowest temperature at 8 degrees celsius on Thursday. According to the Mahatma Phule Krishi Vidyapeeth, Rahuri, this is the lowest temperature recorded in Niphad this season as against the previous lowest temperature of 9 degrees celsius on Sunday. “Rainfall continued till the end of October this year leading to humidity in the soil. There have also been variations in the climate: Sometimes it is cloudy and sometimes it is dry. This is why minimum temperature has been fluctuating,” said an official from the weather station of Mahatma of the Phule Krishi Vidyapeeth.

The drop in temperature, meanwhile, has led to concerns that grapes may be affected. “The minimum temperature was in the range of 10 to 12 degree celsius for the past few days, but it suddenly became cold on Thursday. The fruit may crack if the temperature goes below 5 degrees celsius. Low temperature also affects the growth of the fruit,” said cultivator Arvind Bhosle. Meanwhile, Jalgaon city recorded minimum and maximum temperature at 13.6 degree celsius and 25.5 degree celsius, respectively. Malegaon recorded minimum and maximum temperature at 12.4 and 23.2 degrees celsius respectively.

Title: Hsg societies can lease out collector land sans fresh nod
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Over 20,000 housing societies in the state, especially in the city, Mumbai, Thane and Nashik , granted collector’s land have been given the leeway of leasing it out without fresh permission.The Sena-NCP-Cong government issued an order in this regard on January 7 to reduce bureaucratic delays, clear confusion among residents of such housing societies and allow short-term lease of land without any fee and fresh permission. A senior revenue official, however, said the leave and licence agreements would have to be registered with the registration department.“There was confusion among these housing societies on the registration of lease agreements and sale of land. So, we decided to clear the confusion and ease the trouble of society members making rounds of the office of the collector concerned,” he said.Collector’s land was granted to various housing societies across the state between 1960 and 70. Many were using it as amenity space, while some constructed structures on it.Last year, the erstwhile cabinet had cleared the proposal to convert the collector’s land to freehold land against a premium — 15% of the ready reckoner rate. Now, the present government has given its nod to lease out collector’s land without fresh permission.Housing society federations’ members feel the move would give them relief from visiting the office of the collector concerned to seek permission every time the lease term got over.Suhas Patwardhan, who represents the housing federation in the state and the district, said easing the rules would benefit these societies. “It will ensure that they can lease out the land without any further permission as well as ensure lease agreements,” he said. Many old housing societies would benefit from the new initiative, he added.President of Real Estate Agents Sachin Shingavi said with no additional fee being charged for permission to lease out land, housing societies would take the necessary steps to register the lease agreements with the registration department. “It is a win-win situation for citizens from these housing societies as well as the government,” he said.

Title: ‘He was in touch with three ISIS men’
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Zafar Ali wil be handed over to the special cell of Delhi police

AHMEDABAD: Gujarat Anti-Terrorism Squad (ATS) on Thursday nabbed an alleged operative of international militant group Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS) from Gorva area of Vadodara city. The ATS officials said that he had come to Gujarat to radicalise youths in Jambusar in Bharuch and establish an ISIS module locally.

According to official statement by Gujarat ATS, the alleged ISIS operative has been identified as Zafar Ali Mohammed Haliq, a 25-year-old resident of Cuddalore district in Tamil Nadu. He was nabbed from Panchvati circle in Gorva in a joint operation of the ATS and Vadodara police.

Officials said that fake IDs were found on Ali. "The fake IDs name him as Abdul Rahim," said an ATS official who, however, conceded that no material linking him to ISIS or weapon was found on the suspect.

Zafar Ali had come to Vadodara from Cuddalore to attempt to establish new module of ISIS in the state. He is alleged to be in touch with three alleged ISIS operatives who were held by special cell of Delhi police on Thursday. Zafar Ali was also involved in setting up a module in Tamil Nadu, said ATS officials.

The Gujarat ATS action followed an intelligence input by sister agencies that six Tamil Nadu residents, wanted in serious crimes like murders, had absconded from their respective native places.

“The intelligence inputs indicated that the six absconding men were talking about conducting Jihadi activities at some unknown place. They were inspired by the ISIS and were Islamic extremists. There was a high probability that they could plan terror activity in the country,” said the ATS statement.

Following this, Gujarat ATS officials activated their network in different places and found that one such person was hiding in Vadodara. On the basis of specific inputs, a team of Gujarat ATS and Vadodara police traced at Gorva in Vadodara and nabbed him.

Zafar Ali would be handed over to the special cell of Delhi police for further legal procedure.

Title: Central prison starts sale of soaps made by inmates
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Trichy: Trichy Central prison has commenced the sale of bathing soaps manufactured by the inmates. The soaps come in a range of fragrances and varieties. The prison DIG inaugurated the sale of the soaps to the public here on Thursday. Prison superintendent K Shankar, and prison bazaar superintendent Thirumurugan were also present during the event.

Offers have also been announced for customers, who purchase the soaps in bulk, prison authorities said. The initiative is in line with the drive carried out by prison authorities to sell various products manufactured by the inmates to the public. The initiative is expected to help rehabilitate the prisoners, especially the ones serving lengthy terms.

Th hand-made bathing soaps come in four fragrances-lavender, rose, jasmine, lemon. The soaps also come in three varieties whereby the normal variety costs Rs 16 each while the oil-free variety is priced at Rs 40 and the glycerine bathing soaps cost Rs 56. There is also an offer to buy two glycerine soaps for Rs 100, the prison officials said. The price of detergent soaps has been fixed as Rs 10.

The soaps are available in 100 and 150 gram varieties. The prison inmates have already been running a restaurant, a cake and a sweet shop under one roof named as Prison Bazaar. They have also been selling cloth bags, which are a substitute for plastic bags, air purifier bags, which produce vapours that freshen the air in addition to a tailoring unit functioning inside the prison. Prison bazaar is located in front of the prison on Trichy-Pudukottai main road in the city.

Title: Andhra Pradesh accounts for 10% of all human trafficking crimes in India
Content:
Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: Andhra Pradesh stands second in the country in terms of the most number of women being trafficked for sexual exploitation, according to the National Crime Records Bureau 2018 data released on Thursday. The state also ranks fifth in terms of overall human trafficking cases in India.The NCRB data reveals that AP has a poor record in terms of disposing cases of human trafficking. The conviction rate stands at only 11.4%. Overall, the state saw 367 people being trafficked during 2018. Of them, 266 are women. The state accounts for 9.7% of India’s human trafficking crime. Interestingly, Telangana accounts for 9.8% of the country’s human trafficking offences.The data has vindicated many studies conducted by NGOs that showed how human traffickers walk scot free in the state. Only 48 people have been convicted while 484 accused were acquitted. Overall, Andhra Pradesh saw around 2.2% increase in crime rate in 2018 compared to 2017. However, if one sees the crime rate in terms of IPC offences alone, there has been a four percent decrease in the crime incident.The state with 61 cases stands third in cases of abuse in shelter homes. Only UP and Maharashtra are ahead of AP.The special and local laws (SLL) cases, which are purely based on the suo moto enforcement by the police, saw a 15% increase. AP accounts for less than one percent of the entire country’s crime rate in 2018. Conversely in 2017 NCRB data which was released in October, 2018 shows the state accounting or 4.3% of the overall crime rate in India.Andhra Pradesh continues to perform in a dismal manner in terms of crimes against SCs and STs. It ranks 5th in the country and No. 1 in South India when it comes to poor conviction rate.The state saw a healthy 8% decrease in crimes against senior citizens. However, it continues to account for 6.9% of the crimes against senior citizens in the country.The crime against women also saw a marginal five percent increase. In terms of rape cases, around 578 rape cases were reported. Of them, 79 women were repeatedly raped by the same accused. About 81 of them happen to be custodial rapes within the same family. Three police personnel too were booked for raping women . The state saw a marginal increase in the number of murder cases too by 2%.

Title: Scada meter project hits a roadblock
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Nashik: The Nashik Municipal Smart City Development Corporation Ltd’s (NMSCDCL) plan to install water meters in all households and commercial establishments in the city have apparently hit a roadblock .

While corporators are insisting that installation of the water meters should be carried out simultaneously across the city, the NMSCDCL wants to undertake the project in phases.

“Around 50% of the total water meters are defunct. We want to replace these existing meters with new Scada metres, but the project is yet to be worked out. We are currently issuing average water tax bills to the residents,” an NMC official said.

The corporators, however, are opposing the NMSCDCL’s plan. Mayor Satish Kulkarni, who is also the director of NMSCDCL, said the issue will be discussed during the upcoming board meeting of NMSCDCL.

There are around 1.85 lakh water connections in the city. “It is wrong if 50% of the total water meters are lying defunct in the city. It is a loss to both Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) and water tax payers. I will soon hold a meeting with the officials from the water supply department on the issue and take proper measures in this regard,” Kulkarni said.

“Last month was my first meeting of the smart city board after taking over as its director, but it was adjourned. The next meeting will be held by the end of this month during which will take up the issue of Scada water meter project,” he added.

Last year in July, the NMSCDCL had cancelled the tender process for the Rs 300 crore Scada (Supervisory control and data acquisition) water meter project after allegations that the installation process was purposely being carried out in phases to benefit some contractors.

BJP leaders and some directors of smart city had alleged financial irregularities in Scada water metre project and had also strongly criticised the smart city officials.

Following this, NMSCDCL chairman Kunte had directed the smart city officials to cancel the tender process. The new water meters are to be replaced with the existing ones at homes, hotels and other commercial establishments.

The total network of water pipeline in the city is of 2,100-km. Currently, the non-revenue water (NRW) losses owing to water leakages and theft is around 45% of the total supply.

The Scada project will monior water supply from start point (water filtration plant) to end users (consumers). As part of this, the existing meters are to be replaced with Scada metre. The objective of the Scada water meter project was to keep a check on non-revenue water.

Title: ‘Tiger killings conspiracy to wipe out wildlife sanctuary’
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

The ‘Save Mhadei, Save Goa’ campaign is led by opposition parties and activists against the diversion of the r... Read More

PANAJI: Calling chief minister Pramod Sawant “a failure on all fronts”, a united front of all opposition parties, including Congress, GFP, MGP and Shiv Sena on Thursday said he should resign, taking responsibility for the death of four tigers in Goa’s forest in Sattari taluka. “It is our apprehension that the killings could be a conspiracy to eventually change the status of the Mhadei Wildlife Sanctuary and to use the land for other purposes,” said the opposition parties that have come together to organise a movement called ‘Save Mhadei, Save Goa’, to agitate against the diversion of the Mhadei’s water to Karnataka .

“The central government committee, which has been formed to investigate deaths of the four tigers, should also nail those who failed to protect the tigers. What were the CM and the principal conservator of forests doing? It is their job,” said Hrudaynath Shirodkar of the Progressive Front of Goa. “The government now wants to relocate forest dwellers from the Mhadei Wildlife Sanctuary, stating that it has caused the man-animal conflict and led to the poisoning of the tigers. But the government refuses to stop hosting Sunburn in Goa inspite of three deaths. The government is only hitting at the disadvantaged,” he remarked.

Narayan Sawant of MGP said that the government first misled the people of Goa on the diversion of Mhadei water to Karnataka, and now has failed to protect the state’s wildlife.“We have not just lost our Mhadei, but also her children, the tigers. It is a conspiracy to finish off the existence of the Mhadei Wildlife Sanctuary. If there is no wildlife, there will be no sanctuary. Tomorrow we may hear of the CM having an interest in land in the sanctuary area,” said Ravi Harmalkar of the voluntary organisation ‘Yuva Goa’.

He said the forest-dwellers were illiterate and may not be aware of the importance of certain wildlife to the ecology. “Forest officials have failed in counselling them appropriately,” he added.The front also demanded that a body of Goa’s wildlife conservationists be formed to save any further damage to the state’s wildlife.

Title: Lawyer: No evidence to keep DSK’s kin in custody
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Defence lawyer Sushilkumar Pise argued on Thursday that there was no strong evidence against Anuradha Purandare, sister-in-law of jailed developer DS Kulkarni (DSK) and a co-accused in the alleged Rs 2,091.11-crore economic fraud by the DSK group, to justify her detention in custody.

Pise, while arguing for Purandare’s bail before special MPID judge Jayant Raje, submitted that his client had been arraigned in the case merely on account of her being the sister of DSK’s wife. This is Purandare’s first bail plea after the filing of chargesheet in the case.

Among other things, Pise argued for bail on the grounds of parity with DSK’s chartered accountant and statutory auditor who has been granted bail on a previous occasion. Besides, he cited the applicant’s old age and her ailing husband’s health condition as grounds for bail.

In a related development, lawyer Rohan Nahar, who is appearing for DSK’s chief engineer Rajiv Newaskar, furnished an application seeking the court’s direction to the authorities to furnish copies of all the documents, which police have submitted with the chargesheet, to enable him argue his client’s case for a discharge from the case.

In Purandare’s case, special public prosecutor Pravin Chavan has already submitted a 30-page written submission opposing her bail plea, stating that she may influence witnesses and tamper with evidence if released on bail.

Pise, however, submitted that the charge under Section 409 (criminal breach of trust by banker, merchant or agent), a non-bailable offence, was not applicable in her case as she did not accept any money and was merely a partner in two of the eight partnership firms floated by DSK, till 2015. In the Phursungi land deal, Pise said the prosecution was yet to furnish to the court any power of attorney claimed to have been executed in her favour for making transactions.

Next hearing in the case is on January 20.

Title: Pune: Biomedical waste along rivers challenges ploggers
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

PUNE: Citizens and ploggers involved in clean-up drives across different stretches of rivers in the city have said the biggest challenge is the amount of biomedical waste dumped along the rivers.

Vivek Gurav, who started the movement Pune Ploggers, which undertakes clean-up drives every weekend across different river stretches across the city, said it was a chronic problem.

“We find a range of biomedical waste freely dumped along the riverbanks. We have approached different Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) departments about the waste and sought advice on how to go about disposing this waste. They took it from us at the time and said they would take care of it. However, we are still unsure as to how to go about disposing the biomedical waste,” he said.

He said they had spotted such waste at different spots across the city. “We have found it near Bhide Bridge along the Mutha river. We discovered syringes, two packets of needles and many test tubes containing blood samples,” he added.

Fellow plogger and student Bhushan More (19) said, “I discovered the bag of needles dumped along the Mutha river banks. We have no idea how to clear this.” He added that they came across this kind of waste quite often during plogging sessions.

Shailaja Deshpande , founder director of Jeevitnadi, which conducts river clean-up drives across the city, also said they had discovered such waste along the rivers mostly near crematoriums.

“We found a lot of such biomedical waste usually near the crematoriums along the river banks. We not only find biomedical waste, but bedsheets, mattress and pillows dumped along the banks. As far as biomedical waste is concerned, we generally find syringes, adult diapers, medicines, pads and injection bottles,” Deshpande said.

Dnyaneshwar Molak, head of the civic body’s solid waste department said they tried to clear biomedical waste at source.

“The PMC’s biomedical waste collection entails a system where we collect biomedical waste from each hospital. If there is such waste dumped along the river sides, we will try and carry out an enquiry on the sites where it is found and take action,” he said.

Title: Kondagunta rape: 5 accused arrested
