Title: MUHS brings in online services for research programmes
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Nashik: The Maharashtra University of Health Sciences ( MUHS ) has incorporated various online services in the research programmes at homeopathy colleges affiliated with the varsity. The university recently conducted a meeting of the deans of the homeopathy department with the management and principals of all MUHS-affiliated homeopathy colleges in Maharashtra.

MUHS vice-chancellor Dilip Mhaisekar underlined the importance of planning and research in the field of education. “We have incorporated online services in our teaching and administrative methods. It has increased our efficiency and the institution, colleges, teachers and students are benefiting.”

Pro vice-chancellor Mohan Khamgaonkar said MUHS has started accepting research papers and assessing them online, which has facilitated teachers as well as students. The syllabus of all the homeopathy courses, examination process, research receipts etc are being handled online as well. “While working across the colleges, it has become convenient for the administrative personnel to maximise its resources,” said registrar Kalidas Chavan.

Chairperson of the Association of Homeopathy Colleges of Maharashtra Vikram Kale said that with the onset of technology, the varsity has brought in changes in its approach to learning medical sciences. “There is also a need to address the issue of late admission of the students and the varsity is looking into the matter,” he said.

Title: Delhi: Congress says it’ll follow Kalkaji model on slum dwellers’ rehab
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Delhi Congress president Subhash Chopra. (Photo: Twitter/@SChopraINC)

NEW DELHI: If Congress comes to power, it will provide slum dwellers 25-square-metre flats in multistorey buildings as part of in situ development of slum clusters in the capital, Delhi Congress president Subhash Chopra said on Thursday. BJP has already promised ‘Jahaan Jhuggi Wahan Makaan ’.

Chopra said Congress would replicate the Kalkaji model to relocate the people without demolishing any slum cluster. He was referring to the in-situ slum redevelopment project of Delhi Development Authority (DDA) in south Delhi’s Kalkaji A-14, where more than 3,000 families from three slums will be provided flats. Chopra said he had got the project started as its local MLA.

Pointing out that this will be one of the main promises in the Congress manifesto for the assembly elections, Chopra claimed “Congress fulfils what it promises” and the Kalkaji model, with various amenities such as schools, anganwadis, dispensaries and parks, was an example of it. Both BJP and AAP have betrayed slum dwellers across Delhi, he alleged.

Chief spokesperson Mukesh Sharma claimed Congress had always protected the interest of slum dwellers by providing all civic amenities. When the late Indira Gandhi was the Prime Minister, 46 resettlement colonies were set up in Delhi, he said.

Chopra asked why the Kalkaji flats, finished after a delay of three and a half years, were yet to be allotted. When Congress’ Ajay Maken was a Union minister, flats were also constructed at Katputhli Colony and Ashok Vihar, but these are yet to be allotted, Chopra said. But BJP and AAP are trying to take credit for these flats, he alleged.

Both Chopra and Sharma alleged that BJP and AAP were misleading over 40 lakh residents of the unauthorised colonies in the capital in the name of giving ownership rights.

Title: Former bureaucrats say NRC, NPR and CAA can’t be delinked
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

PUNE: A group of 106 retired civil servants from across the country on Thursday put out an open letter to the citizens on the social media stating that the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ), National Register of Indian Citizens (NRC) and the National Population Register (NPR) could not be delinked as per the government’s claim.

City-based former IPS officer Meeran Borwankar, who is among the signatories of the letter, told TOI on the group’s behalf that it was high time the government focused on issues to address poverty “rather than divide the country on the lines of castes and communities”. She said, “I foresee a lot of harassment for the poor and the marginalised through this exercise.”

The letter stated that the powers to include or exclude a person from the local register of Indian citizens “vested with the bureaucracy at a fairly junior level has the scope of carrying out the activity in an arbitrary and discriminatory manner”.

The group said NPR and NRC were “unnecessary and wasteful exercises”, which would “cause hardship to public at large and entail public expenditure that is better spent on schemes benefiting the poor and disadvantaged sections”. It expressed reservations about the constitutional validity of CAA’s provisions, which they said were “morally indefensible”.

Title: Yashwant Sinha raises pitch for withdrawal of Act
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Yashwant Sinha

PUNE: Former Union finance minister Yashwant Sinha on Thursday said the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) was a “divisive” statute and demanded its withdrawal.

“It (CAA) is a black act. The government is using the Act to create divisive politics. The National Register of Citizens (NRC) has created an atmosphere of fear in the country. The government is acting against the school of thoughts promoted by Mahatma Gandhi ,” said Sinha. He was in the city along with Congress leaders Prithviraj Chavan and Shatrughan Sinha as part of a 3,000km Gandhi Shanti Yatra from Mumbai to New Delhi launched on Wednesday in protest against CAA.

The Yatra will pass through states such as Maharashtra, Gujarat, Rajasthan, Uttar Pradesh and Haryana and conclude at Raj Ghat in the national capital on January 30, the death anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi. The Yatra is also taken out in demand for a judicial probe into the violence at JNU and scrapping of the NRC.

Title: Azim Premji University students criticise Wipro for NRC role
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

While expressing support for students of JNU, students of Azim Premji University also hit out at CAA on Thursd... Read More

BENGALURU: Under-graduate students of Azim Premji University (APU) on Thursday staged a day-long protest to register their opposition to CAA and NRC and also express solidarity with their peers in Jawaharlal Nehru University, Aligarh Muslim University and Jamia Milia University. The students returned to campus on Tuesday after a semester break. The protest inside the campus was out of bounds for media and outsiders.

“The violence unleashed on students of JMI, AMU and JNU show the paranoia, intolerance and the subsequent feeling of insecurity of oppressors as regards their vested interest in retaining the status quo,” a statement released by the students said. “The state’s explicit war against critical dissent does not stop with this and also gets expressed unsubtly in its continual efforts to penalise public universities such as the recent fee hike in JNU.”

Students demanded that the Delhi police drop all charges against students who protested peacefully and the unconditional release of Chandrashekhar Azad Ravan and Akhil Gogoi.

Students and faculty members shared experiences of their times in JNU, “which is contradictory to what is being portrayed by people who want to defame it”. “There were students who were in Delhi when the internet was cut off, some from Assam who have seen the chaos of NRC and detention centres for themselves. All of them narrated their experiences at the protest,” said a student who participated in the protest.

Students also "condemned" IT major Wipro, for assisting the government in implementing NRC in Assam.

"We appeal to the private sector not to partner with the state in its fascist projects by assisting its discriminatory schemes," said a statement signed by 120 students of APU. Wipro did not respond to TOI's request for a comment.

The APU is an arm of Azim Premji Foundation, established by Wipro’s founder-chairman Azim Premji.

Title: SUK convocation on Feb 6
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Kolhapur: The 56th convocation ceremony of the Shivaji University, Kolhapur ( SUK ), will be held on the varsity premises on February 6, said Board of Examinations and Evaluation Director G R Palase. A notice issued by the university states that Maharashtra governor and chancellor Bhagat Singh Koshyari will be attending the ceremony. According to the university notice, Koshyari will be heading the function while Dr Bhushan Patwardhan, vice-chairperson University Grants Commission (UGC), will be the chief guest. Varsity officials said further information about the convocation ceremony will be conveyed via newspapers and published on the university website.

A varsity official said that it according to the Maharashtra Public Universities Act, 2016, it is now mandatory to intimate the stakeholders about the convocation ceremony a month before the actual event and that is why the notification was published on January 6. Due to last year’s changes in the convocation ceremony under the Maharashtra Universities Act, 2016, the affiliated colleges of SUK were asked to conduct a separate ceremony to distribute the certificates. The same procedure will be followed this year.

SUK had conferred around 50,000-degree certificates at the 54th convocation ceremony in 2018, while in 2019, at the 55th convocation ceremony, the university conferred degree certificates to in-house students only. Th university started functioning in 1962 with 34 affiliated colleges and about 14,000 students with five postgraduate departments on the campus. At present, the number of affiliated colleges has gone up to 293 and student strength stands at three lakh with 40 postgraduate departments on campus.

Title: Bareilly: Gangster who escaped police custody held within 15 hours
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

BAREILLY: In a sigh of relief to Bareilly police, gangster Salim, alias, Altaf, was nabbed within 15 hours after he escaped from their custody around 11.50pm on Wednesday.

Three policemen were taking him to Alwar when Salim, 55, jumped off the train as soon as he boarded it at Bareilly Junction railway station . The policemen chased him, but he disappeared in the dense fog.

Superintendent of police (city) Ravindra Kumar said on Thursday afternoon , they arrested him from Bareilly City railway station.

The SP said Salim was lodged for 18 months in a case of theft registered against him. “He has several cases such as theft, animal and vehicle lifting registered against him in various districts. Since he has been operating a gang, the Gangster Act was slapped on him. Salim was taken to Alwar on Wednesday to produce before a local court in connection with a case lodged there when he escaped from the custody,” said the SP.

It has been learnt that policemen — head constable Krishan Avtarn and two constables Dinesh Kumar and Rampal, who were escorting the gangster — had dinner and allegedly consumed alcohol with Salim before boarding Shramjivi Express from platform number two.

“An inquiry has been set up against the cops and appropriate action will be taken against them if found lax on their part,” said the SP.

According to police, as soon as the train arrived, the cops made Salim board a general compartment. He was handcuffed and a policeman was holding him with a rope. However, Salim jumped off the train from another door with handcuffs in his hands.

The SP said after the incident, police sounded high alert across the district and launched a massive manhunt for him.

“However, after fleeing, Salim reached City station to board a train when our team spotted and arrested him,” added the SP.

Title: Nagpur: Vidarbha Sanshodhan Mandal lecture throws light on caves and Buddhist tradition
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Manjiri Bhalerao explains in detail about caves at the event held on Thursday

Nagpur: A lecture was organized by the Vidarbha Sanshodhan Mandal , Civil Lines, on Thursday at their premises on the man-made rock cut caves and their relation to Buddhist traditions.

The lecture was delivered by associate professor of Indology at Tilak Maharashtra University, Pune, Dr Manjiri Bhalerao. She spoke about the architecture, inscriptions and motifs on the caves and how they have been developed over the years.

Bhalerao also enlightened the audience about the presence of multiple caves in just not Vidarbha but whole Maharashtra and the various sects in Buddhism .

According to her, caves are very prominent part of ancient Indian culture as they serve as an important source to reconstruct the history of the country.

She elucidated on the rock cut caves, their types, functions and chronological evolution over the years.

Organizer and Heritage Cell convener of the mandal, Dr Sheshshayan Deshmukh told TOI, “Our heritage which is of great importance to us is being destroyed due to our own ignorance. And the rate at which the destruction is happening is quite alarming. We really need to understand our history to protect our heritage.”

Deshmukh also mentioned that the mandal organizes lectures every month on a topic pertaining to history, literature, art etc to enlighten the people and spread awareness.

Title: Pay higher cess for cow welfare, UP CM Yogi Adityanath asks mandis
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

File photo of UP CM Yogi Adityanath.

LUCKNOW: After Mandi Parishad registered a spike in its revenue, chief minister Yogi Adityanath said it should give 3% cess instead of existing 2% towards welfare of cows.

At the end of current financial year, Mandi Parishad is expected to give about Rs 60 crore for the upkeep and maintenance of stray cattle in cow shelters.

The CM has set a target of Rs 100 crore for the Parishad.

Minister of state (independent charge), agricultural marketing, Sriram Chauhan told TOI that in 2018-19, the total income of Mandi Parishad was Rs 1,346 crore and it paid Rs 26-27 crore as cess for cow welfare.

“This year, our income has already touched Rs 1,508 crore and is expected to touch Rs 2,000 crore by the end of this financial year,” he said.

Chauhan said the CM was of the view that a portion of the amount should be given to those institutions that run cow shelters with devotion while some money could also go to animal husbandry department.

“The CM said in view of volatile situation in the Middle East, the administration should take steps to check hoarding and black marketeering essential items. The CM said we should keep a check on prices of essential commodities. If oil prices are affected, we will have to ensure that there is minimum impact,” Chauhan said.

Yogi also directed officials to ensure that a lab for producing organic food is set up in Lucknow, Varanasi, Gorakhpur , Bundelkhand and west UP. These labs will be set up in Krishi Vigyan Kendras in every district.

Title: Allahabad high court gives six weeks to Centre, UP to enforce service rules for STPF
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

PILIBHIT: The Allahabad high court has given six weeks’ time to the Centre and to the UP government to frame and enforce the service rules for Special Tiger Protection Force (STPF) and to conclude all concerned proceedings by February 16. The Lucknow bench comprising justices Pankaj Kumar and Narendra Kumar Johari fixed final date in the matter to February 17.

The court directed the principal secretary of forest in UP to appear before it if the compliance with the court order was not ensured by the fixed date.

In absence of separate service rules for STPF in Uttar Pradesh , the policemen for this special force are sent on deputation from police or provincial armed constabulary (PAC) who are governed by their own service rules. This badly hampers the objective of tiger protection as well as the effective control on wildlife crimes.

The petition in the matter was filed by Lucknow-based lawyer Satish Kumar Mishra, in 2016. “It was the outcome of my petition that following the high court order, the first STPF comprising 112 cops had been constituted by the state government in 2017 for its deployment at Dudhwa Tiger Reserve (DTR),” the petitioner said.

The court had also been asked to issue directions to the state government to frame exclusive service rules for STPF with an aim to open the door for direct recruitment of cops for this special force and to keep them under the exclusive command and control of the forest authorities, he said.

As the government continued to seek time stating that efforts were on to wipe out legal complications from the way of framing rules in question during the previous about 18 hearings, the matter could not reach its final destination, Mishra said.

“Now the court has extended the last opportunity to the respondents to finalize the proceedings of service rules for STPF and to file the compliance report before the bench on February 17,” he said.

Meanwhile, the field director of DTR, Sanjay Kumar, who is one of the pleaders in court on behalf of the UP forest administration, said, “The new service rules will wipe out complications in governing the STPF in accordance with the actual needs of the forest department.”

“The newly recruited cops will be given proper training in forest and wildlife crime control matters in all aspects and the forest authorities will be free to bring them under the ambit of legal as well as the departmental action in case of any discrepancy on their part without depending upon any other department,” he said.

Title: Delhi: Fraud tops cybercrime chart
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: The capital has witnessed more cybercrime incidents — 189 — in 2018 as compared to 162 in 2017. While most of the offences — 43 — were computer-related frauds, 32 involved sexual exploitation of women, 28 cyber stalking, 17 publishing sexually explicit content, nine other frauds and three bullying children on the net. In 35 cases, chargesheets have been filed.

In 2018, the cops also disposed of 460 cases, including the ones pending for the past two years.

According to National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB), the figure was just 2% of the 10,098 cybercrime cases reported in 19 major cities in 2018. Bengaluru was at the top with 5,253 (32.5%) incidents. While fraud was the motive in the majority of the cases, extortion, personal revenge and playing pranks were the other common reasons.

The cybercrime unit of Delhi Police registered 15 cases of identity theft, eight of cheating using a computer device and 34 of publication or transmission of obscene and sexually explicit act in electronic form. No case was lodged under the head of cyber terrorism. In 2018, the cops probed 163 cases of cybercrime, during which 77 people were arrested and 49 chargesheeted. Only two accused were convicted.

In 2017, Delhi Police had launched a dedicated website where the victims of cybercrime can lodge a complaint. A cyber laboratory to help in such cases was also set up.

Title: Traffic diversion at Bhakti Shakti Chowk to facilitate grade separator, flyover works
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD : Traffic diversions will be imposed at Bhakti Shakti Chowk on the Pune-Mumbai highway in Nigdi from Monday to facilitate construction of a grade separator and a flyover.

The ever-busy Bhakti Shakti Chowk, a gateway to Pimpri Chinchwad city from old Pune-Mumbai highway, is located at the intersection of Pune-Mumbai highway and Spine Road. The Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC) has started the construction work of a grade separator and a rotary flyover at this chowk to ensure uninterrupted traffic flow.

The construction work had begun in the area two years ago, during which vehicles were allowed to the ply on the road with reduced carriageway width. This resulted in traffic snarls, particularly during the peak morning and evening hours, on both the sides of the highway and Spine Road.

Vijay Bhojane, spokesperson of the Bus Rapid Transit System cell, told TOI, “About 80% construction of the grade separator and the rotary flyover has been completed. Now, we need to dig the highway for the construction works. Therefore, vehicles will not be able to cross the junction from one side of Spine Road to another.”

The contractor for the projects has been told to to put up direction boards, radium strips, adequate lights and deploy 50 wardens to control traffic at the chowk when the construction work is in progress. The contractor will be entirely responsible if any accident takes place on the chowk, Bhojane added.

As per the traffic police, vehicles headed to Mumbai from Pune will have to take a left turn at Bhakti Shakti Chowk and go via Appughar through Transportnagar to reach Pune-Mumbai highway. “The vehicles coming from Pune to go to Triveninagar will have to take left turn at the chowk and go via Appughar through Transportnagar to reach Nigdi octroi post and go through PMPML bus terminus and take a left turn to reach Triveninagar,” a traffic officer said.

Similarly, motorists coming from Mumbai to Pune will have to take a left turn and go through PMPML bus terminus to reach Durganagar Chowk. “From there, they will be required to take a right from to reach Tilak Chowk on Pune-Mumbai highway to reach Khandoba Mall Chowk in Akurdi on Pune-Mumbai Highway,” he said.

When it comes to traffic heading to Chinchwad from Mumbai, motorists will have to take a left turn to arrive at Chicken Chowk. From there, they can reach Chinchwad via Durganagar and Tilak junctions. “Traffic going to Pune from Triveninagar, will have to go via Tilak Chowk,” the official added.

Title: Surprise raid: Rampur DM finds RTO officials missing, takes action
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

DM Aunjaneya Kumar Singh (extreme right) conducts an inspection at Regional Transport Office in Rampur on Thur... Read More

BAREILLY: There was a panic at the Regional Transport Office (RTO), located on Bareilly-Rampur road, in the afternoon on Thursday, after district magistrate (DM) Aunjaneya Kumar Singh came for a surprise inspection and found most officials missing in office. Sources said the raid was conducted after the DM received information about irregularities and unauthorised occupation of the office premises and campus by touts, and absenteeism of officials during day time.

Speaking to TOI, DM Aunjaneya Kumar Singh said, “Numerous complaints were pouring in about officials not being present at the RTO during working hours. Besides, there were other complaints pertaining to agents/touts entering the office premises, and of random people entering the office. Several complaints were being lodged by local residents who were being bothered by these “agents” present at the RTO, and therefore a surprise inspection was conducted. During the visit, it was found that only a handful of staff members and contractual employees were present in office, while most were missing.”

He added, “On inquiry, it was found that the passenger tax officer (PTO) was away on field inspection. But six clerks, who were supposed to be in office, were found missing. Several unauthorised people who were inside the premises managed to escape. The inspection continued for around 30 minutes. I’ve ordered one day’s salary to be deducted from those who were absent. One tout was caught from inside the office, and has been detained for enquiry. Strict warning has been issued to the officials to remain present during working hours and take up their responsibilities effectively.

Rampur assistant regional transport officer (ARTO), Arun Kumar, told TOI, “I’m also the office head and was present during the surprise visit by the Rampur DM. PTO Anita Verma was not in office as her work is mostly in the field. But legal action has been initiated against six clerks who were absent.”

Trying to explain the embarrassment, the ARTO pointed at the inconvenience faced by RTO employees, saying, “The current office, set up in a private building, is very small and has reached its maximum capacity . It always remains congested. We’ve requested the administration to relocate the office for the convenience of employees.”

Title: Medicos to get lessons in spirituality in UP
Content:
Representative image

LUCKNOW: Amid complaints of misbehaviour of doctors and commercialisation of the medical profession, the medical education department has decided to run spirituality and morality classes for students in state-run medical colleges.The government is set to issue an order in this regard. The classes would be compulsory for all MBBS and PG students . Sources in the department said the government was planning an overhaul of medical education in the state.While life coaches and experts will be invited for moral and spiritual sermons to students to make them more sensitive, the cost of medical education is also expected to go down. The government aims to make it easier for students from humble economic backgrounds to study in the field.The first major step towards this is the setting up of 45 medical colleges in UP by 2023. Every second district will have a medical college by then to check brain drain from UP. Authorities feel that adequate availability of medical education institutions would check the shift of aspirants to highly commercialised private medical colleges and thus prevent young doctors from “turning into money-making machines”. Medical education minister Suresh Khanna, who also holds charge of finance and parliamentary affairs ministry, confirmed that his department would direct medical colleges, universities and research institutions to hold special classes on spirituality and morality to inculcate a sense of service among the young doctors.Khanna said he had already discussed the plan with principals of medical colleges and they had supported this.Initially, classes on spirituality would either be held in the morning assembly or the end of the day at 4pm for MBBS and PG students. Classes would be held once a week but periodicity could be increased later.“Senior faculty members of professor-rank would be assigned lectures on the significance of ethics and spirituality. Experts will also be invited,” said Khanna.The minister added that this was the most auspicious year to launch such a curriculum as 2020 was being celebrated as the 150th birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi , who embodied ethics and morality in life.Khanna also claimed that there was acute shortage of doctors in UP. There is a need of 2.2 lakh doctors as of now. Under WHO norms, there should be one doctor for 1,000 people. However, in UP, one doctor was for 3,700 people.This deficit, mainly in the government sector, was tempting medical practitioners to make money, he said. The solutions to these concerns was setting up more medical colleges and teaching ethics and spirituality, he said.Incidentally, in November, the Medical Council of India changed the syllabus for medical education nationally to include a component on attitude, ethics and communication to sensitise students.

Title: Extension for Uruli TP scheme draft
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

PUNE: The town planning scheme draft for Uruli-Phursungi faces a six-month delay as the Pune Municipal Corporation failed to complete its report till December 31, 2019, deadline.

The state government has now given the civic body time till July 2020 to finish the task.

Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) officials said the civic body had planned TP schemes at Uruli Devachi and Phursungi. They would be built on land measuring between 110 and 541 hectares. “The draft will show how these schemes will be implemented. The preparations were to be completed by 2019-end,” a civic official said.

After the deadline lapsed, PMC approached the state government for an extension, which was approved. The state has also told the PMC to get due approvals from key municipal committees. “The civic body had some limitations in working on the draft due to the election code of conduct during state polls,” Yuvraj Deshmukh, a senior official of the civic building permission department, said.

Title: Shahjahanpur: Newborn’s body found in polybag near river
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

BAREILLY: A newborn’s body wrapped in a polythene bag was dumped on the bank of river Lodipur Khannaut in Shahjahanpur on Thursday. The body of the baby boy has been sent for postmortem.

According to sources, locals spotted the body and informed the police at Sadar Bazar police station. It is suspected that the newborn was killed and later dumped here as he was wrapped in plastic. Police said the baby boy was about a day old.

SHO, Sadar Bazar police station, Kiran Pal Singh, said, “After getting information, we took the body and sent for postmortem. The body was dumped here on Wednesday night. We are awaiting postmortem report to know the cause of death. No FIR has been lodged so far, but after receiving postmortem report, we will take action accordingly.”

Title: FDA shuts over a dozen meat shops in Kolhapur dist
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Kolhapur: The Food and Drugs Administration (FDA) has shut down over a dozen mutton shops across the district over the last 30 days for failing to comply with guidelines, said M S Kembalkar, assistant commissioner of the FDA ’s Kolhapur unit. He added that the licence of one mutton shop from the city was suspended while in Jaysingpur, the licences of nine shops have been cancelled. Four shops were shut down in Kagal last week due to non-compliance.

According to the FDA official, the action was taken under the Food Safety and Standards Act, 2006. There are around 550 mutton shops across the district, while Kolhapur has over 150 shops. Kembalkar said the guidelines for meat shop owners include an elaborate list of dos and don’ts which are frequently overlooked.

“Meat shops near religious places and vegetable markets are strictly forbidden. According to the rules, meat sellers have to remain beyond a 50-metre radius of religious places. They must also ensure their shops are located at least 100 metres from the main gate of such places. Meat sellers cannot slaughter any animal inside a shop, and have to put up curtains or tinted glass so that the meat is not visible to the public.”

He further said that all people working at meat shops must obtain health certificates from government doctors. The meat will also have to be certified by authorised veterinarians. The FDA is the issuing authority for certificates in urban as well as rural areas. “Meat vendors have also been directed not to slaughter any ill, milch or pregnant animal. All the knives and other implements must be made of steel and there should be no trace of rust on them. Meat shops must have proper waste disposal arrangements and should keep a record of all meat purchased from slaughterhouses. Moreover, the fresh orders specify that meat can only be transported in insulated freezer vehicles from slaughterhouses and should be stored in refrigerators with transparent doors,” said Kembalkar.

“We are aware that this is an exhaustive list of guidelines, but meat shop owners need to comply with it. If, during an inspection, rules are found to be violated, the meat in the shop can be destroyed and the shop can lose its licence. A fine is also imposed,” he said.

FDA guidelines for meat shops

Ill, milch or pregnant animals are not to be slaughtered

Knives, other implements must be made of steel and must be rust-free

Proper waste disposal arrangements are necessary

Record of all meat purchased from slaughterhouses must be maintained

Meat can only be transported in insulated freezer vehicles from slaughterhouses and should be stored in refrigerators with transparent doors.

Meat shops need to be equipped with geysers

Shops must be beyond a 50-metre radius of religious places

Animals must not be slaughtered inside a shop; curtains or tinted glass must be installed so the meat is not visible

Title: Is elephant a citizen, asks CJI, hearing habeas corpus plea
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

CJI Bobde

NEW DELHI: The first-ever legal experiment to test the applicability of habeas corpus writ to locate an elephant failed as the Supreme Court on Thursday asked how such a writ, generally used to locate the whereabouts of a person in illegal detention, could be applied to animals.

CJI Bobde asked, “Is elephant a citizen of India? How does habeas corpus petition apply for animals? If we agree with your arguments, then a villager whose cattle is stolen by another can move the high court with a habeas corpus petition to recover his cattle from the illegal custody of others.”

Appearing before a bench of Chief Justice S A Bobde and Justices B R Gavai and Surya Kant, advocate Wills Mathews argued that since animals had right to life, as ruled by the SC while banning Jallikattu (bull running) on the ground of cruelty to animals, habeas corpus could be used by a mahout to locate elephant Laxmi.

Laxmi was in the news four months ago as Delhi Police on September 17 had claimed that they had arrested mahout Saddam, the petitioner before the SC, for allegedly stealing and hiding her. Saddam was released on bail by a Karkardooma court in east Delhi after spending 68 days in Mandoli jail.

Laxmi, allegedly recovered by police from Saddam, was sent to a rehabilitation centre. The SC asked the petitioner to move the HC where a custody battle over Laxmi is being fought.

Title: Karnataka: Legal eagles argue for, against CAA
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Another group held a protest against the CAA, saying it seeks to divide people

BENGALURU: The Citizenship (Amendment) Act is ruffling feathers of legal eagles in the Karnataka high court. A day after the central government moved the Supreme Court requesting petitions against CAA in the high court be moved to the apex court, two groups of advocates on Thursday held separate demonstrations for and against the Act.

Pro-CAA advocates, under the banner Adhivakt Parishad, Karnataka, congregated in front of the main gate of the high court around 12.30 pm. They demanded immediate implementation of the new legislation — for which rules are yet to be notified. They waved placards and shouted slogans in support of CAA.

Senior advocate Vivek Reddy said a disinformation campaign is being spread against CAA by political parties and individuals. “The Congress and Communist parties, which till now did only lip service to the problems the country faces, are spreading falsehoods on CAA. We commend the Modi government for finding a solution to a 70-year-old problem.”

DP Prasanna, who was all praise for CAA, said the new legislation does not affect any Indian citizen, including Muslims. He said the law was brought in to protect persecuted minorities from Pakistan, Afghanistan and Bangladesh , who are living in India.

Around 4pm, another group of advocates assembled in front of Vidhana Soudha, voicing concern over the new legislation. They said it is discriminatory as it seeks to keep the Muslim community out. Waving the tricolour, the advocates held hands, stood facing Vidhana Soudha and formed a human chain between the two entrances of Namma Metro Vidhana Station on the high court side. The demonstration lasted an hour and ended with them singing the national anthem. Advocates Association, Bengaluru president AP Ranganatha was spotted among the evening protesters.

AS Ponnanna, senior advocate and former Additional Advocate General, who is against CAA, said the earlier definition was homogeneous, but the new legislation seeks to classify religious persecution and is opposed to secularism, the basic principle of the Constitution. He said when the state has no religion, any legislation that seeks to differentiate on the basis of religion goes against the concept of equality and secularism.

Firoze, who works as advocate clerk, said the government should provide jobs for all and stop dividing people.

Title: Taimur Ali Khan calls daddy Saif Ali Khan's avatar from 'Tanhaji: The Unsung Warrior' as 'Sardarji'
Content: Rahul Dev and Mugdha Godse have been together since 7 years and their love has only grown with the passing of each day. There's a very secured sense of calmness, well-being and happiness when you talk to them.

Title: GoAir pilot, co-pilot suspended for landing aircraft on grass at Bengaluru's Kempegowda International Airport
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Kempegowda International Airport

BENGALURU: The pilot and co-pilot responsible for a GoAir flight veering off the runway and landing on grass at Kempegowda International Airport on November 11, have been suspended .

Aviation regulator Directorate General of Civil Aviation conducted an inquiry and suspended the pilot and co-pilot for for six and three months, respectively for landing the aircraft in low-visibility conditions.

There were 180 passengers on board the A320-neo aircraft from Nagpur to Bengaluru. The pilot landed at a visibility of around 155 metres as against the 550 metres necessary for the Air Traffic Control to give a go-ahead for landing.

Title: Delhi: Special Cell nabs 3 with links to IS
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Syed Ali Navaz, Khaja Moideen & Abdul Samad.

NEW DELHI: Delhi Police ’s Special Cell on Thursday morning arrested three alleged Islamic State operatives from a north Delhi locality. The trio was identified as Khaja Moideen (52) and Abdul Samad (28) from Cuddalore, Tamil Nadu and Syed Ali Navaz (32) from Kanyakumari. Another suspect, Zafar Ali, was arrested in Gujarat.

Samad, who has pursued an MCA, is the member of banned outfit Popular Front of India (PFI). Moideen had joined the CPI (M) and later joined Manitha Neethi Pasarai (MNP) as a district organiser in Cuddalore area. A manhunt has been launched for three more members of this module who have been identified as Taufiq, Shamim and Anees.

ACP Lalit Mohan Negi’s team had received an input that a group of highly radicalised suspects from Tamil Nadu had fled under mysterious circumstances and pledged allegiance to ISIS . On January 9, the team found out that the trio had shifted to Delhi and rented a room in Wazirabad area. A team led by inspectors Sunil Rajain, Ravinder Joshi and Vinod Badola laid a trap near Wazirabad bridge and arrested the trio after a brief exchange of fire around 7am.

As per sources, Moideen told the cops that he had made a detailed plan to revive the ISIS network in India. Several rounds of meeting were organised by him at different hideouts to indoctrinate and motivate youths to pledge allegiance to slain ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi. They were guided by a foreign based handler on Telegram and WhatsApp. The group then decided to abscond and meet their handler in Nepal.

Moideen, along with Syed Ali Nawaz and Abdul Samad, went to Kathmandu, Nepal after illegally crossing the border with fake documents. After setting up a base in Nepal to be used as a hideout, they had come to Delhi.

In 2004, Moideen was arrested in Cuddalore for organising a training camp at Nellikuppam. In 2014, a local Hindu Munnani leader namely K P Suresh was brutally hacked to death by this module. In September 2017, one of his recruits Shakul Hameed alias Salavadin, an MBA dropout, was arrested from Otteri in Chennai. It was Moideen, who lured Hameed to IS and even arranged his travel abroad.

Title: After Bijnor, now locals in Moradabad ‘kill’ leopard
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

BAREILLY: In yet another incident of man-leopard conflict, a leopard was allegedly killed by villagers under Kanth police station limits of Moradabad district. The big cat’s carcass was found on Wednesday following which forest department has lodged an FIR against unknown villagers for killing the animal.

Notably, at least 80 villagers were booked in neighbouring Bijnor district on Tuesday for reportedly killing a leopard there.

Speaking to TOI on Thursday, divisional forest officer (DFO) of Moradabad Kanhaiya Patel said that the leopard carcass was sent to Bareilly for autopsy. “The postmortem report suggests that the animal succumbed to traumatic shock due to head injury. Besides head, no other injury mark was found on the body. Veterinary experts said the leopard was either struck on the head by a heavy object or it may have sustained head injury after being hit by a vehicle,” the DFO said, adding that “we have lodged an FIR since it cannot be ruled out that the animal was killed by villagers”.

“The case will be clear once police complete its probe whether the animal was hit by a vehicle or attacked by villagers,” Patel also said.

The carcass of the three-year-old adult male leopard weighing 61 kg was first spotted by villagers near Jamuniya Khurd village on the Moradabad-Amroha border on Wednesday morning. A team of forest department rushed to the spot after getting information. SHO Kanth inspector Ajay Gautam also reached the spot with a police team. SHO and forest officials said that this was “a rare occasion when a leopard’s carcass has been found under mysterious circumstances in the district”.

Title: Amid anti-CAA stir, UP government begins preparation for NPR
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

BAREILLY: After state government’s directives, the district administration here has started its preparation to update the National Population Register ( NPR ).

The NPR is considered as the first step towards National Register of Citizens (NRC). However, the Union home minister Amit Shah has lately said after countrywide anti-CAA-NRC protests that there is no link between NPR and NRC. The Centre has approved Rs 3,941.35 crore for updating of NPR as well as Rs 8,754.23 crore as funding for Census 2021.

Additional district magistrate (finance & revenue) Manoj Pandey told TOI on Thursday that four gazetted officers from Bareilly have recently participated in a training session on NPR preparation held in Lucknow. “These master trainers will further train 180 officers on how to update NPR,” he said.

The officers who attended the training session were district development officer Shiv Kumar, additional statistic officer Mahesh Chand, block education officer Devesh Rai and additional BSA Rajeev Srivastava.

Kumar said that officials from all districts had arrived to take part in the session.

While updating the NPR, all houses will be counted by the enumerators and observers for which a field survey will start from May 16 and will continue until June 30. ADM said that master trainers would start a training session for enumerators and observers from April 20.

Director at UP directorate of census operation, Naresh Shankar Pandey, has asked all district magistrates across the state to select enumerators and observers and provide the list, latest by January 31.

The demographic data for NPR was reportedly first collected in 2010 during UPA government and it was last updated in 2015.

Title: Rickshaw union look for options in students’ transport
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Kolhapur: Using two-wheelers for ferrying students or sticking to the stipulated limit of five students are some of the alternatives that autorickshaw union Vidyarthi Vahtuk Sanghatana is working upon to continue with their school children transport business across the city and district.

Shivaji Patil, president of the 2,300-member Vidyarthi Vahtuk autorickshaw sanghatana, said that the union is trying to abide by the Central Motor Vehicle Rules for the time being until there is some kind of golden mean to the situation.

“Some autorickshaw drivers who have their own two-wheelers are ferrying children to school and back home while others have limited the student carrying capacity in their rickshaws. Earlier, rickshaws used to ferry 10-12 schoolchildren at a time. The number has now reduced to five,” he said.

Patil said that the parents are worried as the only medium of transport for their children has been hampered. They have demanded that the government and school administration should increase the presence of school buses in all areas so that students do not face difficulties in commuting to schools and back home.

“We are firm on filing a public interest litigation (PIL) before January 20. The preparations regarding the same are in progress. PIL is the only way we can have some kind of representation for our case. In cities like Kolhapur , several things, including traffic, is quite different as compared to metro cities like Pune and Mumbai,” he said.

According to Patil, the union ferrys more than 10,000 students to their respective schools with precaution and that the union members are ready to abide by the necessary safety guidelines.

Meanwhile, the Regional Transport Office (RTO) sources said that they have relaxed the action on the rickshaws considering the public sentiments and students’ interest.

An official from the RTO, Kolhapur, said that they received a letter from the education department as well to relax the action until the commencement of the next academic year in June 2020.

“We are not ignoring the situation, but action is being taken against those violating the Motor Vehicle Act. We are monitoring students transportation in rickshaws as well as in school buses,” said the official.

Title: Now 40% payment through FASTag at toll plaza
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Kolhapur: With just six days remaining for the implementation of compulsory FASTag at all toll plazas, the rate of vehicles equipped with the technology in the district is quite low.

According to the National Highway Authority of India (NHAI) officials, only 40% toll was collected through electronic transaction at the Kini toll plaza on the Pune-Bangalore national highway.

According to government officials, FASTags will be mandatory at all toll plazas from January 15.

NHAI officials said that the toll collection through FASTags at the Kini toll plaza in November was 20%. It increased by 10% until December end and, at present, it has gone up to 40%.

B S Salunkhe, official in-charge of NHAI, Kolhapur , said, “The toll collection through FASTags is increasing but at a slow pace. At present, the total toll collection stands at around 40%. We are trying to ensure 100% toll collection through FASTags. For that, we are taking up drives to increase awareness about FASTags among vehicle owners. We expect that they will follow the set rules and regulations about FASTags soon. The Kini toll plaza on the Pune-Bangalore national highway has four lanes and, as special arrangement to avoid inconvenience to the travellers, we have already dedicated two lanes for vehicles paying toll in cash.”

The government had earlier said that no vehicle will be allowed to pass through toll plazas without FASTags from December 1. The deadline was later extended to December 15. However, due to several reasons, the government had to extend the deadline further to January 15. At the time, it was decided that one lane will be kept open for collecting toll through cash for the time being and once all vehicles are equipped with FASTags, all lanes at toll plazas will be closed for cash payments.

FASTags are prepaid rechargeable tags for toll collection that allow automatic payment deduction from a vehicle owner’s account. They are affixed on the front windscreen of vehicles. FASTags work on Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) technology.

Title: Will videograph indirect election process: SEC in HC
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Madurai: The state election commission (SEC) has informed the Madras high court that the indirect election process in local bodies which is to be conducted across the state on January 11 would be videographed.

Two separate petitions were filed by Lalitha, newly-elected DMK councillor of ward 20 in Nilakottai panchayat union in Dindigul district and K Murugan, councillor of ward 5 in Mudukulathur panchayat union in Ramanathapuram district seeking to videograph the indirect elections conducted in their respective panchayats. When these petitions were heard on Thursday, a senior counsel who appeared for one of the petitioners submitted that the entire election process conducted for indirect election in the state should be videographed in order to ensure a free and fair election. He further submitted that videograph of the entire election process would prevent malpractices such as booth capturing which were reported in previous elections.

Another senior counsel who appeared on behalf of the SEC submitted that a circular had been issued to all the district election officers to videograph (not CCTV) the election process whereever required.

He said that the SEC shall instruct all district election officers to videograph the indirect election process conducted for electing the posts of chairmen and vice-chairmen of panchayat unions and district panchayats across the state on January 11. He also submitted that the commission would also issue a modified circular to all the district election officers in this regard.

A division bench of justice M Duraiswamy and justice T Ravindran observed that since the state election commission informed that indirect election process across the state would be videographed, the court is not inclined to pass any further orders in this regard. The judges disposed of these petitions directing the state government to file affidavit of compliance on January 21.

Title: Nagpur: VNIT study suggests new body, measures for metro region water woes
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

NAGPUR: A joint study by professors and students of Visvesvaraya National Institute of Technology ( VNIT ) and Japan’s Keio University (KU) has recommended the establishment of an urban-rural coordinating entity at governance level in Nagpur for dealing with water conflicts emerging due to rapid urbanization, loss of cropland, conservation of forests, land utilization and food security concerns in the metropolitan area.

The study has also highlighted the declining water availability in the Nagpur Metropolitan Area (NMA) and suggested the creation of alternative water sources in different parts of the district. Numerous agencies are involved in water management in Nagpur region, but there is a need for policy coordination at various levels for water being shared in NMA, it states.

Under land cover change, the study places on priority the need to ensure food security in NMA, as fertile agricultural land in its northeast area was lost to urbanization between 2006 and 2018.

The report showcases the flow analysis of people in urban, rural and forest areas along the Pench corridor. It carries a foreword by mayor Sandip Joshi, who notes that the report provides a glimpse into the grassroot level issues in Nagpur, and that strengthening urban-rural linkages holds the key to achieving sustainable urban development.

The study ‘Building Resilient Cities — Through Urban-Rural Partnership’ attributes water as one of the key determinants of economic growth, and calls for a comprehensive long term plan to balance supply and demand of the scarce resources in the region.

As per data from civic bodies, the researchers also recommended alternate water sources, such as Rehari barrage on Kanhan river to fulfil growing water demands in view of declining water availability in Totladoh dam.

Showing a comparison of decadal data, the study points out that areas close to Nagpur city are witnessing maximum rural-urban change.

On Thursday, a round table meet comprising representatives from disaster management institutions, civic bodies, the Institute for Global Environmental Strategies (IGES), and VNIT, KU professors was held to discuss the study, which has been submitted to the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC). National Fire Service College (NFSC) director GS Saini, NMC acting chief fire officer Rajendra Uchake, VNIT director Pramod Padole and the research teams were present.

The researchers comprise Kamakshi Thapa, Harshitha N, Sameer Deshkar (all from VNIT), Vibhas Sukhwani, Rajib Shaw, Wanglin Yan (all from KU) and Bijon Kumar Mitra (IGES). The report is part of research conducted under the India-Japan Bilateral Programme.

The study aims to apply the concept of ‘Regional-Circular Ecological Sphere (R-CES)’ in rural and urban Nagpur. It details the physical characteristics and changing climate, demographic transitions, land utilization/land cover change, water source areas of Nagpur, urban-rural water conflict, water policy and governance aspects, and avenues for urban-rural partnerships, besides recommending entry points for R-CES.

Professor Deshkar said that the R-CES concept is based on an integrated policy approach that incorporates low-carbon society, resource circulation and living in harmony with nature.

Title: Delhi: Fire at printing press, staffer dies in sleep
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: A man working in a printing press died after a major fire broke out at the four-storey building in east Delhi ’s Patparganj early on Thursday.

It took nearly six hours to douse the fire and cooling operations continued till late evening. Preliminary investigation revealed that the fire was caused by a short circuit. The building did not have valid fire No Objection Certificate.

Fire officials received a call at 2.38am about a fire in the Patparganj Industrial Area. “The building comprises basement, ground and two other floors. It took over 30 fire tenders and 160 firefighters to douse the fire by 8am,” said Atul Garg, director, Delhi Fire Services. The building had a single exit and entry route.

Police officers said the fire may have started from the elevator and spread quickly to the other floors. Phool Dev (25) was found at the ground floor and rushed to a hospital where he was declared dead on arrival. He died due to asphyxiation in sleep, police said. “Owners of the building were identified as Atul and Anuj Goyal. The manager of the building, Yogesh, had called PCR at 2.45am. A case has been registered,” said a police officials. TNN

Title: 50 auto drivers fined for not wearing uniform
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Kolhapur: As many as 50 autorickshaw drivers have been fined by the traffic police for not following the prescribed dress code while driving the autos in city.

According to police, from January 1 it is mandatory for auto drivers to wear khaki-coloured uniform along with the registration badge while driving the auto.

Vasant Babar, police inspector in-charge of city traffic department, said, “We launched the drive on January 1 to fine those driving autos with the prescribed uniform. We had held meetings with auto drivers and had asked them to follow the rules. We had also informed them that we will initiate action from January 1 and fine them if they are found violating the rules. In the first eight days, we have fined 50 autorickshaw drivers for violating the dress code norm.”

He added, “Most of the drivers were fined in the first two-to-three days. Now, almost all drivers are found following the dress code and we rarely come across anyone riding an auto without the uniform. The number of such drivers is around 2% in Kolhapur .”

Babar said they are also taking action against auto drivers found violating traffic norms. “The drivers are now following the dress code owing to the ongoing drive. However, our department will continue to take action against them throughout the year if they are found driving without the uniform,” he said.

City traffic department had last month launched a drive against six-seater autorickshaws and those ferrying passengers from neighbouring villages to Kolhapur and had banned their entry into the city.

The drive was successful after the traffic department allowed such autos to enter some roads in the city and assigned stops for them. “Our aim is to ensure that traffic on city roads should move smoothly without unnecessary stops by these autorickshaws,” Babar said.

Title: Manoj Tiwari says will ask Kejriwal one question daily for the next 10 days
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Manoj Tiwari

NEW DELHI: Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari on Thursday came down heavily on chief minister Arvind Kejriwal for the latter’s scathing comments on the BJP-run corporations . He claimed that the chief minister was talking about the corporations in a bid to escape people’s questions on the “failures” of AAP government.

At a press conference held soon after the CM released the report card of the corporations, Tiwari showed videos and photos of broken roads, overflowing sewers, schoolchildren endangering their lives crossing open drains, etc, to claim that AAP government had failed completely onall fronts. He said the pictures were being sharedon social media by citizens.

“Kejriwal has no answers to the questions about the failures of his government. Even after five years, he is running away from the people. To cover up his failures, Kejriwal talks about irrelevant things, but not about water supply, the depleting fleet of DTC buses, pollution, lack of colleges and poor condition of flyovers and roads,” Tiwari said.

The Delhi BJP chief said he would ask Kejriwal one question a day on the development of Delhi for the next 10 days. “Why were Rs 20,000 crore due to the corporations not released by AAP government?” he asked, adding these could have been used for paying the salaries of the employees.

Tiwari said BJP would not allow Kejriwal to escape from a discussion on the performance of his government. “Kejriwal starts talking about other states when we ask him about dirty water supply, pollution and lack of transport infrastructure in the city. The assembly elections in Delhi is just a few days away, people want to know what AAP government has done in all these five years,” Tiwari said. If elected, Tiwari said, his government would give the people of Delhi five times of what AAP was offering in subsidies on power and water, apart from the free bus rides for women and other schemes.

He said that BJP would give the benefits to the people for five years, unlike the AAP which, he claimed, had introduced schemes for free bus ride and electricity in the last few months of its term.

South Delhi BJP MP Ramesh Bidhuri said while Kejriwal was comparing the work of his government with that of the municipal corporations, BJP was asking him about the schools, colleges and hospitals that he had promised but never built in the last five years.

“Kejriwal promised 500 new schools, 20 colleges, free Wi-Fi all over the city and houses for slum dwellers but could not do anything,” Bidhuri said, adding that people were waiting for the election to teach AAP a lesson.

Title: May reopen Loya case, some want to give proof: Minister
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

MUMBAI: Maharashtra home minister Anil Deshmukh on Thursday said he will be meeting some people who are close to the BH Loya case and want to give some fresh evidence in the case.

"I will be meeting some people, and will not be disclosing their names for obvious reasons. They want to present to me some additional information in the case. I will listen to their demands and study the documents in detail. If there is a need felt to re-open the case, that too will be done," Deshmukh said. He also said the people who have reached out to him have some documents, copies of call records and some videos to share.

The death of special CBI judge BH Loya in 2014 had generated controversy. Loya, who was hearing the Sohrabuddin Shaikh fake encounter case of Gujarat, died of cardiac arrest in Nagpur on December 1, 2014, when he had gone to attend the wedding of a colleague's daughter.

NCP chief Sharad Pawar had also said the Justice Loya case will be reinvestigated only if there is a fresh complaint and it has substantial evidence.

On the issue of cases registered during the Elgaar Parishad, Deshmukh said the department has sent him some documents regarding the case. "I am studying the case and also going through the court judgments. Once I get details, I will decide on the future course of action," he said.

Sharad Pawar had in December last year demanded that a Special Investigation Team be set up under a retired judge to probe the action taken by Pune police in the 2018 Koregaon Bhima case .

Title: Fodder scarcity, cattle loss hits milk production
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

CLEARED SKHER

Kolhapur: The last four months of 2019 brought a major worry for dairy farmers of the region, especially those in Kolhapur .

Dairies in the region have recorded a decline in milk production owing to the after-effects of devastating floods in August 2019. Not only did the farmers lose a lot of cattle, the water damaged sugar cane fields that provide easy fodder for the cattle. The hike in price of cattle feed only added to their woes.

Officials associated with dairy farming said the Kolhapur District Milk Producers Organisation, popularly known as Gokul, is facing daily drop of 2.50 to 3 lakh litre in milk production. Gokul is the biggest cooperative dairy in western Maharashtra and supplies milk to major cities including Mumbai and Pune.

According to the district cooperative department, the milk collection in the district has declined by seven lakh litres in a year. The total milk collected in the district in December 2018 was around 26,17,724 litres. In contrast, milk collection in December was 18,87,497 litres. The daily milk production has continued to reduce from three to seven lakh litres in last four months in 2019 compared with the year 2018.

Gokul director Arun Narke said they had daily collection of around 12 to 13 lakh litres of milk, which has reduced to 10 to 10.50 lakh per day now.

“Sudden changes in climate have affected milk production. The floods in August 2019 devastated life and cattle population in Kolhapur district and also the standing crops, including sugar cane. This led to a serious problem of fodder for cattle. The livestock residing on all the banks of the rivers in Kolhapur, Sangli and Satara districts are severely affected due to this,” he said.

Narke added that the price of cattle feed has increased, making it difficult to dairy farmers to sustain the cattle and impacted milk production.

Dairy farmers said the daily expenditure on maintaining cattle in the absence of ready cattle in their fields had become unbearable.

Ramesh Malgonda Patil, dairy farmer from Gadhinglaj, said, “The rate of cattle feed has increased by Rs 400 for 50 kg sack as compared with last year’s prices. We are also facing paucity of fodder to feed cattle due to floods. I have seven cattle that used to give 40 litre milk daily last year, which has now reduced to 30 litres per day. We are unable to meet daily expenditure on the cattle. The rearing of cattle is no more a profitable business now.”
