Title: HC calls for govt affidavit on steps for safety of bulls, owners
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Madurai: The Madras high court has directed the state government to file an affidavit with regard to the steps taken to ensure safety of bulls and their owners who wait behind the vadivasal (entry point of bulls to the arena) during jallikattu events. K M Thiruppathy, a resident of Madurai district, in his petition stated that he owned bulls, which had won prizes at various jallikattu events. He used to take care of his bulls with utmost care.

Every year when jallikattu events are conducted, officials concentrate on the steps taken in front of the vadivasal but fail to make safety arrangements behind it where the bulls and their owners would line up. Since there is no sufficient space behind the vadivasal, the bulls experience suffocation. He further stated that lack of sufficient space would also lead to injuries to the bulls and their owners.

Though he submitted a representation to the authorities concerned seeking to form a committee to ensure the safety of bulls and their owners behind vadivasal, no steps were taken in this regard.

Hence, the petitioner moved the high court seeking to constitute a committee to ensure the safety of jallikattu bulls and their owners behind vadivasal during jallikattu events conducted in Madurai district every year.

When the petition was heard on Thursday, additional advocate general K Chellapandian explained the steps taken by officials in various departments to ensure the safety of the bulls during jallikattu events. Taking note of the submission, a division bench of justice M Duraiswamy and justice T Ravindran directed the state to file an affidavit on Friday.

Title: Delhi: ‘MBBS doctor’ held as girl dies after his treatment
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: A man pretending to be an MBBS doctor was arrested as a 13-year-old girl , whom he had treated, died after having medicines given by him.

During questioning, Banshi Lal showed an ayurvedic degree. Police said that Lal used to run a clinic at Sanjay Colony in south Delhi’s Bhatti Mines and treated local residents claiming to be an MBBS doctor.

DCP (south) Atul Thakur said that they received a complaint from Bachchu Paswan, who said that his daughter was suffering from a health issue due to which he had consulted Lal. Lal assured Paswan that the girl would recover soon and gave her some medicines and an injection. This, however, deteriorated her condition and she died. Based on Paswan’s complaint a case was registered for culpable homicide. The accused was produced before court and sent to judicial custody. TNN

Title: AAP govt crippled us by denying funds: Corporations
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Kamaljeet Sehrawat

NEW DELHI: Taking strong exception to the criticism by CM Arvind Kejriwal , officials of the three corporations on Thursday accused AAP government of deliberately crippling the civic bodies by deducting more than Rs 10,000 crore from their kitty between 2014-15 and 2019-20.

Kamaljeet Sehrawat, leader of House in SDMC, said while the south body was the only financially viable corporation in the city, further fund cuts in the last two years had compelled it to stop all development work. “We used to get Rs 380 crore annually under the sanitation head, but the government reduced it to zero, forcing us to divert funds from development projects,” she said.

Despite this, Sehrawat said, the corporations had beautified 12 flyovers under PWD as well as parks on Delhi government land, besides developing the waste-to-wonder park.

She said SDMC’s performance was comparable with that of Delhi government. “As many as 400 of our 486 schools have CCTV cameras, 286 have smart classes, 100 have gyms for kids and playstations. Our happiness curriculum with bagless day is functional for two years. Our classrooms are no less than Delhi government schools and while ours cost Rs 8-9 lakh, they have spent Rs 20-25 lakh on each.”

EDMC mayor Anju Kamalkant said the east body was hit the worst by the trifurcation of MCD but was being given step-motherly treatment. “We are getting even the basic machinery for fighting pollution through the Rs 100 crore received from the Centre. EDMC has over Rs 3,000 crore pending from Delhi government as dues. We have the poorest areas with the largest chunk of JJ clusters and unauthorised colonies,” she said. “We don’t even have funds to provide uniforms and basic equipment. Give us funds and then judge us”

North Delhi mayor Avtar Singh said the corporation was carrying out its obligatory functions despite financial troubles created by Delhi government. He said the fund allocation was much better under the Sheila Dikshit regime.

Jai Prakash, standing committee chairperson of north Delhi municipal corporation, hit out at AAP and claimed that no such tussle regarding fund allocations happened during the Sheila Dikshit led Congress government.

Title: HC slaps Rs 15,000 cost for filing false ‘abduction’ case
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Madurai: Madras high court has imposed a cost of Rs 15,000 on a petitioner for filing a false case stating that his father, who is the ward councillor of Mudukulathur panchayat union in Ramanathapuram district, was abducted.

In his petition, S Raja stated that his father Sathaiah had won the local body election for the councillor’s post as a DMK candidate. However, he has been missing since January 3 when he went out of the house. He claimed that when his mother contacted him over phone, he informed her that he had been abducted by four highly influential people to prevent him from voting to elect the chairman of Mudukulathur panchayat union on January 11.

Since the Mudukulathur police registered a community service register, he filed a habeas corpus petition before HC Madurai bench. The court, in its previous hearing on Wednesday, directed police officials to produce the petitioner’s father on Thursday, failing which the Ramanathapuram SP was told to appear before the court. Accordingly, when the petition was heard on Thursday, the police officials produced Sathaiah before the court.

However, the abduction case took a turn when Sathaiah informed the court that he was not abducted and was living with his daughter.

Taking note of the submissions, a division bench of Justice T Raja and Justice B Pugalendhi imposed a cost of Rs 15,000 on Raja for wasting the court’s time by filing a false case. The petitioner was asked to pay the cost to the High Court Legal Services Authority within 10 days.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: SP MP Azam Khan, wife and son declared absconders
Content:
File photo of Samajwadi Party MP Azam Khan

Police official pasting a notice on the gate of the residence of Samajwadi Party MP Azam Khan in Rampur on Thursday.

RAMPUR: UP police on Thursday put up notices on the house of senior Samajwadi Party (SP) leader and Rampur MP Azam Khan, declaring him, his wife and son absconders. The court had declared them absconders in three cases recently, a police officer said, adding that the next step will be the attachment of their properties.On Thursday morning, an old and frail man sitting on rickshaw and carrying a battery-operated mike, announced that Azam Khan, his wife and Rampur MLA Tanzeen Fatimah and son Abdullah Azam were absconders in a locality where the SP leader holds sway. A man beating drum also followed him.The exercise, known as ‘munadi’ in official parlance, is part of Section 82 of Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC) and is used when a warrant against an accused cannot be executed.Speaking to TOI, additional district government counsel Ramautar Saini said, “The court directed the police to comply with the proclamation notice against Azam Khan and others into the matter.” Earlier, the court had issued non-bailable warrants against the Khans after they had failed to present themselves before it. Additional district and sessions judge Dhirendra Kamboj on Wednesday proclaimed them “absconder” invoking Section 82 of CrPC.Speaking to TOI, Rampur’s circle 0fficer Satyajit Gupta said, “Azam Khan and his family members against whom the non-bailable warrants were issued by the court failed to appear before it. Therefore in compliance of Section 82 of CrPc, apart from ‘munadi’, the proclamation notice was put up on the wall of his house as well.”On Wednesday, the court gave a fresh date and asked them to appear before it on January 24 in connection with alleged forged birth certificate of Abdullah Azam, whose election from Suar assembly constituency was recently annulled by the Allahabad high court.In two other cases, they have been asked to appear on January 20. On January 3, 2019, BJP leader Akash Saxena had logged a complaint alleging that Azam and his wife helped their son in obtaining two fake birth certificates — one from Lucknow and another from Rampur. Following the complaint, the Ganj kotwali police registered an FIR against the trio under sections 420 (cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property), 467 (forgery of valuable security, will), 468 (forgery for purpose of cheating) and 471 (using as genuine a forged document) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC). Later, the high court annulled the election of Abdullah as Suar MLA on the ground that he was underage and not qualified to fight the 2017 elections.The court had also issued the proclamation orders in another case registered against Azam and his three supporters for rioting and other offences based on the complaint of the former UP minister’s neighbour.

Title: Jyoti Nivas College standoff over CAA snowballs
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Bengaluru: High drama prevailed at Jyoti Nivas College, Koramangala, Bengaluru on Thursday, with parents, students and youths staging separate protests against what they called “high-handedness” of BJP workers, who erected a poster endorsing the controversial Citizenship (Amendment) Act and allegedly forced students of the college to sign it.

With the protest gaining steam, politicians of various parties traded words over the incident and some even made a beeline to the women-only college. With tension simmering, the college management promptly announced holidays on Friday and Saturday. Class tests scheduled for Saturday were postponed.

#StandWithJNC trended on Twitter for most part of the day. Taking note of the developments, chief minister BS Yediyurappa said police have been instructed to investigate the matter.

Tension at the college mounted on Wednesday, when at around 3.30pm, BJP workers led by Mohan Kumar, the party’s BTM Layout general secretary, erected a poster supporting CAA on the college compound wall. Workers then allegedly forced students walking out of the gates to sign the poster to show support for the controversial law. Several students took exception to the party workers’ conduct and an argument ensued. Videos of the argument were widely shared on social media.

On Thursday, some parents of students arrived at the college in the morning and demanded security for their wards. They said BJP workers’ conduct raised serious questions over their wards’ safety.

A group of students then held a demonstration outside the college during the lunch break. “Students from other colleges also arrived to support them. Due to safety reasons, we asked the girls to get inside the college,” said a JNC professor.

Students were allowed to hold a silent protest inside the college. Protesters said it was as much against BJP workers’ behaviour as against CAA. “BJP workers spoke rudely to our collegemates and misbehaved with them. They did not have any permission to put pictures on our college walls,” said Krithika (name changed), a JNC student.

“They asked us if the college wall belonged to us. They called it public property, which is incorrect. As students of JNC, we have a sense of belonging to the college and ownership of its properties. We do not want anyone to vandalize our college property,” Krithika said.

Another student said, “We were initially neutral on CAA, but after yesterday’s incident, we have decided to stand up against the law.”

Tension escalated when a group of boys, claiming to be brothers and friends of JNC students, landed at the campus gates and demanded that they be allowed inside to show solidarity with the girls. The management denied entry to all outsiders, but the boys began shouting slogans against the BJP.

One protesting youth, who claimed his sister was a student of JNC, said: “I am worried over the safety of my sister. This is the plight of many of us, whose kin are studying in JNC.”

With additional reinforcements in place, police asked the boys to disperse and they fell in line. With a huge contingent of police in front of the campus, the college asked its students to leave from the back gate by 3pm after declaring a two-day holiday.

Title: BBMP banks on injection wells to prevent underpass flooding
Content:
Of the 24 underpasses in Bengaluru, at least 10 are known to flood during heavy rain

TimesView The depleting groundwater table is a bundle of paradoxes. While groundwater in itself is, geologically, a common property resource that runs without barriers, its unbridled exploitation is largely private. With replenishment of the groundwater table possible only by harvesting runoff rainwater, public bodies have a larger role. BBMP’s initiative to create injection wells in underpasses is ingenious but everything hinges on implementation. However, this certainly is an opportunity for the agency to redeem itself after having left Bengalureans to live with what are apologies for underpasses.

How it works

Tapping rainwater

BENGALURU: Flooded with complaints about underpasses across the city getting inundated at the slightest hint of rain, BBMP is creating injection wells at the structures to prevent waterlogging and to recharge the groundwater table.The first of such wells has come up at the Sankey Road-Cunningham Road junction underpass . It was successfully tested on Wednesday.“Almost 10,000 litres of recycled water was used for the trial run,” BBMP commissioner BH Anil Kumar said. The 230-ft recharge pit took in all the water in less than five minutes. “We will replicate the project in underpasses across Bengaluru,” he added.Of 24 underpasses in the city, at least 10 are known to flood during rain. Located at Puttenahalli, Kadirenahalli, Tagore Circle, Kadubeesanahalli, Cunningham Road-Sankey Road junction, Doddanekkundi, KR Circle, Palace Road near Maharani College and Kasturinagar, they turn into pools, making it impossible for vehicles and pedestrians to even enter them. BBMP will create injection wells at all these 10 underpasses as the first step.“Though the underpasses have drains, waterlogging persists because they haven’t been laid properly. We hope injection wells will be able to resolve the problem,” a senior BBMP official said.V Ramprasad, an expert on lakes and water conservation, told TOI if BBMP is planning to come up with injection wells, the water quality has to be good, without any impurity. This can happen only if it’s directly injected into the fractures of hard rock layer, he said.An injection well leads water deep into the subterranean surface. Silt traps filter the dirt and debris before the run-off is diverted into the well. Also, multiple layers of filtration media placed at the top purify water to the maximum extent, BBMP officials explained.Kumar said each well can harvest 2.1 million litres of rainwater in a year, and if such structures are created at all underpasses, the city’s groundwater table may never plunge.BBMP is betting big on rainwater harvesting to address the city’s drinking water needs. Injection wells are among the agency’s initiatives to aggressively harvest rainwater.According to another senior official, the city receives an average rainfall of 800mm per year. “Precipitation of just 12.5mm can yield 50,000 litres of water per acre. Even if 40% of water is lost due to evaporation/runoff and soil absorption, a minimum of 30,000 litres of the assured quantity of water can be recharged into the groundwater source daily,” he explained.

Title: 10 children fall victim to crimes every day in Mumbai
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: Every day, 10 children fall victim to crimes in Mumbai.

A total of 10,701 children became victims of different types of crimes in Mumbai between 2016 and 2018, according to the latest NCRB report. Mumbai ranked second in the rate of crimes against children per a population of one lakh, though it recorded a marginal, 7.4% dip in cases in 2018 to 3,511 from 3,790 a year earlier.

While Delhi topped among cities, Mumbai has occupied the second spot for three years now, followed by Bengaluru, Indore and Pune. The report showed the majority of cases reported in Mumbai included kidnapping, followed by unnatural sex, murder, abetment to murder, infanticide, foeticide, exposure and abandonment of newborns.

Experts said newborns are abandoned on the roadside or are found dumped in garbage bins.

Investigators said towards rural areas of the state, children are abandoned due to poverty and females due to social prejudices in favour of the male child. In urban areas such as Mumbai, the majority of abandoned children are those born out of the wedlock.

Requesting anonymity, a senior IPS officer said a major chunk of kidnapping cases are of minors who elope and who are later tracked down.

Cases of rape, though, continue to be reported regularly, especially from slums.

“Take the example of Kurla’s 2011 Nehru Nagar rape and murder of three minor girls. All the minors were lured with chocolates by the accused,” said the officer.

Investigation into abandonment, foeticide and infanticide is given top priority. “We continuously seek information from civic bodies (health teams) about action taken against quacks and those who carry out illegal pregnancy and abortion tests. Accordingly, action is taken and further probe is carried out after a case is registered,” a senior IPS officer told TOI.

RTI activist Jitendra Ghadge said it is unfortunate that most of Maharashtra ’s population is still socially and economically backward. “It is not easy for any woman to abandon her newborn but poverty and family pressure for a male child puts a lot of pressure on her. The state sovernment has failed to empower women with education and livelihood. Social and economic independence of a woman is the only solution.”

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: HC seeks govt counter on plea to redo corpn delimitation
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Madurai: The Madras high court has directed the state government to file a counter on a public interest litigation (PIL) filed by DMK MLA of Madurai Central constituency P T R Palanivel Thiagarajan seeking to re-do the delimitation exercise for Madurai Corporation.

In his petition, Thiagarajan stated that Madurai Corporation is the second largest by territorial area and third largest population-wise in the state. It is divided into four zones with a total of 100 wards.

After the announcement of delimitation of wards, he submitted a representation to the Madurai district collector in 2018 in that regard, however, it was not considered.

He stated that the delimitation of the wards violates certain basic principles specified by the delimitation commission constituted under the Tamil Nadu Local Bodies Delimitation Regulations, 2017, and Section 3(1) of Tamil Nadu Commission Regulations Act, 2017.

The boundaries of an assembly constituency should not be altered during the delimitation process. He stated that the creation of a ward that spreads across the boundaries of an assembly constituency is also a violation of law and it is against the principles specified in the People’s Representation Act and Tamil Nadu Delimitation Commission Act.

Since the urban local body elections have not been declared in the state, the delimitation of wards in Madurai Corporation can be rectified before election is notified.

Hence, the petitioner moved the high court Madurai bench seeking to declare the current delimitation of wards null and void and sought to re-do the entire exercise of delimitation by strictly complying with the provisions of Act and Regulations.

When the petition of Palanivel Thiagarajanwas heard on Thursday, a division bench of justice M Duraiswamy and justice T Ravindran gave the direction to the state.

Title: Jaipur: After Madhya Pradesh, Rajasthan has maximum numbers of rapes
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Image used for representational purpose

JAIPUR: According to NCRB data for 2018, Rajasthan has the highest number of rape cases only after the neighbouring state of Madhya Pradesh . A total of 4,335 rape cases were lodged, out of which 3,305 were of adult women, while the remaining were of girls below 18 years. The state stands among top five in the country in attempt to rape cases. In 2017, the state witnessed 3,305 rapes and has gone up by one rank in this category.

While Madhya Pradesh had recorded 5,433 rape cases, Uttar Pradesh had 3,946 such cases followed by Maharashtra with 2,142 cases and Chhattisgarh with 2,091. Out of the total rape cases in Rajasthan, 299 were in Jaipur In attempt to commit rape also Rajasthan had one of the highest figures with 620 cases registered out of which 583 were of adult women and remaining of minors. In this category, 18 cases were in Jaipur.

The number was also high of incidents of assault on women with the intention to outrage her modesty with 5249 cases recorded out of which 301 were in the state capital.

In 3,748 rapes, the offenders were known to the survivors which are 86.5% of the total cases. Recently Rajasthan police also released data which indicated an alarming rise in the number of rape cases registered across the state, reporting an increase of 81.45% in 2019 when compared to 2017. In 2019, the registered rape cases reached 5,997 according to official figures. There was an increase in rapes by 38.34% from 2018 to 2019. The increase in the case of rapes being reported is also due to the initiative of free registration which was introduced in 2019. According to police data, sexual crimes against children also saw an increase with 22% more rape cases registered under Pocso Act.

Title: ‘90% crimes against women are solved’
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: Mumbai saw 10% rise in crimes against women in 2018 with 6,058 cases compared with 5,453 in the previous year, shows the latest NCRB data.

Among 19 cities with over 20 lakh people, Mumbai ranked 13 in the rate of crimes against women per a one lakh population. Lucknow saw the maximum rate of crimes against women in the country with 2,736 cases in 2018.

Delhi registered 13,803 cases in 2016, which fell to 11,542 in 2017 and then increased slightly to 11,724 in 2018.

“Women in urban areas are no longer willing to take things lying down. Earlier, there was shame associated with reporting offences. Women would brush aside instances of sexual harassment but they are no longer quiet. The call log of police’s 103 helpline shows that the maximum complaints received are of domestic violence, followed by molestation. It is a positive sign that women are now more open to registration of offences,” said Y P Singh, IPS-officer-turned lawyer.

Social media has played an important role too, with survivors sharing photographs of perpetrators online and tagging security agencies.

According to NCRB, Maharashtra had the highest number of cases of abetment of suicide, abducting, stalking, voyeurism and assault. “Data usually shows crimes against women rising in urban areas, but not as much in rural belts. This doesn’t mean women are not being harassed in villages. There is just no environment to report crimes. Victims do not know whom to approach, there are no NGOs to support them, the victims are located very far from a taluka and in general no systems work,” said advocate Flavia Agnes of NGO Majlis.

Agnes said police in Maharashtra and Mumbai take the initiative to lodge complaints. Even survivors are coming forward to lodge complaints, she added.

Former Thane police commissioner S P S Yadav, too, said women who are not aware of legal assistance and live or work in isolated places are at greater risk of facing crimes.

Santosh Rastogi, joint commissioner of police (crime), said the increase in cases was also due rising awareness among the masses. “We are also doing a lot of awareness programs. Our ‘Police Didi Project’ is on and people are now coming forward to lodge complaints in such crimes. We are registering all such cases,” said Rastogi.

Rastogi further said the police pay special attention to crimes against women as well as detection of cases.

“The detection rate of crimes against women is 90%. CCTV footage is a great help in identifying an accused and arresting him. A speedy probe and preventive action against habitual offenders is undertaken too.”

Title: Nagpur: Opening of Reach I Metro stations delayed by six months
Content:
This story is from January 10, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: MahaMetro had promised to open all stations of Reach I (Sitabuldi to Khapri stretch) by December 2019 end. However, now officials say it will take another six months.

Metro’s figures show that opening of new stations increased ridership. Despite this, it has failed to open the stations as per schedule.

Reach I had been inaugurated by Prime Minister Narendra Modi in March 2019. At that time, five stations were operational — Sitabuldi Interchange, Airport, Airport South, New Airport and Khapri. It took MahaMetro another six months to open a new station — Jai Prakash Nagar in November.

Five more stations — Rahate Colony, Congress Nagar, Ajni Square, Chhatrapati Nagar and Ujjwal Nagar — have to be opened. According to a Metro official, Rahate Colony station would be started this month. “Chhatrapati Nagar and Ajni Square stations will be ready in February, while Congress Nagar station will be ready by March end or April first week. Ujjwal Nagar station will take some time because we got the land recently. The land owner had moved the court,” said the official.

According to the official, opening of Congress Nagar station may be delayed further as Metro plans to open Manish Nagar railway underbridge (RUB) in March end anyhow. “As contractor is the same for the two works, he may concentrate on the RUB at the cost of the station,” he said.

Metro may complete construction as per its schedule, but opening the stations will take more time. Commissioner of Metro Rail Safety (CMRS) will have to inspect each station and then give a green signal for opening them for the public. Metro officials, therefore, expect all the stations, barring Ujjwal Nagar, to be open by the middle of the year.

Commenting on the reasons for the delay, the official said initial contractor ILFS went bust forcing the Metro to re-tender the works.

The official said that work on stations of Reach III (Sitabuldi to Lokmanya Nagar stretch) was going ahead at full pace. “Bansi Nagar station will be ready this month. Wasudeo Nagar station is almost complete. Rachna T-point, LAD Square and Shankar Nagar stations will be ready by April or at the most May. Dharampeth College station will be the last as it has a viewing gallery,” he added.

Commenting on the delay in opening of Reach III, the official said that it was expected this month.
